220.spr_content: Security is essential for client trust, extending beyond technology into reputation and compliance.  <hr />Early focus on features shifts to security concerns as enterprise clients inquire about privacy, GDPR, and data protection.  <hr />Addressing security builds trust, enables scaling, and attracts new clients.  <hr />A strategic security plan is necessary to embed security across development without hindering agility.  <hr />Objectives include securing applications, data, infrastructure; achieving GDPR, ISO compliance; providing transparency; maintaining speed.  <hr />Security must be a continuous, integrated process spanning application, data, and infrastructure security domains.  <hr />Application security involves protecting against unauthorized access and vulnerabilities via secure authentication, API best practices, and penetration testing guided by OWASP.  <hr />Data security prioritizes confidentiality, integrity, and availability through encryption at rest and transit, privacy rights, and data deletion mechanisms aligned with GDPR and CCPA.  <hr />Development and infrastructure security require role controls, multi-factor authentication, employee cybersecurity training, and adherence to ISO 27001 standards.  <hr />A three-month phased roadmap enables quick wins and long-term resilience:  <hr />- Phase 1: Implement MFA, secure tokens, AES-256 encryption.  <hr />- Phase 2: Address OWASP top risks, enhance data privacy, transparency, and consent processes.  <hr />- Phase 3: Segregate environment layers, set up comprehensive log management and alerts.  <hr />Security strategies must be tailored to the company's specific context, client needs, and resources, balancing immediate and future goals.  <hr />This high-level plan offers a flexible, scalable foundation to construct a customized, effective security approach aligned with organizational priorities.

221.title: How I came up with our Security Standard
221.description: In this memo, I want to share with you my thought process behind our security guideline for Dwarves. This is a critical aspect for a software company that aims to establish trusted partnerships with clients. They rely on us because we take the security of their ideas and data seriously.
221.spr_content: - Security guidelines for Dwarves are critical for establishing trusted client partnerships and safeguarding ideas and data.  <hr />- Developed due to client requests, emphasizing data leak prevention despite existing NDAs.  <hr />- Noted low security awareness among team members, with behaviors in public channels and insecure remote work environments.  <hr />- Enhancing security capabilities is strategic for winning larger clients and overall strength.  <hr />- Compliance considerations include aligning with standards like ISO 27001 and GDPR to streamline client onboarding.  <hr />- The remote work model necessitates security measures beyond physical controls, addressing network vulnerabilities and unauthorized access.  <hr />- Daily activities—coding, browsing, breaks—pose security risks; awareness and preventive practices are emphasized.  <hr />- The guideline is designed to be accessible, concise, and easy to adopt during training.  <hr />- Structured into three sections: setup/configuration, daily operations, and management/reporting.  <hr />- Each section contains practical dos and don'ts, with visual aids to reinforce understanding.  <hr />- Implementation aims to embed security into routines, enhancing reputation, professionalism, and responsibility toward client assets.

222.title: DuckDB demo and showcase
222.description:
DuckDB is a great starting point for modern stacks that don't need to worry about scalability, but want to derive hard analytics from the data that they have. This meeting will do a 3-part demo of DuckDB (15 minutes total):
• Consolidate NYC taxi data in parallel (through map-reduce) over HTTPS
• Aggregate IBM AML transactions (Anti-Money Laundering)
• Some examples of how it is used to consolidate and do basic analytics on note.d and log.console.so
222.spr_content: - DuckDB is a lightweight, emerging OLAP database optimized for analytical workloads with small to moderate data sizes (1GB-10GB).  <hr />- It is suitable for modern stacks prioritizing ease of use over scalability concerns.  <hr />- Use cases include data consolidation, ad hoc analytics, and quick iterative analysis in startups like MotherDuck.  <hr />- The upcoming demo (23/11/2023, internal Discord 🎙・labs-stage) features a three-part showcase:  <hr />  - Parallel NYC taxi data consolidation via map-reduce over HTTPS.  <hr />  - IBM AML transaction aggregation to detect money laundering.  <hr />  - Examples of basic analytics on notes and logs.  <hr />- Demo objectives: assess DuckDB’s applicability for current and future projects; establish demo formats for new tech.  <hr />- Visuals:  <hr />  - Metadata aggregation from Notion notes into Parquet files (`memo.d.foundation`).  <hr />  - Parallel NYC taxi data analysis via HTTPFS, illustrating local versus server-based database flexibility.  <hr />- Key metaphor: DuckDB as a fast, local analytical engine suited for small-scale, iterative data analysis rather than large-scale warehouse-scale workloads.
222.tags: demo discussion duckdb dwarves event internal labs work workshop

223.title: Explaining Gradient Descent in Machine Learning with a simple analogy
223.description: Gradient descent is a fundamental optimization algorithm in machine learning. It's a way for models to learn from data and improve their accuracy by gradually adjusting their internal settings. Think of it like carefully descending a hill to find the lowest point—each small step you take brings you closer to the best possible solution.
223.spr_content: Gradient descent: optimization algorithm akin to descending a foggy mountain.  <hr />- Mountain = error function in machine learning.  <hr />- Downhill direction = gradient indicating steepest decrease in error.  <hr />- Small steps = parameter adjustments to reduce error.  <hr />- Repeated steps = iterative tuning of model parameters.  <hr />- Looking around = computing gradients to find the descent direction.  <hr />- Lowest point = minimal error, optimal learning.  <hr />- Process mimics climbing down a hill seeking a hidden treasure—finding the most accurate model fitting data.  <hr />- The computer (you) navigates the error landscape by incremental steps toward the global minimum.

224.title: Design feedback mechanism for LLM applications
224.description: Improving AI models requires collecting accurate user feedback,which can be difficult. The article explores more into the importance of collecting human feedback and discusses the need for creating an organized database to effectively store and use this valuable input. We hope to continuously improve our large language models, ensuring they deliver greater performance and match user expectations more effectively.
224.spr_content: - LLM answer consistency and accuracy depend on effective feedback mechanisms.<hr />- Incorporating a user feedback collection system is crucial for continuous improvement.<hr />- Logging all interactions, including implicit signals and explicit responses, is the foundation of feedback collection.<hr />- Feedback logs include prompt context, model parameters, and user reactions.<hr />- Feedback data supports model fine-tuning and pre-training, primarily via RLHF.<hr />- Validation employs A/B testing and validation agents to ensure performance gains.<hr />- Deployment involves ongoing feedback collection for real-time monitoring.<hr />- Implicit feedback derives from user behaviors: stopping generation indicates dissatisfaction.<hr />- Users checking AI answers externally signal distrust; regenerating responses indicates unmet needs.<hr />- Explicit feedback involves direct signals: likes/dislikes, ratings, surveys, textual comments.<hr />- Organized data schemas—`chat_feedback` and `feedback_type` tables—systematize feedback storage.<hr />- `chat_feedback` links feedback to conversation (`thread_id`, `chat_id`) with categorized `type_id`.<hr />- Feedback categories (e.g., "Too long," "Irrelevant") are stored in `feedback_type`.<hr />- Proper feedback categorization enables pattern recognition and targeted improvements.<hr />- Feedback collection creates high-quality datasets for RLHF training.<hr />- Logical steps: collect, organize, analyze, then train models iteratively.<hr />- Designing a feedback log database ensures traceability and facilitates model fine-tuning.<hr />- Future training steps involve human-in-the-loop datasets, leveraging categorized feedback.<hr />- Continuous feedback monitoring and analysis drive model accuracy, relevance, and user satisfaction.

225.title: Memo Knowledge Base Meeting
225.description: Here are the simple steps we follow each week to keep the Memo content pipeline organized and our team informed.
225.spr_content: - Memo serves as Dwarves' team wiki; central for work, learning, operations.  <hr />- Written for craftsmen, by team members.  <hr />- Weekly routine: update content pipeline, coordinate, and stay organized.  <hr />- Check all Memo to-do lists in Basecamp; ensure content pipeline is current.  <hr />- Prepare succinct updates on changes/new info; share at Friday meetings.  <hr />- Confirm `memo.d.foundation > Home` shows latest content.  <hr />- Assign content clusters to responsible team members in Basecamp; clarify responsibilities.  <hr />- Prioritize urgent content: move to "Soon"; keep "Soon" ≤ 10 items.  <hr />- Emphasize tasks by importance; meet deadlines.  <hr />- Develop and maintain content map: track existing, updating, and planned content.  <hr />- Use guides to create and optimize the content map.  <hr />- Weekly adherence to checklist keeps Memo active and projects on track.

226.title: Labs Weekly Catchup #1
226.description: Our first weekly catchup. We organize an agenda the day beforehand and consolidate our findings, notable research progress, possibly new tech, insight or technique everyone should know.
226.spr_content: - LLMs utilize Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) for real-time context updates.  <hr />- Realtime memory advances incorporate unique base prompts to improve data integration within LLMs.  <hr />- Token limitations are being mitigated via fewer steps and optimized prompting strategies.  <hr />- Rust game server developed with Actix shows significant progress; multiplayer shooter demo showcased.  <hr />- Tokio explored as cost-effective alternative to Actix; documentation gaps identified for tooling improvements.  <hr />- Mochi UI practices focus on standardization in Figma, component naming, and usability; workshop scheduled for Dec 14, 2023.  <hr />- WebStudio is an open-source low-code framework for website creation, inspired by WebFlow, supporting large tree sync and live collaboration via immerhin.  <hr />- Emerging standards include JSON patches (RFC 6902) for efficient JSON updates, and W3C design tokens for consistent visual styling.

227.title: How to withdraw ICY
227.description: This guide show how to swap ICY to fiat.
227.spr_content: - To withdraw ICY, pre-setup a crypto wallet and Binance wallet; if absent, follow setup guidelines.<hr />- Use Mochi command to withdraw tokens; input your crypto wallet address upon clicking “Enter address.”<hr />- Ensure Ethereum exists on Base Network for ICY to USDT swap; acquire via purchase or faucet (ticket Dwarves Discord).<hr />- Swap ICY to USDT at icy.so; connect wallet, select Base network, approve, input amount, confirm transactions.<hr />- Bridge USDC from Base to Binance via Stargate Finance; select Base to BNB, input amount, approve transfer.<hr />- Retrieve Binance deposit address: go to Wallet > Funding > Deposit > USDT > BNB network; copy address.<hr />- Transfer tokens from Coinbase wallet to Binance: Send > select token & amount > paste Binance address > review & send.<hr />- Final step: use P2P trading to convert USDT to local bank or Visa, completing withdrawal.

228.title: Building a Data-Driven Project Reporting System: A Lens into Modern Data Engineering
228.description: Learn how to transition from application development to data engineering by building a modern project reporting system. Discover essential mindset shifts, best practices, and hands-on look using tools like DuckDB, and Modal. Master system-level architecture and data pipeline design for scalable enterprise solutions.
228.spr_content: - Transitioning from application development to data engineering is akin to shifting from building furniture to constructing entire houses; it requires thinking about foundations, load-bearing structures, and system-wide flows.  <hr />- Application development is bottom-up: focus on individual features, immediate responses, and discrete transactions (CRUD, single requests).  <hr />- System-level data engineering demands a top-down mindset: design for continuous data flows, scalability, and future growth; focus on data as a stream of events rather than static snapshots.  <hr />- Building an automated project reporting system illustrates the shift: from handling isolated components to orchestrating complex data pipelines across multiple sources (Discord, Git, team metrics).  <hr />- The application view (client, application, data, UI layers) handles requests reactively, optimized for small-scale operations.  <hr />- The data engineer’s view models data as flows: source collection, raw storage (Data Lake), structured transformation (Data Warehouse), creation of views, and serving through interfaces.  <hr />- Systems are designed around processing paradigms: **Map-Reduce**, **ETL**, **Event Streaming**, and **Parallel Processing**—patterns consistent across scales and problem domains.  <hr />- Data flow patterns are anticipative: understanding how data propagates, scales, and integrates beyond individual transactions; system boundaries are fuzzy, flexible, and designed for growth.  <hr />- Automation is akin to conducting an orchestra: each component (parameters, extraction, processing, reduction) interplays harmoniously within a system, not isolated units.  <hr />- Data engineering tools support this system-level thinking:  <hr />  - **Processing Engines**: Spark (distributed), DuckDB (fast analytics), Beam (unified flow).  <hr />  - **Storage Solutions**: Data Lakes (raw data reservoir), Data Warehouses (structured insights), Data Formats (efficient communication).  <hr />  - **Orchestration**: Airflow, Dagster, Modal—managing dependencies, scaling, and holistic monitoring.  <hr />- Architecturally, storage format choices (like Parquet) enable efficient, scalable querying; query engines (DuckDB) process data in place; orchestration frameworks control end-to-end workflows, emphasizing system coherence.  <hr />- The evolution emphasizes a paradigm shift:  <hr />  - From feature-focused, request-driven (application) approaches  <hr />  - To system-wide, pattern-based, flow-oriented (data engineering) approaches.  <hr />- Core contrasts highlight:  <hr />  - Problem-solving shifts from individual features to scalable architecture.  <hr />  - Data movement from reactive requests to anticipatory design.  <hr />  - Scale from linear, user-focused to exponential, system-wide capacity.  <hr />  - Boundaries become fuzzy, adaptable.  <hr />  - Processing from synchronous, immediate to asynchronous, batch-oriented.  <hr />- Developing a systems mindset involves balancing immediate needs with long-term architecture, recognizing that in data engineering, the system itself is the ultimate feature; success depends on cohesive integration, not just component correctness.

229.title: How to push content on memo.d.foundation
229.description: This is a guide on how to setup your environment and settings to push content to our notes website, memo.d.foundation.
229.spr_content: - Ensure environment setup for memo editing via linked guide.<hr />- Verify access rights and repository ownership before proceeding.<hr />- Keep local data synchronized with remote repository through Source Control.<hr />- To create a post, select appropriate folder or default to `vault/playground/00_fleeting`.<hr />- Use New files icon, name file with `.md` extension for segmentation.<hr />- Insert metadata block with tags, title, date, description, authors at top.<hr />- Edit post content below metadata.<hr />- Save changes with `Cmd+S`.<hr />- Preview site via `devbox shell`, `make watch-run`, localhost.<hr />- For review, capture entire post page, send to supervisor and @anna.<hr />- Commit local changes: sync, stage, name commit, and commit.<hr />- Push changes to remote branch.<hr />- Log into GitHub, navigate repositories, select branch.<hr />- Create pull request for admin review.<hr />- Await approval to publish post.

230.title: Radix Sort
230.description: Radix Sort is a non-comparative sorting algorithm that sorts integers by processing individual digits. Unlike comparison-based algorithms (like Quick Sort or Merge Sort), Radix Sort groups numbers by their individual digits.
230.spr_content: Radix Sort is a non-comparative, digit-based sorting algorithm. It groups numbers by individual digit positions, from LSD to MSD. Stability is essential to preserve order of equal keys. Counting Sort is used internally for digit sorting, ensuring stability. The algorithm finds the maximum number to determine digit count, then iteratively sorts by each digit using buckets (0-9 for decimal). After distributing into buckets based on current digit, numbers are collected back in order. This repeats for each digit, from least to most significant. Its time complexity is O(n×k), with n elements and k digit length, and space complexity is O(n+k). Advantages include predictable linear performance when k is small; disadvantages involve limited scope to integers or fixed-length strings, and additional memory for counting.

231.title: Writing Content for Multimedia Guidelines
231.description: To help all our Dwarves team members, create original, helpful, and consistent writing across various platforms, we've put together this content guideline as a reference whenever we're writing for Dwarves.
231.spr_content: - Communication power lies in understanding and sufficient context, not total unification of language.<hr />- Words shape brand identity, foster connections, and facilitate knowledge sharing.<hr />- Dwarves emphasizes quality and consistency in writing, akin to product creation—focused on people first.<hr />- Writing goals include: informing, connecting emotionally, educating, expressing viewpoints confidently, entertaining clearly, inspiring positivity, and learning continuously.<hr />- To "inform," define the desired perception of Dwarves’ personality and reputation.<hr />- To "connect," evoke emotional resonance and memorable impressions about Dwarves Design.<hr />- To "educate," share knowledge openly, even beyond direct offerings, to promote growth.<hr />- To "express," confidently share perspectives, maintaining objectivity and expertise.<hr />- To "entertain," simplify complex ideas, making tech accessible and engaging for all levels, ensuring learning remains enjoyable.<hr />- To "inspire," use uplifting language that celebrates collective progress, success, and industry advancements.<hr />- To "learn," adopt a growth mindset by asking questions, reflecting, and seeking feedback for continual improvement.<hr />- Favor active voice for clarity, engagement, and authority; minimize passive constructions.<hr />- Write in a conversational second person ("you") and include "we" to foster inclusivity and teamwork recognition.<hr />- Make content scannable by using short paragraphs, hierarchical structuring, and visual cues.<hr />- Target calls to action carefully—align them with audience interests, context, and industry relevance—avoiding over-promotion or misalignment.<hr />- Emojis are acceptable for fostering brand personality but used sparsely; overuse diminishes professionalism.<hr />- Limit exclamation points and question marks; use expressive language instead of punctuation overload.<hr />- Simplify technical jargon—define terms plainly to ensure accessibility and understanding.<hr />- Apply relevant tags and hashtags for enhanced content discoverability and reach.<hr />- Respect copyright laws, credit sources, and obtain permissions when necessary.<hr />- Rigorously proofread for structure, grammar, accuracy; seek guidance if multiple guidelines are missed.<hr />- Reflect post-publication: assess performance, seek feedback, identify improvements, and stay informed of industry trends.<hr />- Maintain an authentic voice portraying Dwarves as a skilled, trustworthy partner committed to shared growth.<hr />- Adapt tone according to context: casual and sincere generally, but sensitive to appropriateness, respectful of channel and audience nuances.<hr />- Aim for content that resonates—relatable, valuable, engaging—and builds long-term audience trust.

232.title: Dynamic Liquidity Market Maker - a new form of concentrated liquidity AMM on Solana
232.description: a new form of concentrated liquidity AMM on solana
232.spr_content: - DLMM introduces a concentrated liquidity AMM on Solana, facilitating broader, deeper, and more sustainable liquidity provision.<hr />- It aims to enhance LP profitability through dynamic fees, innovative token bootstrap methods, and flexible liquidity strategies.<hr />- Liquidity in DLMM is allocated to discrete bins, each representing a fixed price point with specific token contributions.<hr />- Bins are separated by bin steps, calculated via basis points, creating a sequence of price levels (e.g., $20, $20.05, $20.10).<hr />- Each bin follows the constant sum price model `X + Y = L`, with rate `P = ΔY/ΔX`, defining liquidity distribution and price.<hr />- Market operation transitions sequentially between bins as reserves deplete, with only one active bin at a time.<hr />- The active bin contains both tokens; bins left contain only Y tokens, right only X tokens.<hr />- DLMMs provide advantages over traditional AMMs:<hr />  - Reduced slippage due to liquidity concentration.<hr />  - Better capital efficiency by targeted liquidity deployment.<hr />  - Deeper liquidity for low-volume assets.<hr />  - Enhanced profitability via dynamic fee structures aligned with volatility.<hr />- Compared to CLMMs, DLMMs enable zero-slippage swaps within active bins, requiring less liquidity and supporting higher volume.<hr />- Main benefits include zero slippage, higher capital utilization, and flexible liquidity shaping for improved strategies.<hr />- DLMM is actively used in Jupiter’s Launchpad, supporting projects like Jupiter, Zeus Network, and Uprock.<hr />- Users can create or add to DLMM pools via Meteora to earn fees.<hr />- References: Meteora docs.

233.title: Labs Weekly Catchup #5
233.description: Our fifth weekly catchup to kick off the new year! We organize an agenda the day beforehand and consolidate our findings, notable research progress, possibly new tech, insight or technique everyone should know.
233.spr_content: - The weekly catchup is a recurring event, aimed at sharing research progress, technical insights, and identifying improvements.   <hr />- Agenda items include automation of reCAPTCHA bypass, passkey implementation, and GitHub trending analysis.  <hr />- reCAPTCHA bypass success relies on object detection with YoloV8 via TensorFlow.js, WebGPU, enabling image recognition and auto-clicking.  <hr />- Passkey demo advances use Golang backend to implement a verification system distinct from JWT-based magic links.  <hr />- GitHub data scraper captures trend signals, profile metrics, and contribution patterns, utilizing TimescaleDB for high-frequency data ingestion.  <hr />- Overall, event captures experimental progress, technical demonstrations, and strategic discussion of application use-cases.  <hr />- Focus on integration of computer vision, secure authentication, and large-scale data analysis for innovative solutions.
233.tags: catchup discussion dwarves elixir event internal labs rust work

234.title: Recapping A publication
234.description: Recapping a publication is the work of summarizing its key points, analyzing why it matters, and providing insights or opinions on its content. At Dwarves, we follow a set of must-dos and set expectations for recapping a publication, to ensure we have a clear and insightful summary that can contribute to readers' understanding of the topic.
234.spr_content: - Recapping a publication involves summarizing key points, analyzing its significance, and offering insights or opinions.  <hr />- Dwarves employs a structured approach to ensure clarity, accuracy, and depth in recaps.  <hr />- Effective reading is essential; thoroughly understand the material by noting main ideas, arguments, evidence, and conclusions.  <hr />- Identify the main ideas: core arguments, findings, themes, and critical points that explain the publication’s importance.  <hr />- Craft a brief summary (2-3 sentences) highlighting the main ideas without unnecessary detail.  <hr />- Explain why the publication matters: its background, purpose, relevance, and contribution to existing knowledge or the field.  <hr />- Provide insights and opinions: evaluate strengths, weaknesses, impact on industry or research, and raise questions or concerns.  <hr />- Conclude with a summary of main points and final thoughts, ensuring a cohesive wrap-up.  <hr />- Adhere to expectations: accuracy, clarity, organization, critical thinking, and ethical attribution to authors.  <hr />- Use simple language; keep the recap concise and structured with clear sections and transitions.

235.title: Rust Trait
235.description: Rust's **trait** system is a powerful feature that enables developers to define shared behavior across different types. Traits play a crucial role in achieving code reusability, abstraction, and flexibility...
235.spr_content: - Rust's trait system enables shared behavior across types.  <hr />- Traits define capabilities without internal structure details.  <hr />- Traits resemble interfaces but have distinct characteristics.  <hr />- A trait contains method signatures that types can implement.  <hr />- Implementing a trait involves defining its methods via `impl`.  <hr />- Default trait methods allow optional overriding by types.  <hr />- Traits promote abstraction, reusability, and flexibility.  <hr />- Traits can be used as function parameters for polymorphism.  <hr />- Trait bounds restrict generic functions to types implementing specific traits.  <hr />- Traits facilitate modular, generic, and adaptable code architecture.

236.title: Record and reward sharing at Dwarves
236.description: Discover how the Dwarves community fosters a culture of continuous learning and knowledge sharing. With a monthly reward pool of up to 2500 ICY, contributors are recognized for sharing valuable insights, especially in areas like AI/LLM, Golang, and more. Get involved and grow with us.
236.spr_content: - Dwarves community promotes continuous learning and knowledge sharing as core culture.  <hr />- Culture emphasizes community building alongside individual growth.  <hr />- Learning is prioritized, valued, and rewarded to foster environment of growth.  <hr />- Organized events and activities encourage participation in knowledge sharing.  <hr />- Community contributions are recognized with awards funded by profit sharing.  <hr />- Monthly pool of 2500 ICY (~$4000) allocated for rewarding contributions.  <hr />- 70% of ICY pool rewards active knowledge sharers, especially in AI/LLM, Golang, Software Architecture, Blockchain.  <hr />- Recognition incentivizes sharing valuable insights, particularly in key technical areas.  <hr />- Participation involves sharing links and topics on designated channels (tech, til, OGIFs, memo).  <hr />- Community members encouraged to contribute, present topics, and join open-source projects.  <hr />- Building productivity tools and open-source work celebrated and promoted within the community.  <hr />- System aligns rewards with sharing in specialized fields to reinforce expertise and contribution.  <hr />- Overall goal: strengthen learning culture, community engagement, and collective growth.

237.title: Strategy design pattern, the concept, use cases and difference with the state design pattern
237.description: Strategy design pattern, a behavioral design pattern that denote the functionality of a family of interchangeable classes to a interface, the context, with the helper objects, selects the appropriate implementation of the interface.
237.spr_content: - The problem models a restaurant's cookbook management as a need for flexible recipe access.<hr />- Originally, a single, secret cookbook is used to prevent trade secret leaks.<hr />- Multiple chefs (head cooks) require concurrent, organized access, causing conflicts.<hr />- Solution divides cookbook into categories: by dish type (appetizer, main, side) and cuisine (Asian, French, Italian).<hr />- Head cooks select cookbooks based on station (dish type) and cuisine, enabling targeted retrieval.<hr />- The Strategy pattern abstracts interchangeable algorithms or procedures under a common interface.<hr />- It groups similar function-set classes, enabling dynamic selection of behaviors at runtime.<hr />- An interface defines shared methods; each concrete class implements specific behavior (e.g., addition, subtraction).<hr />- The context (main program) chooses strategy based on input (e.g., operation type) using switch-case or conditional logic.<hr />- Use cases:<hr />  - Routing systems select path calculation strategies based on vehicle types.<hr />  - Transaction systems select charge/discount strategies based on transaction context.<hr />- Strategy encapsulates algorithms; decouples execution from implementation details.<hr />- The pattern supports dynamic, runtime algorithm swapping, enhancing flexibility.<hr />- Compared to State pattern:<hr />  - Strategy is stateless, interchangeable, unaware of others.<hr />  - State maintains internal state, transitions, aware of other states, and can change context behavior actively.<hr />- Both leverage composition; Strategy focuses on interchangeability of algorithms, State on behavior based on internal status.<hr />- The cookbook analogy represents Strategy: selecting different recipes (strategies) based on cuisine and dish type.<hr />- The classification into multiple cookbooks parallels strategy encapsulation for diverse recipe preparations.<hr />- Overall, Strategy pattern enables flexible, maintainable, and scalable approach to selecting behaviors in complex systems.

238.title: Labs Weekly Catchup #4
238.description: Our fourth weekly catchup. We organize an agenda the day beforehand and consolidate our findings, notable research progress, possibly new tech, insight or technique everyone should know.
238.spr_content: - LLMs embed knowledge, abilities, latent content, and latent space associative with prime cues.  <hr />- Properly structured prompts prime neural activations, akin to human mnemonic triggers.  <hr />- SPRs facilitate minimal, distilled instructions to activate rich internal states in models.  <hr />- Sparse priming distills complex concepts into key associations, enabling efficient activation of capabilities.  <hr />- Structuring inputs as concise assertions primes latent abilities like reasoning, planning, and perception.  <hr />- Effective SPRs leverage associative nature of LLMs to evoke specific knowledge and skills with minimal cues.  <hr />- Using SPRs enhances model responsiveness, aligns internal activations, and accelerates task-specific outputs.

239.title: Sign-in Form Best Practices
239.spr_content: - Use semantic HTML elements: `<form>`, `<input>`, `<label>`, `<button>` for accessibility and clarity.  <hr />- Associate each input with a `<label>` for screen readers.  <hr />- Leverage attributes: `type`, `name`, `autocomplete`, `required` to enhance browser features and validation.  <hr />- Assign stable `name` and `id` attributes that persist across loads and deployments for consistency.  <hr />- Enclose sign-in inputs within a dedicated `<form>` to isolate context and submission behavior.  <hr />- Ensure form submission results in navigation or state change (e.g., page redirect).  <hr />- For password inputs: use `autocomplete="current-password"` with `id="current-password"` in sign-in forms; use `autocomplete="new-password"` and `id="new-password"` in sign-up or reset forms.  <hr />- Provide password visibility toggle to improve usability.  <hr />- Improve accessibility with `aria-label` and `aria-describedby` on password fields.  <hr />- Avoid duplicate inputs; prevent requiring users to re-enter the same data.  <hr />- Design forms for mobile: prevent keyboard from covering inputs and buttons, use large touch targets and legible text.  <hr />- Preserve branding and styling consistency on sign-in and sign-up pages.  <hr />- Incorporate analytics: track interactions, conversions, and performance metrics during sign-in/sign-up flows.  <hr />- Test across browsers and devices to account for platform differences in form behavior.

240.title: Giving a talk
240.description: The checklist presents how to prepare for a talk

241.title: Founder Liquidity
241.description: Founder liquidity is a secret that founders and investors don't want you to know
241.spr_content: - Founders claim high risk to justify large equity stakes; early employees face similar risks.<hr />- Silicon Valley mythology centers on founder risk and sacrifice.<hr />- Lesser-known: founder liquidity—selling shares during funding rounds—reduces founders' personal risk.<hr />- Founder liquidity often secret, kept in closed-door discussions; known only to founders, investors, and cap table insiders.<hr />- Propaganda of founder "all-in" status is maintained to attract talent and justify disparities.<hr />- Founder liquidity de-risks founders while employees remain all-in, creating asymmetry.<hr />- Public narratives hide founder liquidity to preserve romanticized risk stories.<hr />- Example: founder cashing out huge amounts before employees could, exemplified by WeWork’s Neumann.<hr />- Employees often unaware of founders' liquidity; stories of unfairness and hidden gains.<hr />- Investors and founders assume transparency would harm morale; but evidence suggests it wouldn't.<hr />- Once founders access liquidity, perceived risk advantage over employees diminishes.<hr />- Personal exposure: employer's liquidity access obvious to insiders; employee ignorance is systemic.<hr />- Transparency about founder liquidity could realign perceptions; foster trust.<hr />- My experience: early success built from joining startups and shared risk, contrast with founder liquidity privilege.<hr />- Responsible founders should balance risk: broader equity pools, shorter cliffs, longer exercise periods.<hr />- Industry standard: 20% option pool, 4-year vest, 90-day post-termination exercise.<hr />- Proposed: increase transparency with each funding round about founder liquidity.<hr />- Transparency empowers employees to assess true risk; questions should be normalized.<hr />- Knowing founder liquidity status could lead to more equitable compensation, acknowledgment of risk, or frustration.<hr />- Core issue: asymmetrical risk perception fueled by hidden liquidity; undermines trust and fairness.<hr />- Final insight: the myth of founder sacrifice is partly sustained by secrecy; opening access benefits all.

242.title: Knowledge Journey
242.description: Our process for evaluating and integrating technology is designed to be thorough yet efficient, ensuring we adopt only the most effective tools into our operations. It consists of four key stages: Assess, Trial, Adopt, and Hold.
242.spr_content: - LLM-based evaluation process prioritizes thoroughness and efficiency.  <hr />- Four stages: Assess, Trial, Adopt, Hold.  <hr />- Assess: initial evaluation, understanding potential and limitations, resource conservation.  <hr />- Trial: practical testing in projects, gaining hands-on experience, assessing impact.  <hr />- Adopt: proven technology, formal integration, based on successful trials.  <hr />- Hold: caution or cessation, mitigating risks from outdated or misaligned tech.  <hr />- Transition to Playbook occurs after "Adopt" and successful multi-project application.  <hr />- Inclusion criteria for Playbook: at least two project implementations, unanimous key team approval.  <hr />- Final intent: ensure only effective, reliable, and beneficial technologies become core standards.

243.title: Database design Circular
243.description: A comprehensive guide to understanding circular references in database design, including types, challenges, real-world applications, and solutions for managing them effectively. Covers self-references, circular dependencies, and strategies for maintaining data integrity while working with circular relationships.
243.spr_content: - Circular references occur when tables reference each other in a cycle, e.g., students ↔ professors with mutual advisory relationships.  <hr />- Such references hinder data insertion due to non-null constraints on foreign keys; cannot insert one without the other.  <hr />- Complex systems, like task management with entities: users, tasks, projects, project_assignments, project_teams, can form multi-entity circular dependencies.  <hr />- Circular reference identification involves detecting tables serving as primary sources for multiple foreign keys, creating potential loops.  <hr />- Some models that appear circular are not true circular references, e.g., purchasing systems with products, purchases, commissions, customers, retailers—where no data insertion cycle exists.  <hr />- Types of circular references:  <hr />  - Self-reference: parent-child hierarchies, root indicated by null parent.  <hr />  - Circle: an endless loop starting and ending at the same entity.  <hr />  - Multi-table: multiple chains linking tables via PK-FK relations forming cycles.  <hr />- Challenges include:  <hr />  - Data integrity risks during updates or deletions.  <hr />  - Complex, inefficient queries traversing many tables.  <hr />  - Infinite loops in recursive queries or cascades.  <hr />  - Maintenance difficulty as systems grow.  <hr />- Real-world scenarios requiring circular references include:  <hr />  - Bidirectional relationships, e.g., employee and manager referencing each other.  <hr />  - Hierarchies with parent-child and child-parent links for navigation.  <hr />  - Cross-referenced entities like customer and supplier referencing contracts.  <hr />  - Graph structures such as social networks with mutual friendships.  <hr />- Solutions aim to minimize and manage circular references:  <hr />  - Keep their number as low as possible.  <hr />  - Detect and prevent them during implementation.  <hr />  - Ensure only one route exists between entities for data flow.  <hr />  - Use deferred constraints (e.g., PostgreSQL) to validate at transaction end.  <hr />  - Employ soft or application-managed references instead of strict foreign keys.  <hr />  - Introduce intermediate or junction tables to break direct cycles.  <hr />  - Apply application logic to manage relationships and maintain integrity.  <hr />  - Normalize schemas; consider denormalization selectively to simplify relationships.  <hr />- Overall, circular references are sometimes necessary but are risky; best practices recommend limiting their use and employing strategies to mitigate their impact.

245.title: Design file-sharing system - Part 1: Directory Structure
245.description: This system aims to provide users with the ability to store, access, and share files directly on our website, similar to Google Drive. This system aims to enhance user convenience and collaboration by allowing seamless file management and sharing capabilities.
245.spr_content: System goal: Enable file storage, access, sharing, similar to Google Drive.  <hr />Enhance user convenience and collaboration via seamless file management.  <hr />Visual aid: design-file-sharing-system.webp.  <hr /><hr />Overview:  <hr />- Upload and edit diverse files within personal storage.  <hr />- Share files selectively with individuals or groups; controlled access.  <hr />- Make specific files public for guest view without login.  <hr />- Apply password protection for secure access.  <hr /><hr />Design principles: user-friendly, secure, user manages control, maintains content privacy.  <hr /><hr />Data model:  <hr />- Workspace: groups working towards shared goals, contains essential context info.  <hr />- Asset: core digital content record; includes metadata, ownership, categorization.  <hr />- Permissions: manage access levels, roles, and scope, enabling flexible control.  <hr /><hr />Hierarchy handling challenge: replicate folder structure, enable efficient file retrieval and movement, preserve data integrity, update references and permissions.  <hr />Solution: `path` field in Asset model; string of concatenated IDs (e.g., `/workspaceID/parentDirID/.../assetID`).  <hr />- First ID: workspace identifier.  <hr />- Following IDs: directory hierarchy levels.  <hr /><hr />Performance benefits:  <hr />- Direct access via path string; no recursive traversal needed.  <hr />- Easy updates by modifying path string; O(1) complexity.  <hr />- Simplifies hierarchy operations, reduces computational overhead.  <hr /><hr />Conclusion:  <hr />- System requirements analyzed; data structure optimized for efficiency.  <hr />- Future focus: permissions, sharing, password security elaboration.  <hr />- Goal: comprehensive, secure, accessible file management system.  <hr /><hr />Next step: explore permissions, sharing controls, password protections for enhanced security and accessibility.

246.title: Invoking component functions in React
246.description: What happens if you invoked the component function directly in React?
246.spr_content: - Invoking a React component as a regular function executes it immediately, reusing or recreating its hooks each time.  <hr />- React components (functions) are not ordinary functions; they are special constructs managed by React's rendering engine, preserving hook state via the Virtual DOM and internal fiber data.  <hr />- Calling a component directly, like `ExampleComponent()`, bypasses React's component lifecycle and hook rules, causing "render more hooks than during the previous render" errors.  <hr />- React's hooks rely on consistent order and number during each render; direct invocation mishandles this, breaking invariants.  <hr />- On initial render, `show` is false; `ExampleComponent()` isn't called, so hooks are not initialized.  <hr />- When triggered (`show` becomes true), `ExampleComponent()` is called directly, attempting to initialize hooks anew, violating hook rules.  <hr />- Using `<ExampleComponent />` ensures React manages the component's lifecycle, preserving hook consistency, and updating props/state accurately.  <hr />- `<ExampleComponent />` translates to `React.createElement(ExampleComponent)`, integrating into React's rendering and diffing process, maintaining the hook order.

247.title: How to deal with technical debt in Scrum
247.description: How to deal with Technical debt in Scrum
247.spr_content: - Technical debt arises from outdated tech, poor testing, lack of documentation, and other suboptimal practices within Scrum projects.<hr />- Identifying sources of technical debt involves inspecting code, architecture, testing, and documentation.<hr />- Prioritization focuses on items that impede value delivery, aligning with Scrum's value increment.<hr />- Planning includes refactoring, updating tech stacks, bolstering testing, and documentation improvements.<hr />- Integrating technical debt work into sprints ensures continuous effort; dedicating sprint capacity or explicitly including debt tasks.<hr />- Monitoring progress involves tracking debt reduction, code quality metrics, and impact on velocity.<hr />- Stakeholder communication aligns expectations, clarifies debt implications, and fosters support.<hr />- Managing technical debt in Scrum is an ongoing cycle of identification, prioritization, action, measurement, and communication.

249.title: Introduce the Observer pattern and its use cases
249.description: Concept of the Observer Pattern with its pros and cons.
249.spr_content: Observer pattern: decouples state changes from notifications.  <hr />Subject maintains list of observers, notifies on change.  <hr />Analogy: mailbox subscription—publisher knows subscribers, delivers updates.  <hr />Real-world: DOM events, event listeners—element (subject), handlers (observers).  <hr />Custom emitters: modular notifications—emitters (subjects), listeners (observers).  <hr />Redux: store (subject), components (observers)—state management via subscription.  <hr />Advantages: loose coupling, automatic updates, reusability, structured event handling, simplified communication.  <hr />Disadvantages: memory leaks if unregistered, unexpected updates, performance costs, added complexity, debugging difficulty.

251.title: Automata
251.description: Things about automata that devs should know
251.spr_content: Finite State Automata (FSA) are algebraic models `F = ⟨Σ, S, s0, F, δ⟩` for systems with discrete states and transitions.  <hr />- `Σ` (alphabet): input symbols.  <hr />- `S` (states): finite set of states.  <hr />- `s0` (start state): initial state.  <hr />- `F` (accepting states): subset of states indicating success.  <hr />- `δ` (transition function): maps state-input pairs to next states (`δ:S×Σ→S`).  <hr /><hr />FSA express systems with concrete, deterministic paths, not probabilistic or quantum states.  <hr />- Example: regex pattern `AB+C` accepts strings with `'A'`, followed by one or more `'B'`, and ending with `'C'`.  <hr />- Visualized as a directed graph: `A --> B* --> C`, where loops on `B`.  <hr /><hr />FSAs are primarily thinking tools—formal descriptions for systems' states and transitions, not direct programming techniques.  <hr />- Useful in designing workflows, ensuring correct order: "A before C" constraints.  <hr />- Simplify analysis, testing, and debugging of sequential systems.  <hr /><hr />Finite State Machine (FSM) and Finite Automata (FA) are synonymous, both describing abstract models of computation for regular languages.  <hr />- The term "finite" implies limited memory: finite states `Q`.  <hr />- "Automata" emphasizes the automatic, rule-driven nature: no need for explicit intervention once transition rules are defined.  <hr />- Transition rules are represented via diagrams, tables, or functions (`δ(q,a)→q'`).  <hr /><hr />The transition function `δ:Q×Σ → Q` (or `δ:Q×Σ→Q`) formalizes the state changes:  <hr />- Domain: pairs of current state and input symbol (`Q×Σ`).  <hr />- Range: next state (`Q`).  <hr />- Reads as: "From state `q` on input `a`, transition to `q'`."  <hr /><hr />Comparison:  <hr />- **State machine vs. workflow**: State machines are event-driven, respond to external events; workflows progress sequentially after task completion.  <hr />- **DFA (Deterministic)**: Single definite path—one instruction per input, no ambiguity.  <hr />- **NFA (Non-deterministic)**: Multiple possible paths—can explore many alternatives simultaneously.  <hr /><hr />DFA example:  <hr />- Robot on one tile, always performs one action based on exact input—fast, predictable, strict.  <hr />NFA example:  <hr />- Robot considers all possible actions it might take upon seeing a tile—more flexible, explores multiple options concurrently, but potentially slower.  <hr /><hr />Key distinctions:  <hr />- DFA: single, sure path; high efficiency; limited flexibility.  <hr />- NFA: multiple paths; more adaptable; may require more processing time.

252.title: Design file-sharing system - Part 2: Permission & Password
252.description: In this part, I will discuss how I handle the logic and design the data model for the following features: setting permissions, sharing files for public access, and setting a password for a file.
252.spr_content: - Permission handling relies on a hierarchical model: direct user permissions override inherited permissions, which override default or parent's permissions.<hr /><hr />- Files inherit permissions from parent folders unless explicitly overridden, indicated by `isInherit` flag.<hr /><hr />- MainPermission table holds general permissions per asset, with roles `PUBLIC_ROLE` (guest access roles: EDITOR, VIEWER, NO_ACCESS) and `ChildRole` (workspace members: FULL_ACCESS, EDITOR, VIEWER, NO_ACCESS, INHERIT).<hr /><hr />- SubPermission table stores specific email-based roles, allowing overrides for individual invitees or project members, with same role options and an `INHERIT` indicator.<hr /><hr />- Permission evaluation follows order: direct user (SubPermission) → `ChildRole` in MainPermission → inheritance from parent.<hr /><hr />- On asset creation, default MainPermission has `isInherit` true and `childRole` `INHERIT`, inheriting from parent.<hr /><hr />- Permission updates switch `isInherit` to false, assigning explicit roles.<hr /><hr />- Sharing allows setting `publicRole` in MainPermission to `VIEWER`, `EDITOR`, or `NO_ASSET`. Public access checks `publicRole` for guest users, enabling view or edit capabilities, with non-logged-in users restricted to view only.<hr /><hr />- Password protection utilizes `passwordHash` in MainPermission: presence indicates password enabled, password stored securely hashed.<hr /><hr />- Access workflow involves client obtaining an asset token via login endpoint, then including token in headers to retrieve detailed asset info, facilitating secured access and permission checks.<hr /><hr />- System architecture emphasizes flexibility, inheritance, security via password hashing, and fine-grained permission control, enabling robust file sharing, access management, and collaboration.

253.title: Migration Planning
253.description: Migration planning is a crucial part of any software development project, especially when migrating to a new database or platform.
253.spr_content: Migration plan considerations: minimize downtime, ensure data consistency, prepare rollback strategy, establish observability and metrics, and ensure team awareness.  <hr />Common migration steps:  <hr />- Dual reads/writes with old database as primary for safety.  <hr />- Backfill data into new database.  <hr />- Compare and validate new database against old.  <hr />- Switch to dual reads/writes with new database as primary.  <hr />- Remove old database once stable.

254.description: Our third weekly catchup. We organize an agenda the day beforehand and consolidate our findings, notable research progress, possibly new tech, insight or technique everyone should know.
254.spr_content: - LLMs embed latent knowledge and abilities; activation via primed language cues.  <hr />- LLMs associative; priming words can unlock complex reasoning, planning, theory of mind.  <hr />- Prime models with succinct, complete statements; balance abstraction and detail.  <hr />- Use SPR to distill research insights, technical progress, strategic planning.  <hr />- Focus on novel tech: chatbot alternatives like LibreChat, Ollama Web UI; cost-effective testing, customization.  <hr />- Leverage web-based query processing with DuckDB WASM; enable real-time data analytics in-browser.  <hr />- Demonstrate object detection bypassing reCaptcha with self-hosted AI (YoloV8, TensorFlow.js, WebGPU).  <hr />- Promote front-end to desktop deployment using Tauri; cross-platform apps, open source demos.  <hr />- Integrate type-safe API routing (Spacedrive, RSPC); ensure robustness, scalability in full-stack stacks.  <hr />- Next steps: develop passwordless auth repo; utilize GenState and Elixir tools for scalable, alert systems.

255.title: Error handling patterns
255.description: Quick note on error handling patterns in programming languages
255.spr_content: - Error handling is vital for robust software; it maintains correctness amidst unexpected inputs or conditions.<hr />- Return codes embed success/failure status; simple, efficient, but prone to overlooked checks, causing silent bugs.<hr />- Exceptions (try-catch) provide structured error separation; handle deep errors cleanly but may introduce runtime overhead and obscure logic.<hr />- Error objects or results enforce explicit success/error handling; common in functional languages, reduce oversight, enable chaining but can be verbose.<hr />- Assertions verify assumptions during debugging; catch bugs early, but are disabled in production and unsuitable for recoverable errors.<hr />- Callbacks (error-first) support asynchronous error handling; explicit but lead to callback hell if misused.<hr />- Promise-based handling streamlines asynchronous code; clearer than callbacks, but complex chains can hamper debugging.<hr />- Pattern matching facilitates comprehensive case handling; explicit, readable, but overcomplicated for simple errors.<hr />- Panic (crash) triggers in non-recoverable errors; useful for critical issues, but should be used sparingly to avoid unsalvageable crashes.<hr />- Each pattern balances simplicity, robustness, overhead, and suitability to context; combining approaches often yields best results.

257.title: Case study: Write-heavy scalable and reliable inventory platform
257.description: How Doordash designed a successful write-heavy scalable and reliable inventory platform
257.spr_content: - Successful inventory platform requires high scalability, reliability, low latency, and observability.<hr />- Natural primary keys derived from business parameters outperform auto-incrementing IDs by reducing columns and optimizing queries centered on business logic.<hr />- Database optimization involves adding missing indexes to support queries and removing redundant ones to avoid overhead.<hr />- Reducing column count enhances efficiency; frequently updated columns are consolidated into JSONB columns, balancing pros and cons based on use case.<hr />- Implement TTL for tables with rapid data growth that do not require long-term retention, improving storage management.<hr />- Query batching and rewriting within single SQL requests decreases QPS, reducing load on downstream services and databases.<hr />- Overall, structural priming via data and query design principles maximizes performance, scalability, and reliability in a write-heavy environment.
257.tags: doordash inventory-platform low-latency observability reliability scalability write-heavy

258.title: Evaluating search engine in RAG systems
258.description: Hybrid search comes to solving problems in vector search and full-text search. Let's see how it works. In this article, we will know how hybrid search approach and how to evaluate each search method through metrics in information retrieval.
258.spr_content: - Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) challenges traditional search and info retrieval paradigms by integrating diverse methods.  <hr />- Hybrid search combines vector and full-text search to address their individual limitations: vector search lacks precision; full-text search lacks meaning.  <hr />- Vector search relies on embedding queries and data into vector space, then calculates similarity (cosine or Euclidean), returning top-k closest matches.  <hr />- In large datasets, vector search may miss specific keywords, providing broader but less detailed results.  <hr />- Full-text search uses inverted index, TF-IDF, Boolean operators, and exact match queries for precise text retrieval.  <hr />- It may yield irrelevant results due to common keywords with different meanings across documents.  <hr />- Hybrid search employs both strategies, leveraging their strengths for quality results in complex queries.  <hr />- Use hybrid search when content relevance and keyword precision are both required, e.g., scientific articles with exact terms and contextual understanding.  <hr />- Limitations of hybrid search include latency, context-length constraints, and database support issues.  <hr />- Combining results involves re-ranking with models or Reciprocal Rank Fusion (RRF), balancing semantic relevance and exact matches.  <hr />- Re-Rank models score and reorder based on closeness to the query; RRF fuses rankings from different methods to prioritize relevant documents.  <hr />- RRF score calculation blends vector and full-text ranks weighted by alpha, ensuring documents relevant to both are prioritized.  <hr />- Systematic organization: store retrieval settings (searchMethod, topK, similarityThreshold, alpha) per dataset in a database (e.g., Postgres).  <hr />- Retrieval configuration includes an enum for search methods, and parameters for result quantity and similarity thresholds.  <hr />- A unified retrieval function passses parameters to vector, full-text, or hybrid searches; combines and sorts results by relevance scores.  <hr />- Hybrid implementation involves combining vector and full-text results, applying RRF scoring, and selecting top-k results for UI presentation.  <hr />- Performance evaluation uses metrics: recall (relevant found / total relevant), precision (relevant / retrieved), F1 (balance), and NDCG (ranking quality).  <hr />- Recall indicates coverage; precision indicates accuracy; F1 balances these metrics for overall effectiveness.  <hr />- NDCG accounts for result position and relevance importance, useful for ranking scenarios.  <hr />- Evaluation guides selection of search method based on dataset characteristics and desired outcomes.  <hr />- Optimal search strategy depends on balancing precision, recall, latency, and contextual understanding, guided by these metrics.

259.title: Labs Weekly Catchup #2
259.description: Our second weekly catchup. We organize an agenda the day beforehand and consolidate our findings, notable research progress, possibly new tech, insight or technique everyone should know.
259.spr_content: - LLMs possess latent knowledge, abilities, and concepts embedded in deep neural network representations.  <hr />- Activation of latent space is achievable through priming with specific words or prompts.  <hr />- Priming functions like associative cues, similar to human mnemonic triggers.  <hr />- Sparse priming enhances neural activation, enabling complex reasoning and content retrieval.  <hr />- Discrete, targeted prompts can steer internal states towards specific outcomes.  <hr />- Summarizing diverse technical updates consolidates concept associations:  <hr />  - Self-hosted browser-based AI models relate to internet bandwidth constraints and WebGPU support, emphasizing resource management and performance optimization.  <hr />  - Elixir clustering via Process Groups and Raft consensus illustrate scalable distributed system principles—group orchestration, message broadcasting, leader election.  <hr />  - Rust vs Go comparison highlights concurrency paradigms—Rust's emphasis on safety, references, borrowing; Go's simplicity and goroutines—implying trade-offs in complexity, learning curve, and performance.  <hr />  - Rust game UI demo exemplifies interactive system design, practical challenges, and language-specific UI approaches.  <hr />  - AI architecture updates (Mixtral, Mixture of Experts) demonstrate modular, scalable, multi-agent model structures, relevant for multi-modal and specialized tasks.  <hr />- Strategy for advanced LLM priming involves integrating abstractions of these concepts as associative hooks, enabling dynamic internal state modulation aligned with technical contexts.
259.tags: LLM catchup discussion dwarves elixir event internal labs rust work

260.title: React Fiber
260.description: Fiber is the new reconciliation algorithm since React 16, a completely backward-compatible rewrite of the old reconciler (Stack Reconciler).
260.spr_content: React Fiber: New reconciliation algorithm since React 16; fully backward-compatible rewrite of Stack Reconciler.  <hr />Purpose: Enhance performance by breaking call stack limits; enables dividing work into chunks and spreading over multiple frames.  <hr />Allows pausing, resuming, or aborting work conditionally based on priority.  <hr />Provides control over work priority; user-initiated functions prioritized over background tasks.  <hr />Improves UI handling for animations, layouts, gestures through priority management.  <hr />Enables fluid user experience by chunking work into interruptible units.  <hr />Old Stack Reconciler performed synchronous, monolithic reconciliation; caused lag and choppiness.  <hr />Fiber architecture separates rendering from reconciliation, permitting interruption and prioritization.  <hr />References detail the algorithm, performance benefits, and implementation insights.

261.title: Visitor design pattern, the concept, problem solution and use cases
261.description: Visitor is a behavioral design pattern that lets you separate algorithms from the objects on which they operate.
261.spr_content: - The Visitor pattern separates algorithms from object structures, enabling addition of behaviors without modifying element classes.<hr />- It is a behavioral design pattern primarily used for performing operations on groups of similar objects.<hr />- Key components include the `Visit()` method implemented by visitors and `Accept()` methods in visitable classes.<hr />- The pattern addresses issues when adding new operations to complex object structures, such as document elements or ASTs, by encapsulating behaviors into visitor classes.<hr />- Structure involves:<hr />  - Element classes (`Paragraph`, `Table`, `Image`) with `accept()` methods that invoke visitor methods.<hr />  - Visitor interface (`DocumentVisitor`) declaring `visit` methods for each element type.<hr />  - Concrete visitors (`RenderVisitor`, `ExportVisitor`, `SpellCheckVisitor`) implementing specific behaviors for each element.<hr />- Benefits include adherence to the Open/Closed Principle, single responsibility for behaviors, and easy extension of functionalities.<hr />- Drawbacks include the necessity to update all visitors when element classes change and limited access to private class members.<hr />- Applicability spans:<hr />  - Traversing object trees (e.g., document structures, ASTs).<hr />  - Isolating auxiliary behaviors from core classes.<hr />  - Handling behaviors relevant only to specific elements in hierarchies.<hr />- Use cases:<hr />  - Compiler design: type checking, code generation on ASTs.<hr />  - Document processing: rendering, exporting, spell-checking.<hr />  - Graphics: drawing, resizing, calculating areas for shapes.<hr />  - File systems: searching, compression, encryption.<hr />  - Game development: rendering, updating, collision detection.<hr />  - E-commerce: apply discounts, calculate shipping, invoicing.<hr />  - Network protocols: serialization, logging.<hr />  - UI components: rendering, event handling, validation.<hr />- The pattern supports adding new operations quickly and maintains class hierarchy stability but requires care with visitor updates when structures evolve.<hr />

262.title: Go JSON parser: number <-> interface
262.description: TLDR; be careful when using  map[string]interface{} to hold json number value, use custom decoder with newDecoder.UseNumber() to decode the json string.
262.spr_content: - Go's json.Marshal on struct with large int outputs accurate number in JSON string.  <hr />- Using json.Unmarshal into map[string]interface{} defaults numeric values to float64.  <hr />- float64 precision limits cause large integers to lose exact value, leading to rounding errors.  <hr />- Default decoder interprets numbers as float64, not preserving integer precision.  <hr />- To maintain number integrity, use json.Decoder with UseNumber() prior to decode.  <hr />- Apply decoder := json.NewDecoder(reader); decoder.UseNumber(); decoder.Decode(&map).  <hr />- After decoding with UseNumber(), numbers are stored as json.Number type, preserving exact value.  <hr />- Re-marshal json.Number to JSON string yields original large integers accurately.  <hr />- Summary: for precise integer parsing, rely on json.Decoder with UseNumber(), not default unmarshal.

263.title: Error Messaging
263.description: What makes a bad error message
263.spr_content: - **Bad error message principles:**  <hr />  - Inappropriate tone: dismissive, sarcastic, or rude.  <hr />  - Technical jargon: confusing and alienating users without technical knowledge.  <hr />  - Passing the blame: implying user fault instead of explaining the issue.  <hr />  - Generic for no reason: vague messages like “Error occurred,” offering no guidance or context.  <hr /><hr />- **Good error message principles:**  <hr />  - Say what happened and why: clear explanation of the issue context.  <hr />  - Provide reassurance: affirm user assistance and reduce frustration.  <hr />  - Be empathetic: acknowledge inconvenience and show understanding.  <hr />  - Help them fix it: suggest concrete steps to resolve the problem.  <hr />  - Always give a way out: offer options, retry, contact support, or exit.  <hr /><hr />- **Reference:**  <hr />  - Useful UX practices in error messaging from Wix UX article.  <hr />  - Visual cues highlight the importance of clarity and empathy in UX design.

264.title: Tech Canvas
264.description: This is where we share our journey in the ever-evolving landscape of technology. It’s a space where we unveil our latest breakthroughs, discuss our research, and delve into our innovative projects. Just as an artist expresses their vision on a canvas, we use this platform to paint a picture of our technological advancements and how they’re shaping the future.
264.spr_content: - Technology landscape is a dynamic, evolving journey akin to an artistic canvas of innovation.<hr />- Sharing breakthroughs, research, and projects aims to shape future tech visions.<hr />- Expanding field work involves complex, nuanced problems with big data and intricate business logic requiring comprehensive solutions.<hr />- Focus areas include structuring and scaling notifications: timing, batching, frequency.<hr />- Strategies for full-text and vector indexing enhance semantic understanding of user intent.<hr />- Subscription and onboarding logic face rapid complexity due to feature toggles and plan variations.<hr />- Lab research prioritizes AI and LLM; exploring coherent, rich output generation.<hr />- Building RAG pipelines aggregates diverse data sources to enrich AI responses.<hr />- Developing LLMs with near-infinite memory to sustain complex, context-rich conversations.<hr />- Optimizing data transformation for the speed and efficiency of vector database retrieval.<hr />- Analyzing vector indexing pitfalls to benchmark and select effective similarity search techniques.<hr />- Enhancing RAG pipelines with content ranking prior to embedding, improving relevance.<hr />- Deepening understanding of function calling and AI agent architecture, emphasizing structured data.<hr />- Internal projects like LLM Builder facilitate integrated, knowledge-based chatbots.<hr />- News Aggregator consolidates tech news to track industry trends.<hr />- Market reports from Feb, Mar, Jan, Dec 2023/2024 reveal AI, FinOps, Cybersecurity, SaaS growth, and evolving tech trends.<hr />- Regular labs weekly summaries track research, tech insights, and strategic shifts.<hr />- Community problem spaces include internal notes management, Icy token utilities, Fortress command reworks, staking mechanics.<hr />- Bounties support collaborative innovation, solving tooling, data, and infrastructure challenges.<hr />- Overall motif: a collaborative, iterative pursuit of AI, data, and scalable tech advancements, painted as a future-shaping masterpiece.

265.title: Breaking Down Complexity: The Role of Abstractions and UML in C4 Modelling
265.description: Understanding and conveying software architecture can be a daunting task, especially when dealing with non-technical stakeholders or diverse development teams. This article delves into the challenges of traditional methods like complex UML diagrams and non-descriptive box-and-line drawings. We introduce the C4 model, a powerful framework that simplifies these challenges by using layered abstractions and visualizations. Explore how the model breaks down software architecture into comprehensible levels—Context, Container, Component, and Code—and offers guidelines on creating effective diagrams. Real-world examples illustrate the application of the C4 model, making it an invaluable tool for creating a shared understanding and ensuring clear, meaningful communication among all parties involved.
265.spr_content: - Software architecture communication is hindered by UML complexity, vague diagrams, lack of domain context, technical jargon, and communication difficulties.<hr />- The C4 model offers a hierarchical abstraction framework to describe software systems clearly and visually.<hr />- Abstractions facilitate understanding across technical and non-technical audiences, bridging knowledge gaps.<hr />- Developing effective abstractions involves consensus and iterative effort among stakeholders, with designated sources of truth.<hr />- The C4 model organizes abstractions into four levels: Context, Container, Component, and Code.<hr />- System-level context defines the overall system within its environment, users, dependencies, and pain points.<hr />- Containers are essential runtime units (applications or data stores) within the system, responsible for specific operational roles.<hr />- Components are functional units within containers, composed of classes and methods, completing specific flows.<hr />- Code details the implementation, including conditions, outputs, exceptions, and fallback behaviors.<hr />- Visualization should use clear, uniform, domain-specific diagram elements with legends, emphasizing solution clarity.<hr />- The level of diagram detail and abstraction should align with the intended value and understanding for the audience.<hr />- The C4 diagram and abstractions act as a central, authoritative reference, guiding design and discussion efforts.

266.title: How we crafted the OGIF summarizer bot to streamline weekly knowledge-sharing
266.description: Introducing the OGIF Memo Summarizer, a chatbot we developed using Dify in collaboration with @innno_. This tool transcribes YouTube videos and extracts key points from our Oh God It’s Friday (OGIF) sessions. By providing both short and detailed summaries in English and Vietnamese, it significantly enhances our ability to review and reference the diverse knowledge shared every Friday.
266.spr_content: - OGIF ("Oh God It’s Friday") is a weekly team tradition for sharing 10-minute talks on diverse topics via Discord.  <hr />- Topics include software development, engineering patterns, industry trends, finance, entrepreneurship, blockchain, AI, and others.  <hr />- Purpose: facilitate quick, engaging learning, and promote open sharing among Dwarves team members, including non-developers.  <hr />- Collaborated with @innno_ to create a YouTube transcript-based OGIF memo summarizer using Dify.  <hr />- The summarizer transcribes YouTube videos, extracts key points, and enhances review and reference of OGIF sessions.  <hr />- It employs a workflow combining YouTube transcription, structured summarization, and a well-designed prompt.  <hr />- Generates three summary levels:  <hr />  1. Short summary: 3-5 timestamps with brief topic descriptions.  <hr />  2. Detailed summary: timestamps with 2-3 bullet points each for in-depth content.  <hr />  3. Multilingual output: summaries in English and Vietnamese.  <hr />- The core prompt ensures structured, timestamped, clickable summaries with consistent formatting for readability.  <hr />- Benefits include time savings, easy navigation, better knowledge retention, and enhanced accessibility for absent participants.  <hr />- Future improvements: automatic tagging, search across summaries, visual timelines of topics over sessions.  <hr />- Overall, the OGIF Memo Summarizer advances weekly knowledge sharing, leveraging AI to save time and increase session value.  <hr />- Other teams are encouraged to adopt similar tools for efficient learning and info sharing in engineering environments.

267.title: Local-first Software
267.description: Local-first software is an approach to software development that emphasizes data ownership, offline functionality, and real-time collaboration. This model ensures data is primarily stored on the user's device, enhancing privacy and control while enabling seamless synchronization and collaboration without relying on continuous internet connectivity
267.spr_content: - Local-first software prioritizes data storage on user devices, ensuring ownership, privacy, and offline capabilities.  <hr />- It synchronizes data with other devices and cloud when possible, mimicking cloud collaboration benefits without centralized control.  <hr />- Contrasts with traditional thin-client apps dependent on servers for data read/write; shifts roles, making clients primary data sources, servers backups.  <hr />- Core concepts enabling local-first: CRDTs for conflict-free multi-user edits; data synchronization for offline changes with encrypted security.  <hr />- Benefits include enhanced data control and privacy, offline accessibility, improved performance, and reliable operation without internet.  <hr />- Facilitates real-time collaboration and conflict resolution, reducing reliance on centralized services.  <hr />- Differs from traditional file systems and email, lacking seamless multi-device sync; from cloud solutions, which centralize control; and hybrid models, which still depend on servers.  <hr />- Examples: Figma (design, real-time, local-first principles), Obsidian (local knowledge base, sync), Notion (local-first elements), Linear (project management, offline access).  <hr />- Challenges: Complexity of CRDT implementation, security during sync, UI complexity, and synchronization performance overhead.

268.title: $icy in 2024

268.spr_content: - Since 2020, $icy integrated into our workflow, representing long-term community engagement.  <hr />- 2020: Initiative launched as our first community experiment, establishing foundational trust.  <hr />- 2021: Deployment of icy.so to enable $icy redemption, expanding utility.  <hr />- 2022: Adoption of $icy as primary reward token, notably during summit-2022 and doty, distributing ~$20,000, indicating substantial reward infrastructure.  <hr />- 2023: Introduction of vault as an internal reward mechanism for our functional team, diversifying reward channels.  <hr />- Future plans include:  <hr />  - Salary advance, a short-term credit feature for full-time team members, promoting financial flexibility.  <hr />  - Discord utility commands to streamline $icy interactions and enhance engagement.  <hr />  - Direct withdrawal of $icy to bank accounts, bridging on-chain and off-chain assets.  <hr />  - Launch of $icy store for merchandise or services, increasing tangible utility.  <hr />  - Staking $icy, encouraging token holding and ecosystem stability.  <hr />- All development plans are approved; focus shifts to coding and implementation.  <hr />- Engagement invitation: keen to onboard contributors via @hnh on Discord for collaborative development and bounty rewards.

269.title: 💠 df protocol, $icy and $dfg
269.description: Here's our draft internal map/v0 for 🧊 $icy play, based on our current activities at this borderless software firm...
269.spr_content: - 2018 vision: unconventional setup, introducing $dfg, empowering team ownership and next-gen software development.<hr />- $dfg designed to distribute responsibility, reward implementation, foster ownership among team "grind chads."<hr />- 2020: launch of 🧊 $icy as a loyalty and appreciation token, promoting recognition culture.<hr />- 2023: building a protocol with its own economy, integrating proposals, voting, automation.<hr />- Goal: ensure Dwarves brand’s vitality and benefit for all participants.<hr />- Paradigm shift: from ownership and recognition to decentralized governance and automated workflows.<hr />- $dfg as a foundational asset, enabling participation and value accrual.<hr />- $icy as a social layer, incentivizing engagement and community cohesion.<hr />- Protocol embodies a layered ecosystem: social (recognition) + governance + economic incentives.<hr />- Long-term aspiration: borderless, autonomous software community with shared ownership and continuous benefit.<hr />- Future components: proposal system, voting mechanisms, integrated workflows, sustained decentralization.<hr />- Visual representation: a playful, evolving map of innovation, appreciation, governance, and ownership within decentralized software culture.

270.description: Explore our November 2023 Labs Roadmap highlighting innovative technology projects and challenges for the upcoming month. Key focus areas include WebAssembly (WASM), Passwordless Authentication, Rust, AI, MPC, and UI practices.
270.spr_content: Key concepts and associations:  <hr />- Collaborative Labs and Consulting teams identify core topics, challenges, and potential projects.  <hr />- Focus on deep technological engagement and practical applications.  <hr />- Primary focus for upcoming period: WebAssembly (WASM).  <hr />- Topics are interconnected; some overlap and intersect.  <hr />- Each topic has a PIC (Person In Charge) and a defined set of challenges:  <hr />  - **WASM** (An Tran):  <hr />    - Self-host AI models in-browser (OCR, private chatbots).  <hr />    - Data processing and visualization with DuckDB-WASM.  <hr />    - Implementing Rust-based games via WASM.  <hr />  - **Passwordless** (An Tran):  <hr />    - Web biometrics with external devices.  <hr />    - QR code login solutions.  <hr />    - Magic links for authentication.  <hr />  - **Rust** (Hieu Phan):  <hr />    - Rust-based game server development.  <hr />  - **AI** (Tom):  <hr />    - Real-time memory updates using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG).  <hr />  - **MPC** (Huy Nguyen):  <hr />    - Multi-party computation for Web3 authentication.  <hr />  - **UI practices** (Thanh Pham):  <hr />    - Building "mochi-ui" interface.  <hr />- Other explored domains remain in backlog: functional programming, API mockups, aspect-oriented programming, CRDT vs. OT, cloud HSM, fullstack shifts, analytics, databases, iframe integration, ziglang, openid, Zero Trust Infra, feature flags.  <hr />- Challenges documented in the "earn" program; contact PICs for details.  <hr /><hr />Underlying metaphor:  <hr />- Focused exploration as a multi-layered web of interconnected technological nodes, primed for deep dive with primed latent knowledge activate specific project-colored pathways.

271.title: How R&D contributes to Performance Review
271.description: Our organization values the research and development (R&D) efforts of our team members and aims to incorporate these contributions into performance reviews. It's important that individual R&D activities not only pursue personal growth but also align with our team and organizational objectives.
