271.spr_content: - Organization values individual R&D efforts and integrates them into performance reviews.  <hr />- R&D activities should promote personal growth and align with team and organizational goals.  <hr />- Key performance factors for R&D: alignment with team objectives, relevance to sales and consulting needs, personal topic choice.  <hr />- Research must support future team growth and success; topics should resonate with sales/consulting audiences.  <hr />- Personal topic selection may differ from collective priorities; pursuit of passion topics is encouraged if justified with progress and value.  <hr />- Goals and objectives for research should be established collaboratively with team leaders and referenced in self-review.  <hr />- Clearly define initial research goals and expected outcomes through goal agreement.  <hr />- Flexibility allowed for exploring new areas; topic changes require prompt communication and approval.  <hr />- Late changes in research topics impact evaluation timing, deferred to subsequent review cycle for fairness.
271.tags: assessment dwarves internal labs performance-review work

272.title: Command Pattern
272.description: Command is a behavioral design pattern that encapsulates a request as an object. This allows you to parameterize methods with different requests, delay or queue a request’s execution, and support undoable operations. This pattern promotes the decoupling of the sender and receiver of a request, enhancing flexibility and maintainability.
272.spr_content: - Command Pattern is a behavioral design pattern that encapsulates requests as objects.  <hr />- Encapsulation allows parameterization, queuing, delaying execution, and undo support.  <hr />- Decouples request sender from receiver, increasing flexibility and maintainability.  <hr />- Core components: Command Interface, Concrete Command, Receiver, Invoker.  <hr />- Command Interface declares an execute() method; all commands implement it uniformly.  <hr />- Concrete Command binds to a Receiver, implementing execute() by invoking Receiver operations.  <hr />- Receiver is aware of how to perform specific actions for request fulfillment.  <hr />- Invoker requests command execution; it can store, queue, and support undo operations.  <hr />- Real-life analogy: restaurant scenario with waiter (Invoker, queuing orders), paper orders (Commands), kitchen staff (Receiver).  <hr />- Orders serve as commands, holding all info needed for preparation, enabling asynchronous, queued processing.  <hr />- Pros: adheres to Single Responsibility, supports Open/Closed, undo/redo, deferred, and complex commands.  <hr />- Cons: adds complexity layer between sender and receiver, which can complicate code structure.  <hr />- Applicability: transactional systems, task schedulers, user interfaces, batch processing.

273.title: Going Through use cases of the prototype design pattern and it place among the creational patterns
273.description: Prototype, one of the creational patterns, minimize efforts when recreating new from the exist object by cloning the 'prototype' of it.
273.spr_content: - Problem: difficult to clone objects with runtime-initialized, private, or multi-process manipulated properties (e.g., DB credentials, transaction histories).   <hr />- Cloning complexity: private fields, encapsulation, dynamic state.   <hr />- Prototype pattern: request object copy without knowing class or implementation.   <hr />- Prototype: add Clone() method to produce a mirror object with essential state for user.   <hr />- In Go example: Hero object with private fields (level, experience, killLogIDs).   <hr />- Clone method: returns shallow copy of Hero including selected private data.   <hr />- Cloning allows bypassing heavy reconstruction, preserving core data.   <hr />- Prototype works with factory, builder, abstract factory: creates original object; prototype clones it.   <hr />- Opposite to singleton: prototype enables cloning during mid-process, not a single shared instance.   <hr />- Common use cases: credentials/access objects, ledger/bank statement objects.   <hr />- Prototype facilitates object replication for statistics, simulations, or internal processing without exposing encapsulation.  <hr />- Key insight: provides a flexible, runtime-independent way to replicate complex objects with private or protected state.

274.title: Subscription Pricing Models
274.spr_content: Pricing Models Overview:<hr />- Freemium: attract users with free baseline; upgrade for premium; example Evernote; use for market entry, viral growth.<hr />- Pay per Quantity: charge per unit (seats, emails); example Help Scout; suits predictable, scalable costs for large orgs.<hr />- Pay per Active User: charge only for active users; example Slack; appeals to large enterprises, fairness.<hr />- Flat-fee: fixed recurring charge; example Hubspot; stabilizes revenue, appeals to risk-averse customers.<hr />- Pay-as-you-go: usage-based, tiered; example Postmark; adaptable, value-focused, flexible demand.<hr />- Tiered: predefined usage tiers; example ManageWiz; structured pricing for different consumption levels.<hr />- Volume: decreasing unit price with larger quantity; example Jira; incentivizes bulk purchases, economies of scale.<hr />- Stair-step: fixed price for usage ranges; example Trello; predictable, simple, transparent.<hr />- Name Your Price: negotiated, bespoke; example Jira enterprise; high-touch, customized solutions.<hr />- Hybrid: combines multiple models; example DocuSign; multi-dimensional value extraction, upgrade paths.<hr />- À la carte: select specific features; example Shopify; flexible, modular feature pay, adaptable to many needs.<hr />References: https://www.chargebee.com/resources/guides/subscription-pricing-trial-strategy/find-the-right-pricing-model/

275.title: How We Set Up a Recording Workflow for Dwarves Office Hours
275.description: This memo is essentially a playbook and recipe on how to record the Discord events.
275.spr_content: Dwarves Foundation Office Hours content capture:<hr /><hr />- Topics are numerous, valuable, and should be preserved.<hr />- Objective: share findings, promote community learning.<hr />- Workflow involves dual-format recording: video and audio.<hr />- Prerequisites: OBS Studio installed; Craig Bot installed.<hr />- The memo serves as a procedural playbook for discord event recording.<hr /><hr />Video recording and streaming:<hr /><hr />- Configure OBS: select specific window, set streaming mode (multi-platform), mute microphone.<hr />- During OGIF: start OBS recording and YouTube stream simultaneously.<hr />- End OGIF: stop recording, save file, split into sessions.<hr /><hr />Audio recording:<hr /><hr />- Use Craig Bot: invite to server, then to voice channel (`/join` command).<hr />- During OGIF: background audio is recorded, segments labeled by user.<hr />- Post-OGIF: stop Craig, save audio, transcribe with ChatGPT-4.<hr />- Transcripts are segmented analogous to video parts.<hr /><hr />Metaphors and associations:<hr /><hr />- OBS is a capture device, like a camera capturing a scene.<hr />- Streaming mode is a multi-venue broadcast, akin to theater on multiple stages.<hr />- Craig Bot functions as an audio recorder and segmenter—like a diligent scribe.<hr />- Transcription is translating spoken word into written record—building a knowledge archive.<hr />- Workflow ensures no interesting content is lost; archives as digital fossil record.

276.title: How to earn reward from staking DFG
276.description: This guide will show you how to use $DFG staking to earn $USDC, cool merch, and more.
276.spr_content: Using $DFG staking on Base:<hr /><hr />- $DFG: token from Dwarves Foundation, future distributions expected, available on Ethereum.<hr />- Dwarves created a staking pool on Base, enabling staking for rewards.<hr />- Rewards calculated via a specific formula based on staked amount and APY (~10%).<hr />- Preparation: store tokens in Coinbase Wallet (see how-to guide).<hr />- Transfer ETH from Binance to Coinbase Wallet (see guide).<hr />- Move ETH from Binance to Base network; transfer $DFG from Ethereum to Base (see guides).<hr />- Access Dwarves Foundation Earning via web, log in with Coinbase Wallet, verify DFG balance.<hr />- Stake: select amount, confirm transactions, earn passive rewards.<hr />- Rewards accrue with ~10% APY; monitor earnings via "My Earn" dashboard.<hr />- To withdraw: unstake via platform, confirm transactions, retrieve $DFG and rewards to wallet.<hr />- Staking involves multiple transaction confirmations; passive income through holding.<hr />- Process emphasizes user guides for each transfer step; rewards incentivize continued staking.

277.title: The Best of CSS TLDR
277.description: Tailwind is not another Bootstrap, a `justify-center` class maps exactly to 1 line of css code, you have total control over what is being shipped to the user, whereas a `.btn` class in Bootstrap expands to +50 line of css styles and custom variables, you can customize it but it will not be a joyful experience.
277.spr_content: - UI libraries primarily fall into three categories: pure styling, behavioral, and style systems.<hr />- Pure: CSS-only, no JavaScript, compile-time styling; examples include Tailwind and SASS; focus on visual design.<hr />- Behavioral: JavaScript-driven, framework-agnostic, unstyled components for accessibility and cross-browser consistency; examples include HeadlessUI, Radix, React-Aria.<hr />- Style system: Opinionated component libraries built atop CSS modules, with predefined styles; examples include Bootstrap, TailwindUI, Mantine, DaisyUI; library controls appearance.<hr />- Bootstrap's `.btn` expands to many CSS rules, making customization cumbersome.<hr />- Tailwind offers single CSS classes (e.g., `justify-center`) that map directly to minimal CSS, enabling precise control and easier learning.<hr />- MUI (Material UI) blends behavioral and style system; provides styled components with built-in JS interactions; limits extensive customization and may require hacks.<hr />- When unsure, prefer Tailwind: accelerates CSS mastery, enhances component quality, and adapts easily.<hr />- Tailwind's utility-first approach contrasts with monolithic class-based CSS frameworks; fosters flexibility and developer control.<hr />

278.title: Understanding Saving, Investing, and Speculating: Key Differences and Strategies
278.description: In personal finance, the strategies we choose to manage our money can significantly impact our financial future. These strategies typically fall into three categories: saving, investing, and speculating. Each comes with its own levels of risk, timeframes, and methods. Understanding the distinctions and appropriate uses of each can guide us in making smarter financial decisions...
278.spr_content: - Personal finance strategies: saving, investing, speculating; distinct risk, timeframes, methods.<hr />- Saving: low risk, secure, short-term, emergency fund; regular deposits, capital preservation.<hr />- Investing: moderate risk, long-term, wealth growth; asset purchases, diversification, appreciation.<hr />- Speculating: high risk, short-term, rapid gains; market timing, high volatility, aggressive trades.<hr />- Key differences focus on risk, timeframe, approach, mindset.<hr />- Strategies can mix; adapt to life stage, goals, risk appetite.<hr />- Saving goal: safeguard capital, ensure liquidity.<hr />- Investing goal: wealth accumulation via assets, diversification.<hr />- Speculating goal: quick profits, risk acceptance.<hr />- Risk management: diversify, research, match strategy to risk tolerance.<hr />- Long-term/investment horizon guides suitable strategy.<hr />- Diversification reduces risk across all strategies.<hr />- Tailor strategies to personal goals and risk levels; informed, wise use essential.

279.title: Introduce the Builder pattern and its use cases
279.description: Builder, one of the creational patterns, allows user to construct complex object step by step while still maintaining flexibility.
279.spr_content: - Factory pattern creates fixed objects without flexibility, pushing all choices into a single step.<hr />- Builder pattern introduces a stepwise construction process, enabling incremental customization.<hr />- Builder methods return the builder instance, facilitating method chaining for readability.<hr />- Finalization method, typically called `build()`, outputs the constructed object.<hr />- Example: `DrinkBuilder` constructs `Drink` objects via chained steps: naming, adding ingredients, mixing.<hr />- Builder encapsulates property modifications, hiding complexity from the consumer.<hr />- Method chaining enhances code clarity and intuitive object configuration.<hr />- In practice, libraries like jQuery, wretch, zod, and Spotify API wrappers exemplify builder usage.<hr />- Pros: improves readability through explicit step-wise commands; offers high flexibility for object configuration.<hr />- Cons: each object type demands a dedicated builder class, complicating maintenance as codebase enlarges.<hr />- The pattern balances customization with potential for class proliferation in extensive systems.<hr />

280.title: A tour of Singleton design pattern with Golang
280.description: Singleton real-world problem, concept, solution, use cases, implementations, pros & cons, references
280.spr_content: - Singleton pattern ensures one instance per class/type, providing global access.<hr />- Useful for managing a single resource, e.g., subscription counter, logger, configuration.<hr />- For real-time subscriber count, Singleton guarantees data consistency across actors (subscribers, visitors).<hr />- Thread safety is critical in multi-threaded environments; prevents missed counts or duplicate instances.<hr />- Eager initialization: create the singleton at app start; simple, less flexible, may impact startup performance.<hr />- Lazy initialization: create singleton on first demand; more complex, needs double-checked locking for thread safety.<hr />- Eager suited for lightweight resources; lazy better for heavy resources to optimize performance.<hr />- Singleton's benefits include controlled instantiation and global availability.<hr />- Drawbacks involve tight coupling, debugging difficulty, testing challenges, and limited applicability.<hr />- Implementation involves defining a class/struct, then instantiation strategy (eager or lazy).<hr />- Pseudocode demonstrates singleton with thread-safe lazy loading using double-checked locking.<hr />- Singleton pattern resolves concurrent access issues, ensuring consistent live subscriber count across web app actors.

281.title: Designing a model with dynamic properties
281.description: When we started working on this project aimed at the creative community, we faced an interesting challenge. We needed to build a model that was similar to a task but with a key difference: it had to support custom, dynamic, and extensible properties. If you’ve ever used Notion and appreciated how flexible its objects are, you’ll know exactly what we were trying to achieve.
281.spr_content: - The project targets the creative community, emphasizing flexible, extensible data models akin to Notion's object system.<hr />- Extensibility is central: support for various data types (text, boolean, select options, date-time, relations).<hr />- Select options must be shareable across teams, serving as reusable configurations.<hr />- Queryability: models must support sorting and pagination; scalability and performance are priorities.<hr />- The foundational `tasks` model links to a `values` table, not directly to `fields`, allowing for flexible, per-task data.<hr />- `Fields` are defined separately, with types dictating their handling (text, checkbox, select, users, etc.) and options.<hr />- `Options` are tied to `select` fields via separate tables, enabling dynamic, shareable choices.<hr />- `Values` store actual data per task, linking back to `fields` and holding type-specific data (text, boolean, select list, user list).<hr />- Modularity achieved by decoupling objects (`tasks`) from their fields, facilitating dynamic field sets per task.<hr />- Decision to relate `tasks` to `values` rather than directly to `fields` enhances flexibility and simplifies data flow.<hr />- Removing relationships between tasks and fields directly reduces complexity, easing field removal and updates.<hr />- Challenges include complex joins affecting performance during filtering and pagination; reliance on CTEs to optimize queries.<hr />- Cross-team collaboration is limited by field scoping; shared workspace across teams remains an ongoing challenge.<hr />- System design balances flexibility and efficiency, supporting growth and adaptation with room for future improvements.

282.title: Typesafe Client Server
282.description: A code generation layer that bridges the gap between frontend and backend more effectively.
282.spr_content: - Software development relies on models and API clients in strongly-typed languages.  <hr />- Models represent data structures: objects, parameters, responses.  <hr />- API client mediates requests, binds data to models.  <hr />- Synchronization between backend models and frontend models is vital but often manual, error-prone.  <hr />- Manual sync leads to inconsistencies, runtime bugs.  <hr />- Typesafe client-server architecture introduces code generation as a bridge.  <hr />- API definitions in JSON/YAML serve as single source of truth; generate models and clients automatically.  <hr />- Code generation ensures frontend and backend "speak the same data language."  <hr />- Changes in API are reflected instantly and accurately on both sides.  <hr />- Automation minimizes human errors; accelerates development, refocuses effort on features.  <hr />- Benefits: increased reliability, early error detection, higher productivity, better security, clearer documentation, easier refactoring.  <hr />- Effective use involves API-first design, automating code generation, integrating into CI/CD, thorough testing, interactive docs, and versioning.  <hr />- Tools: openapi-generator (validates Swagger, uses Axios), Orval (multi-client codegen, mock data support).  <hr />- References include OpenAPI specs, Swagger, spectral, trpc.

283.title: Google Dataproc
283.description: Google Dataproc is a fast and easy-to-use, fully managed cloud service for running Apache Spark and Hadoop workloads. It allows users to process and analyze large-scale data efficiently and at scale.
283.spr_content: - Google Dataproc is a managed cloud service designed for running Apache Spark and Hadoop workloads efficiently.<hr />- It offers fast, scalable processing leveraging Google Cloud infrastructure.<hr />- Seamless integration with Google Cloud services (BigQuery, Cloud Storage, Spanner) centralizes data access.<hr />- Supports data analytics, machine learning model development, and deployment.<hr />- Delivers a secure, fully managed environment eliminating infrastructure worries.<hr />- Simplifies big data processing with a unified platform for various workloads.<hr />- Use cases span batch processing (ETL, data warehousing, log analysis, financial, scientific, image processing), real-time processing (streaming data, IoT, ML training), and other domains (web scraping, social media, genomics).<hr />- Pricing is based on cluster vCPU count and runtime duration, billed per second with a 1-minute minimum, plus costs for associated Google Cloud resources.<hr />- Example: A 24 vCPU cluster running 2 hours costs approximately $0.48, excluding other resource charges.<hr />- Setup prerequisites: GCP account, billing enabled, Google Cloud SDK installed, project created, APIs enabled.<hr />- Cluster creation via `gcloud` command with customizable parameters.<hr />- Access and manage clusters through Cloud Shell and GCP Console.<hr />- Submit jobs (Spark/Hadoop) through the Console’s `Submit Job` interface.<hr />- Specify job ID, type, main file location, and optional parameters.<hr />- Monitor job status till completion, then delete clusters to avoid charges.<hr />- Full deployment involves choosing job type, entering details, submitting, and verifying execution results.
283.tags: ETL brainery data data-engineering engineering/data google-dataproc hadoop streaming

284.title: Leveraging Golang and WebRTC for High-Performance Video Streaming
284.description: Explores using Golang and the Pion WebRTC library to build high-performance, scalable, low-latency video streaming infrastructure. Covers WebRTC basics (ICE, STUN, TURN), Go's concurrency benefits, Pion's native Go implementation, and a real-world multi-stream security monitoring use case.
284.spr_content: - WebRTC enables fast, reliable browser-based peer-to-peer media transfer without extra installs.<hr />- WebRTC reduces latency by bypassing central servers, establishing direct peer connections.<hr />- NAT and firewalls hinder true direct connections; ICE, STUN, TURN facilitate traversal.<hr />- ICE uses STUN to discover public IPs; fallback to TURN relays when direct fails.<hr />- Signaling infrastructure is essential for coordination, offer/answer exchange, candidate sharing.<hr />- Go (Golang) excels for WebRTC signaling servers: lightweight concurrency via goroutines, channels.<hr />- Go’s performance in network I/O matches demand; compact, fast compilation aids rapid iteration.<hr />- Pion provides a native Go WebRTC stack; no CGo or external dependencies needed.<hr />- Example: Pion WebRTC setup with STUN, event handlers for ICE, media tracks.<hr />- Multi-stream, low-latency security feeds illustrate scalability: handling thousands of concurrent streams.<hr />- Challenges include scalable architecture, signaling robustness, resource optimization, low-latency media flow.<hr />- Signaling protocol typically over WebSocket, exchanging SDP and ICE candidates.<hr />- System architecture involves sources (cameras), backend (Go/Pion), signaling, and browser dashboards.<hr />- Golang’s reputation in video is less mature than C++, but its strengths in networking and concurrency align with WebRTC needs.<hr />- Pion bridges this gap, providing a composable, native WebRTC library in Go, streamlining system design.<hr />- Go’s performance is sufficient for signaling, relaying, and connection management; not just raw media processing.<hr />- Combining Go + Pion yields scalable, low-latency, browser-compatible video infrastructures.<hr />- Advantages: high throughput, low latency, cross-platform WebRTC, developer productivity, easy horizontal scaling.<hr />- Modern WebRTC infrastructure benefits from Go’s concurrency and performance strengths, with mature libraries.<hr />- Proven capacity to deliver secure, multi-stream, real-time video at scale confirms Go’s viability.<hr />- Overall, for critical real-time video systems, Golang offers an effective, maintainable, and performant foundation.

285.title: Google Data Fusion
285.description: Google Data Fusion is a fully managed, cloud-native data integration service that enables users to efficiently build and manage ETL/ELT data pipelines. It is designed to streamline data engineering tasks for enterprise users and is built on top of the open-source project CDAP.
285.spr_content: - Google Data Fusion is a cloud-native, fully managed data integration service built on open-source CDAP.<hr />- It facilitates efficient construction and management of ETL/ELT data pipelines for enterprises.<hr />- Features include a user-friendly GUI with drag-and-drop interface, reducing coding requirements.<hr />- Highly flexible, allowing custom code extensions alongside visual pipeline creation.<hr />- GCP-native architecture ensures scalability, reliability, security, and privacy.<hr />- Supports data governance through data lineage, metadata management, and cloud-native security.<hr />- Integrates seamlessly with Google Cloud services like Cloud Storage, BigQuery, and Cloud Spanner.<hr />- Simplifies data consolidation across multiple sources, including on-premises, cloud, and SaaS apps.<hr />- Enables data transformation, cleansing, enrichment, and creation of data warehouses and lakes.<hr />- Assists in cloud data migration and cross-platform data replication (GCP, AWS, Azure).<hr />- Supports real-time data processing via Apache Spark, enabling live dashboards, alerts, and event-triggered actions.<hr />- Offers additional capabilities such as data governance, self-service data access, and custom connector development.<hr />- Pricing tiers range from Basic to Enterprise, each with specific features and capacities.<hr />- Setup requires a GCP account, enabling the Data Fusion API, installing Cloud SDK, and creating storage and Data Fusion instances.<hr />- Creating a Data Fusion instance involves specifying region, zone, network, subnet, and storage bucket.<hr />- Access the Data Fusion UI via the created instance’s URL to design pipelines visually.<hr />- A typical ETL setup involves deploying a pipeline with source (GCS), transformation (Wrangler), and sink (BigQuery).<hr />- Data loading includes uploading CSV to GCS, configuring source and sink properties, and deploying pipelines.<hr />- Running the pipeline executes data transfer and transformation, with status and results viewable in BigQuery.<hr />- Overall, Data Fusion accelerates data integration, enhances governance, and supports real-time analytics at scale.
285.tags: CDAP ETL Google-Data-Studio brainery data data-engineering devops engineering/data google-cloud google-data-fusion reliability

286.file_path: playground/notes/Engineering/Backend/SQL Sargable Queries and Their Impact on Database Performance.md
286.title: SQL Saragable Queries and Their Impact on Database Performance
286.description: Structured Query Language (SQL) is widely used for managing data in relational database management systems (RDBMS). In the context of SQL, the optimization of database queries forms the foundation for efficient data retrieval, providing quicker response times and increasing overall database performance. One key strategy to optimize SQL queries involves the concept of "Sargable" queries...
286.spr_content: - SQL manages relational databases; query optimization ensures fast data retrieval and improved performance.<hr />- "Sargable" (Search Argument Able) queries are designed to leverage indexes effectively.<hr />- Originates from a 1979 paper by Selinger et al., emphasizing optimal access paths via indexes.<hr />- Sargable queries allow the query engine to use indexes for faster execution.<hr />- Non-sargable queries involve functions or operations on indexed columns, blocking index usage.<hr />- Examples:<hr />  - Sargable: `WHERE myColumn LIKE 'ABC%'` — uses index via prefix wildcards.<hr />  - Non-sargable: `WHERE SUBSTRING(myColumn, 1, 3) = 'ABC'` — disables index use.<hr />- Using wildcards at the beginning of a LIKE pattern (`'%prefix%'`) prevents index seek, resulting in table scans.<hr />- Modifying queries to match exact values (`column = 'value'`) makes them sargable.<hr />- Proper handling of NULLs affects index utility; `IS NOT NULL` predicates are typically non-sargable.<hr />- Combining multiple `IS NOT NULL` conditions can facilitate index use on multiple columns.<hr />- Function calls like `YEAR(dateColumn) = 2022` disable index usage; rewriting as range queries (`dateColumn >= '2022-01-01' AND dateColumn < '2023-01-01'`) restores sargability.<hr />- Sargable queries perform index seeks, limiting IO, reducing disk reads and writes.<hr />- Efficient index use (clustered, non-clustered, columnstore) critically enhances search speed.<hr />- In large datasets, sargable queries significantly boost system speed and efficiency.<hr />- Converting non-sargable to sargable involves avoiding functions on indexed columns and using appropriate comparison operators.<hr />- Mastery of sargability principles is essential for robust SQL programming, optimization, and performance tuning.

287.file_path: playground/notes/Engineering/Backend/SQL and how it relates to Disk Reads and Writes.md
287.title: SQL and how it relates to Disk Reads and Writes
287.description: Sequential read/write operations involve accessing data in a continuous, linear manner. This typically occurs when transferring large files or accessing a large file on the drive. In sequential read/write operations, the drive can read or write data from a series of blocks, allowing for faster performance...
287.spr_content: - Random reads/writes access scattered small data blocks, increasing seek time, slowing performance, especially on HDDs; SSDs mitigate this.<hr />- Sequential reads/writes process contiguous data blocks linearly, enabling faster transfer rates.<hr />- Hard drives excel at sequential I/O; random I/O limits their performance due to head movement.<hr />- SQL operations (SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, INDEXing) translate to either sequential or random disk actions based on data organization.<hr />- SELECT can be sequential if data is contiguous; otherwise, random.<hr />- INSERTs may be sequential if appending; random if inserting at arbitrary positions.<hr />- UPDATEs and DELETEs typically cause random I/O due to scattered data.<hr />- Index creating/updating can involve sequential (clustered index) or random (non-clustered index) I/O.<hr />- Database design influences I/O pattern: partitioning reduces scatter; indexing accelerates queries; configuration tuning improves performance.<hr />- Separate storage techniques (SSDs for random, HDDs for sequential) exploit hardware strengths.<hr />- SQL performance optimization involves partitioning, indexing, query rewriting, tablespace placement, and configuration tuning.<hr />- Disk layout and data organization are critical for maximizing sequential I/O, minimizing random I/O.<hr />- CQRS design benefits by segregating read/write paths, enabling tailored storage solutions for each.<hr />- Read-heavy workloads favor SSDs and optimized schemas for random access; write-heavy favor sequential writes.<hr />- Understanding I/O patterns guides effective database schema design, hardware deployment, and optimization strategies.<hr />- Latent model capabilities include understanding the trade-offs and optimizing data access patterns through architecture and hardware choices.
287.tags: data-engineering engineering random-reads random-writes sequential-reads sequential-writes

288.title: Bloom Filter
288.description: A Bloom Filter is a probabilistic data structure used for testing whether an element is a member of a set or not. It's space-efficient compared to other data structures like hash tables, but it may give false positives (indicating that an element is in the set when it's not) and never gives false negatives (indicating that an element is not in the set when it actually is not)...
288.spr_content: - Bloom Filter is a probabilistic, space-efficient data structure for set membership testing.<hr />- It uses a bit array and multiple hash functions.<hr />- Initialization: bit array of size m (large prime), k hash functions.<hr />- Adding element: hash with each function, set corresponding bits to 1.<hr />- Checking element: hash with each, verify all bits are 1; if so, probably in set; if any 0, definitely not.<hr />- False positives possible, false negatives impossible.<hr />- Suitable for large-scale systems: user registration, caching, data deduplication, web crawling, spell checking, network routing, distributed synchronization.<hr />- Strengths: space-efficient, fast O(k), no false negatives, adaptable.<hr />- Weaknesses: false positives, no removal support, sensitive to parameter choice, limited operations, hash function quality impacts performance.<hr />- Practical implementation example provided in Go code.<hr />- Use cases accept small false positive risk for efficiency gains.<hr />- Not appropriate when exact membership or element removal needed.

289.title: Introduction to CRDT
289.description: Conflict-free Replicated Data Types (CRDTs) (aka convergent replicated data type or commutative replicated data type) are data structures that can be replicated across multiple computers in a network, where the replicas can be updated independently and concurrently without coordination between them, and enable operations to always converge to a final state consistent among all replicas.
289.spr_content: CRDTs are data structures enabling concurrent independent updates across distributed systems. They guarantee eventual convergence to a consistent state without coordination.  <hr />CRDTs address the data modification dilemma by facilitating optimistic replication where conflicts are resolved automatically.  <hr />Strong consistency relies on coordination, sacrificing performance due to CAP theorem limitations.  <hr />Optimistic replication improves performance but introduces conflicts, which CRDTs resolve seamlessly through commutative operations.  <hr />CRDTs are essential in applications like mobile synchronization, distributed databases, collaborative software, and large-scale storage.  <hr />They support decentralized, peer-to-peer networks, avoiding reliance on central servers or single authority.  <hr />CRDTs automate conflict resolution, merging divergent changes into a coherent state without user intervention or conflict resolution code.  <hr />Different from systems like Google Docs or Trello, CRDTs do not presuppose central coordination, enabling seamless operation in decentralized environments.

290.file_path: playground/notes/Engineering/Backend/The removal of Apache Kafka's dependency on Zookeeper.md
290.title: The removal of Apache Kafka's dependency on Zookeeper
290.description: Kafka has been using Zookeeper for a variety of important functions. It uses Zookeeper to keep track of which brokers are part of the Kafka cluster. This is a critical task, as it enables Kafka to ensure that each broker is working properly and that the entire cluster is functioning as intended...
290.spr_content: Zookeeper in Kafka:  <hr />- Tracks cluster membership, brokers are part of Kafka cluster.  <hr />- Elects partition leaders; resource-intensive task.  <hr />- Stores topic configurations, permissions, consumer offsets.  <hr />- Sends health notifications for cluster events.  <hr /><hr />Downsides of Zookeeper:  <hr />- Metadata mismatches with Kafka Controller cause confusion.  <hr />- Overload during high leader elections affects performance.  <hr />- Limited scaling: max ~200k partitions.  <hr /><hr />Kafka's architecture (pre-removal):  <hr />- Controller loads state from Zookeeper quorum.  <hr />- Uses `LeaderAndIsr` and `UpdateMetadata` messages to synchronize cluster state.  <hr />- Critical for cluster management and stability.  <hr /><hr />Transition to KRaft mode:  <hr />- Replaces Zookeeper with Controller quorum managed via Raft consensus.  <hr />- Controller manages all metadata internally, no dependency on Zookeeper.  <hr />- Active controller handles RPCs; followers replicate data.  <hr />- Improves performance, reduces leader election overhead.  <hr />- Brokers fetch updates via `MetadataFetch` API, only latest data.  <hr />- Simplifies setup, configuration; eliminates external Zookeeper service.  <hr />- Enhances scalability beyond 200k partitions.  <hr />- Supports smoother, faster cluster operations and more reliable metadata management.  <hr /><hr />Overall:  <hr />- Zookeeper enabled critical Kafka functions but faced performance & consistency issues.  <hr />- KRaft architecture offers a streamlined, scalable, and more efficient alternative, paving way for future Kafka deployments.

291.title: Introducing HTMX - Navigating the Advantages and Concerns
291.description: A comprehensive exploration of HTMX, a JavaScript library that extends HTML as a hypermedia, addressing the limitations of legacy HTML applications.
291.spr_content: - HTMX is a lightweight, hypermedia-oriented JavaScript library that extends HTML to simplify dynamic web development with minimal scripting.  <hr />- It enhances HTML with custom attributes, enabling any element to send requests, trigger events, and update targets without writing JavaScript.  <hr />- Core concept: clients and servers share hypermedia elements, allowing robust navigation and interaction; server modifications won’t break clients if hypermedia options are recognized.  <hr />- Attributes such as hx-get, hx-trigger, and hx-target facilitate request sending, event control, and content replacement.  <hr />- Example: input with hx-get, hx-trigger with delay, and hx-target to update results; showcases simplicity over JavaScript or React.  <hr />- HTMX supports AJAX, WebSocket, SSE natively, reducing the need for extensive JavaScript code.  <hr />- HTMX provides APIs for AJAX requests, server-triggered events, and reaction to server responses (e.g., custom events via HX-Trigger headers).  <hr />- Use cases: rapid rendering, SEO, simple CRUD, UI blocks updating; advantageous for performance, locality of behavior, and team agility.  <hr />- Limitations include potential SOC violations, reduced control over client-side logic, and reliance on server responses that manage UI states.  <hr />- Best suited for projects emphasizing HTML-driven interaction, where UI dependencies are manageable, and offline support is not critical.  <hr />- HTMX offers a novel, agile paradigm, balancing server-side control with simplified client-side code, an alternative to traditional JavaScript frameworks.

292.title: URL Redirect vs. Rewrite; What’s the difference?
292.description: When working with websites and managing the computers that show them, we run into two important ideas: redirect URLs and rewrite URLs. These ideas are like tools that help us make websites work better for people. They help us make websites easier to find on search engines, and they help us make the paths on websites smoother. In this guide, we're going to explore these tools together. We'll learn what makes them different and how we can use them to make websites even cooler.
292.spr_content: - Redirect URLs guide users from one URL to another, acting as digital signposts during webpage relocations or restructures.<hr />- Rewrite URLs modify URLs before content delivery, creating clean, user-friendly, and SEO-optimized paths.<hr />- 301 redirects are permanent, transfer SEO value, and update search engine indexes; 302 redirects are temporary, suggest return to original URL.<hr />- Redirects involve server instructions to browser: request → server redirect rule → browser navigates to new URL.<hr />- URL rewriting occurs on the server, transforming complex URLs into simplified, descriptive formats before content delivery.<hr />- Clean URLs enhance readability and memorability, e.g., `/products/123` instead of long query strings.<hr />- SEO-friendly URLs include relevant keywords, improving rankings and click-through rates.<hr />- User experience improves with shareable, memorable URLs; e.g., `/contact` more inviting than convoluted links.<hr />- Differences: redirects change URL display and involve HTTP status codes; rewriting alters URL appearance without changing the URL in the browser.<hr />- Use redirects for content movement; choose rewriting for cleaner URLs without relocating content.<hr />- Both techniques contribute to seamless navigation, better SEO, and organized websites.

293.title: Data Pipeline Design Framework
293.description: To improve and strongly go-live the data pipeline, besides apply best practices and pillar for Data Pipeline Native Solution, a design framework and pattern are robustly help us in...
293.spr_content: - Data pipeline design improves reliability, maintainability, and go-live success by applying best practices and structured patterns.<hr />- Frameworks and patterns help organize workflow, align with market standards, and facilitate peer reference.<hr />- Discussing patterns with SWAT ensures pros/cons assessment, clarifies best/worst use cases, and promotes initiative questions: when to use or not.<hr />- Choosing data pipeline approach hinges on key questions: need for historical data, replayability, source size, transformation complexity, sink type, and idempotence.<hr />- Source systems: determine if data is replayable, ordered, and supports versioning; informs design choices.<hr />- Sink systems: assess if overwritable (primary key, unique IDs) or append-only (Kafka, queues) for data consistency and deduplication.<hr />- Pattern selection is guided by extraction method: time-range/delta, snapshot, lookback, streaming.<hr />- Time-range/delta pulls data only for specific periods, enabling fast, parallelized, but complex merge logic and source replay reliance.<hr />- Snapshot pattern pulls entire dataset per run, easy to track, version, but costly, slow, schema-sensitive.<hr />- Lookback supports late-arriving data, ideal for KPI and fact tables; introduces dashboard confusion if data is late.<hr />- Streaming offers low latency, real-time insights but requires scaling, fault handling, and source replay support.<hr />- Behavioral patterns: idempotency via delete-write ensures data consistency, albeit with longer dev time, best for OLAP.<hr />- Self-healing pipelines automatically recover from failures using checkpoints and meta-tables, reducing alert fatigue but adding complexity.<hr />- Structural patterns: multi-hop levels isolate data quality issues, enable modular debugging; requires staging, increasing storage costs.<hr />- Conditional/dynamic pipelines adapt flow based on input, flexible but complex to debug, test, and maintain.<hr />- Disconnected pipelines leverage other pipelines’ sinks, promoting decoupling but complicating lineage, debugging, and SLA enforcement.<hr />- Multi-hop and layered transformations improve data quality, fault detection, and traceability.<hr />- Dynamic and conditional pipelines manage complexity, accommodate evolving requirements; challenge is in debugging and testing.<hr />- Final considerations emphasize communication, feedback, iterative refinement, and applying Scrum practices for effective development.<hr />- Continuous reflection and peer input are vital; lack of experience is common; invite questions and collaboration to enhance design.

294.title: MapReduce
294.description: We are the head of census bureau for the state of California and tasked with finding the finding the population of all cities in California. All the resources we want are ready but we have only four months to finish the task. Calculating the population of all cities for a big state like california is not an easy task. The sensible thing to do is to divide the state by city and make individuals in charge of each city to calculate the population of each city where he is in charge of...
294.spr_content: - MapReduce is a distributed programming model for large data set processing.  <hr />- It is not a programming language, but a conceptual framework.  <hr />- Conceived by Google, adapted by Hadoop.  <hr />- It divides tasks into Map phase, Shuffle phase, and Reduce phase.  <hr />- Map phase involves individual data collection by Mappers.  <hr />- Each Mapper processes an Input Split and produces key-value pairs.  <hr />- Key: City or city part; Value: population count in a home.  <hr />- Shuffle phase transfers intermediate key-value pairs from Mappers to Reducers.  <hr />- Reducers consolidate data to produce final outputs per city.  <hr />- The Map phase is about collecting local data; the Reduce phase is about aggregation.  <hr />- Scalability: doubling resources halves processing time; model scale-out friendly.  <hr />- To ensure data integrity, results from city parts are sent to specific HQs, not mixed.  <hr />- This model mimics dividing a big task into smaller, independent chunks for parallel processing.  <hr />- Hadoop’s implementation manages communication, data transfer, and parallelism automatically.

295.title: Quick Learning Vector Database
295.description: The motivation of this thoughts that trying to discover the LLMs and Generative AI...
295.spr_content: - The motivation behind vector databases is to facilitate discovery and development in LLMs and Generative AI.  <hr />- Building models requires addressing data scarcity, metadata management, infrastructure, and data handling.  <hr />- Vector databases underpin Generative AI by storing tokenized, vectorized, and serialized data in a unified language.  <hr />- Data (video, speech, images, text) is encoded into vectors via embedding models like Gemini or OpenAI.  <hr />- Applications involve product development with tools like Drant, Milvus, Redis, pgvector, Pinecone, LanceDB, Oracle, MongoDB Atlas, AthenaDB.  <hr />- Unlike relational databases, vector databases handle multi-dimensional data inherently without fixed schemas.  <hr />- Data structure centers on storing vectors, not predefined table schemas.  <hr />- Queries find similar vectors using algorithms such as KNN, with room for optimization beyond traditional models.  <hr />- Indexing algorithms include Flat, HNSW, IVF; optimization opportunities exist in cache and index management.  <hr />- Workflow: data is embedded into vectors, converted from user input, then queried against database vectors to find matches.  <hr />- Embedding models convert raw data into numerical vectors optimized for large parameter sets.  <hr />- The querying process involves comparing the input vector with stored vectors via similarity measures for resource retrieval.  <hr />- Benefits: schemaless flexibility, scalable bucketing, fast vector search, standardized data format.  <hr />- Use cases include real-time data feeding for LLMs, search problem solutions, video/image recognition, and context-aware recommendations.  <hr />- Technical challenges focus on indexing performance, long-term cache optimization, hardware efficiency, and enhancing KNN models.

296.title: Behavior Driven Development
296.description: Behavior Driven Development (BDD) is a software development process that encourages collaboration among developers, QA, and non-technical stakeholders.
296.spr_content: - BDD practices focus on small, incremental system changes driven by User Stories.  <hr />- First practice involves discussing concrete examples to clarify requirements and expectations.  <hr />- Second practice documents these examples in an executable format to promote shared understanding and agreement.  <hr />- Third practice implements the behavior by starting with automated tests that guide coding.  <hr />- The goal is rapid small changes, iterative feedback, and continuous validation.  <hr />- Use "example exploration" to understand and specify behaviors before development.  <hr />- Automate documented examples to verify behavior and facilitate regression checks.  <hr />- Develop code from these tests, ensuring implementation matches expected behaviors.  <hr />- BDD emphasizes early testing, not only during testing phases but as part of the development process.  <hr />- BDD's intent is to explore and specify multiple scenarios, capturing varied behaviors upfront.  <hr />- Incorporates ubiquitous language, borrowed from DDD, ensuring team-wide shared understanding.  <hr />- Example scenario outlines login process with concrete inputs and expected outcomes, including variable examples.  <hr />- Personal note: If BDD is limited to automation testing, it loses its value; it should influence requirements and design early.

297.title: Designing for Forgiveness: Creating Error-Tolerant Interfaces
297.description: In this article, we will look at some simple principles for designing error-tolerant interfaces and how to apply them to improve user experience.
297.spr_content: - Users will inevitably make errors; system design must accommodate this reality.  <hr />- Error types include accidental actions, misunderstandings, and unclear interfaces.  <hr />- Early warnings prevent mistakes by alerting users before irreversible actions.  <hr />- Examples: save prompts in Word, unsaved changes warnings in Shopify.  <hr />- Early warnings reduce data loss, prevent serious errors, and foster user trust.  <hr />- Clear, consistent interfaces simplify navigation and reduce confusion.  <hr />- Examples: familiar layouts and icons in Microsoft Office ease task switching.  <hr />- Consistency minimizes mistakes caused by unpredictability.  <hr />- Even well-designed systems require error recovery options for quick correction.  <hr />- Examples: undo features in Drive restore accidental deletions.  <hr />- Recovery tools decrease frustration and enable task continuity.  <hr />- Visual feedback alerts users in real-time to prevent mistakes proactively.  <hr />- Examples: Twitter character limit highlight, disable submit; Discord disable button.  <hr />- Real-time cues allow users to correct errors instantly, improving efficiency.  <hr />- Support and guidance—tooltips, tutorials, visual cues—help users avoid mistakes.  <hr />- Examples: tooltips in Word, onboarding tutorials in Webflow assist beginners.  <hr />- Guidance reduces errors, especially among new users, enhancing experience.  <hr />- Designing for forgiveness combines prevention, immediate feedback, and recovery.  <hr />- Goal: instill confidence, reduce obstacles, boost satisfaction through forgiving interfaces.

298.title: Echelon X Singapore 2024: Where Innovations Meet Inspiration
298.description: This year’s Echelon X in Singapore was a bustling hub of innovation, bringing together around 10,000 participants. Along with visiting SPGroup, our team also attended Echelon X to have a better understanding of how the tech and startup ecosystem is heading.
298.spr_content: Echelon X Singapore 2024: a hub of innovation with 10,000+ participants, 154 speakers, startups, investors, government, from 35+ countries. Reinforces Singapore’s status as SE Asia’s leading tech & investment hub.<hr /><hr />Goals:  <hr />- Strengthen tech ecosystem through resilience and collaboration.  <hr />- Promote knowledge sharing, collective innovation, community building.  <hr /><hr />Themes:  <hr />- Resilience via connections, funding, networking support.  <hr />- Sustainability integrated into tech and business practices, aligned with global and government goals.  <hr />- Focus areas: AI, government support, future-proofing strategies.  <hr /><hr />Market dynamics:  <hr />- Thailand & Indonesia emerging as tech hubs; Philippines’ startup funding +50%, reaching $2B; Indonesia leads with $5B (+30%).  <hr />- Regional startup funding constrained by preference for free products, challenging revenue models; startups expanding globally (US, UK, EU) despite costs.  <hr />- Investors cautious, valuing team quality; optimism for sustainable growth; disciplined, valuation-conscious investing.  <hr />- 2024 funding projected at $14B (+40%), with 25% more deals, indicating recovery and confidence.  <hr /><hr />Verticals & sectors:  <hr />- Significant deal activity in top sectors under SNDE theme; detailed data illustrated.  <hr /><hr />Challenges:  <hr />- Post-COVID impacts: housing prices, layoffs (5-20%) ongoing in Q1 2024.  <hr />- Vietnamese developers face migration risks due to residency issues.  <hr />- AI dominates discussions: startups showcase innovations; government addresses AI challenges; no major LLM development reported yet.  <hr />- Cost of living and education straining families; platform usage (Binance, AWS) increasing but LLM adoption limited.  <hr />- Notable leader: Nam Nguyen of OplaCRM sharing insights.  <hr /><hr />AI landscape:  <hr />- Growth driven by big tech; startups mainly applying AI tech.  <hr />- SEA AI market to grow 35% annually, reaching $6B by 2028; widespread in software, data, fraud detection, management.  <hr />- Low enterprise AI adoption (15%), mostly in digital transformation.  <hr />- Challenges include data security, privacy, localmodel creation, high costs, ethics & governance concerns.  <hr /><hr />Overall:  <hr />- Southeast Asian tech market remains tough: layoffs, high living costs in Singapore, job insecurity, AI’s rising role heightening automation fears.  <hr />- Future: tech innovations will continue shaping the ecosystem; event reflections = achievement, insights, connections, clear trends.  <hr /><hr />Outcome:  <hr />- Post-event, a sense of achievement, awareness of current and future SEA tech trends, and valuable network connections.

299.title: Memo Publication Workflow
299.description: This guide will help you step-by-step create content and publish on memo.
299.spr_content: - Determine the writing field: blockchain, communication, design, engineering, market, security, or writing. Use `playground` directory.  <hr />- If unsure, contact support on Discord for guidance.  <hr />- Set up local environment: follow specific [setup guide](https://memo.d.foundation/playground/01_literature/how-to-set-up-environment-for-editing-memo/).  <hr />- Learn to write, submit, publish via [instructions].  <hr />- Ensure articles contain: title, description, author, date, tags (mandatory fields).  <hr />- Name files in kebab case, e.g., `how-to-write-a-memo.md`.  <hr />- Verify links locally before publishing.  <hr />- Upload images to `assets` folder; reference them in the article.  <hr />- Follow image and screenshot guidelines: refer to specific [guides].  <hr />- Review process: notify reviewer if draft or final version.  <hr />- Content review: experts like @tom (engineering), @nikki (communication).  <hr />- Format/Design review: @anna; upload screenshot and request feedback.  <hr />- Collect and implement feedback per lifecycle instructions.

300.title: State, Explain, Link - An all-purpose writing technique
300.description: State, explain, link is a basic style for organizing and explaining ideas in an understandable way. This technique may have many names, but in essence it is a way to organize paragraphs in roughly 3 sentences or more.
300.spr_content: - The Introduction State, Explain, Link technique is a basic organizational method for clarity and understanding, often called by various names.<hr />- It structures paragraphs with a minimum of three sentences: State (broad overview), Explain (detailed elaboration), and Link (relation or example).<hr />- "State" introduces the main idea briefly, providing the paragraph’s coverage or scope.<hr />- "Explain" develops the idea in depth, offering details, reasoning, or clarification.<hr />- "Link" connects to related ideas, examples, or broader context, reinforcing or illustrating the point.<hr />- Originally designed for concise paragraph writing, this style permeates many fields—theses, diagrams, etc.—due to its semantic clarity.<hr />- Operationally, any broad statement can be broken into detailed points supported by examples via State, Explain, and Link.<hr />- "State" is a quick, broad statement—marked in blue—setting the topic.<hr />- "Explain" provides elaboration—orange—adding depth and understanding.<hr />- "Link" ties the concept to practical examples or related ideas—purple—creating relational context.<hr />- Example: Six Sigma in quality assurance begins with a broad statement, then explains statistical methods, and links to corporate examples like Motorola and GE.<hr />- Larger topics, like product quality failure impacts, are expanded through layered State, Explain, Link components, illustrating complex cause-effect scenarios (e.g., Samsung Note 7).<hr />- The method's versatility allows for its application in outlines, speeches, and any narrative requiring logical progression.<hr />- It enhances clarity, supporting detailed reasoning and contextual connections within any English-based communication.<hr />- Useful as a foundational framework for outlining ideas, ensuring completeness and coherence during writing or speaking.

301.title: Building a Local Search Engine for Our Memo Website
301.description: Explore how we developed a fully local search engine for our memo website using DuckDB-wasm, Transformers.js, and Alpine.js. Learn about hybrid search techniques, real-time embeddings, and performance optimizations that deliver fast and accurate results without compromising on privacy or requiring server-side processing.
301.spr_content: - Transition from third-party (Algolia, Modal) to fully local search reflects growth, privacy, cost, offline capabilities, customization.<hr />- DuckDB chosen for in-browser SQL, powerful, aligns with trend of embedded analysis, AI, web apps.<hr />- Timing of DuckDB array type and hybrid search post shows evolving tech ecosystem.<hr />- Search combines full-text (BM25) and semantic (embeddings cosine similarity) to improve relevance.<hr />- Filters using syntax (`author:`, `tag:`, `title:`) enable precise querying.<hr />- Real-time query embeddings generated in-browser via Transformers.js; enables instant semantic understanding.<hr />- Caching mechanisms optimize load times, reduce repeated data fetches.<hr />- UI built with Alpine.js ensures responsiveness, immediate feedback.<hr />- Indexing uses FTS and HNSW for rapid retrieval, balancing speed and accuracy.<hr />- Debouncing search input mitigates unnecessary queries, enhances performance.<hr />- Lazy loading and selective heavy tasks (like embeddings) improve mobile performance.<hr />- Challenges: balancing accuracy and speed; tackled with hybrid search, indexing, caching.<hr />- Future: persistent search state across navigation; SPA architecture, global state, browser history.<hr />- Further speed: progressive loading, WebAssembly, query optimization, web workers.<hr />- Considering server-side: static site generation, Elixir search engine, hybrid models for better SEO.<hr />- Overall: modern tech stack, client-side processing, privacy-first, no server dependency, fast, accurate, adaptable.<hr />- Conceptually, the system exemplifies end-user control, local intelligence, and seamless integration of AI and search.

302.title: How to set up environment to edit memo
302.description: This is a guide on how to setup your environment and settings to push content to our notes website, memo.d.foundation.
302.spr_content: - SSH key is a secure authentication method with public and private keys.<hr />- Public key is shared publicly, such as on GitHub.<hr />- Private key remains secret on your Mac.<hr />- During SSH connection, server verifies identity via fingerprint comparison.<hr />- Server checks fingerprint of your public key against its record.<hr />- Successful verification and unlock (passphrase) establish a secure connection.<hr />- To generate SSH keys: create key pair, save private key locally, submit public key to GitHub.<hr />- Instructions for SSH key generation are available via provided link.<hr />- Install Visual Studio Code from the official website.<hr />- Open terminal in VSCode with `Control + ~`.<hr />- Install Devbox using `curl -fsSL https://get.jetpack.io/devbox | bash`.<hr />- Pull GitHub repo by method 1 (terminal) or method 2 (VSCode interface).<hr />- Method 1 steps: run `xcode-select`, install git-credential-manager, configure user email and name, clone repository.<hr />- Method 2: connect VSCode with GitHub, then clone via interface search.<hr />- Open cloned repo, run submodule update commands sequentially.<hr />- Create "content" folder inside `node.d.foundation`.<hr />- Start dev environment with `devbox shell`, then run `make watch-run` to build site.<hr />- Preview site via localhost link, accessible by `Cmd + click`.<hr />- If errors occur, rerun `devbox shell` and `make watch-run`.

303.title: Labs - New Member Onboarding
303.description: New members joining our Labs team can be recommended either personally by an existing team member or through a development plan survey. Once onboarded, each new member is paired with a mentor who provides guidance on our operational practices within the team, specifically in relation to a chosen research topic. The initial probation period for new members is set to one month.
303.spr_content: New members join Labs via personal recommendation or development survey.  <hr />Onboarding pairs each new member with a mentor focused on operational practices and a research topic.  <hr />Probation period lasts one month.  <hr />During probation, two main deliverables are expected:  <hr />— An assessment report (including use-case and cost-benefit analysis), due within two weeks.  <hr />— A demonstration for the Labs team, prepared within one week.  <hr />Evaluation occurs through review templates or Chad diagram.

304.title: Labs Team
304.description: This is our Labs team homepage, where we list out the latest advances in our engineering team, our publications, events & workshops, as well as frequently asked questions on who and what team labs are.
304.spr_content: Labs Team 2023-11-23 SPR Conceptual Map<hr /><hr />Labs Team identity:<hr />- United by passion for emerging technologies.<hr />- Diverse backgrounds, unified goal: explore, understand, and leverage innovations.<hr />- Mission: enhance lives, shape a better future through tech.<hr /><hr />Operations:<hr />- Collaborative insight exchange; cross-functional partnerships.<hr />- Hands-on assessments; iterative assumption reexamination.<hr />- Focus on practicality, futurity, and breakthrough potential.<hr />- Workflow documented in detailed guides (e.g., Labs x Consulting Workflow).<hr /><hr />Research focus:<hr />- Trend analysis; technology scanning.<hr />- Identification of transformative innovations.<hr />- Roadmap alignment (e.g., Labs Roadmap Nov 23).<hr /><hr />Membership dynamics:<hr />- Mostly via recommendations; value community endorsement.<hr />- External enthusiasts encouraged via Discord engagement.<hr />- Mentorship program: one-month deep dive, culminating in tech report and demo.<hr />- Onboarding detailed in governance docs.<hr /><hr />Proposal process:<hr />- Formal proposals by internal teams.<hr />- External contributions via Discord insights.<hr />- Rewards: ICY tokens proportional to impact.<hr />- Recognition system: contribution valuation in knowledge, innovation.<hr />- R&D efforts influence performance metrics; growth opportunities.<hr /><hr />Events:<hr />- Weekly catchups: agenda prep, research summaries, tech sharing.<hr />- Demonstrations (e.g., DuckDB): data processing, analytics, applied examples.<hr />- Past events include detailed tech showcases and progress reports.<hr /><hr />Technology and presentation:<hr />- Example: DuckDB—modern analytics engine for scalable, fast data analysis.<hr />- Use cases exemplified: NYC taxi data, AML transaction aggregation.<hr />- Visual aids: illustrative images showing process flow and technical steps.<hr /><hr />Connections:<hr />- Core concept: active priming of LLMs via structured, succinct, associative cues.<hr />- Goal: Enable models to access and utilize rich latent knowledge efficiently.<hr />- Implication: SPR enhances understanding, reasoning, and contextual recall in advanced NLP tasks.

305.title: Pure CSS Parallax
305.description: This article demonstrates how to use CSS transforms, perspective and some scaling trickery to create a pure CSS parallax scrolling website.
305.spr_content: - CSS transforms, perspective, and scaling create a CSS-only parallax scrolling effect.<hr />- Pure CSS avoids performance issues linked to JavaScript, such as reflows and paints triggered by scroll event handlers.<hr />- CSS-based parallax leverages hardware acceleration for smoother performance and better responsiveness.<hr />- Markup structure involves a container `.parallax` with nested `.layer` elements representing different depths.<hr />- CSS styles for `.parallax` set `perspective: 1px`, `height: 100vh`, and overflow-y: auto, establishing a fixed 3D viewpoint.<hr />- `.layer` elements are absolutely positioned within `.parallax`, with `translateZ()` to set depth (Z-offset).<hr />- Layers farther away (more negative `translateZ`) scroll more slowly, creating depth illusion.<hr />- Using `transform: translateZ()`, layers simulate distance; closer layers move faster.<hr />- Combining `translateZ()` with `scale()` can correct size perspective, maintaining original dimensions.<hr />- `scale = 1 + (translateZ * -1) / perspective`; adjusts apparent size.<hr />- Grouping layers in `.group` with `transform-style: preserve-3d` maintains 3D positioning.<hr />- Content overflow management: avoid `overflow: hidden` on groups; use `z-index` creatively for layer stacking.<hr />- Debugging involves applying a `translate3d()` and `rotateY()` transform to position groups in 3D space for visualization.<hr />- Multi-section sites group layers; nested `.group` elements enable complex layered effects.<hr />- Depth correction prevents distant layers from appearing unnaturally small by applying scale transforms.<hr />- Pure CSS parallax offers straightforward, hardware-accelerated, scalable design with minimal complexity.

306.title: CSS Container Queries
306.description: Container Queries is a CSS feature that allows us to style elements based on the size of a container.
306.spr_content: Container Queries introduced in Chrome 105, address media query limitations by enabling styling based on container size rather than viewport.  <hr />Media queries only support page-wide responsiveness, not component-specific adjustments.  <hr />Container queries operate by assigning a container-type—such as inline-size or block-size—to an element, making it a reference point for queries.  <hr />Using `@container`, styles can be conditionally applied when container dimensions meet specified criteria, e.g., min-width.  <hr />Containers can be named with `container-name`, allowing targeted queries to specific containers.  <hr />Syntax variations include `container: name / type` shorthand for named containers.  <hr />Supported in Chrome 105+, Safari 15+, Edge 105+, with polyfills available for broader compatibility.  <hr />This development enables true component responsiveness within CSS, advancing modular design capabilities.

307.title: CSS in JS
307.description: CSS-in-JS is a styling technique where Javascript is used to style the component.
307.spr_content: CSS-in-JS styled as JavaScript code embeds styling within components, leveraging libraries like emotion, styled-components, and JSS to address CSS limitations: lack of dynamism, poor scoping, and portability.  <hr />Benefits include:  <hr />- Scoped styles prevent unintended global effects, isolating component styles.  <hr />- Auto-generated unique class selectors mitigate naming conflicts, removing the need for manual naming.  <hr />- JavaScript's logic provides dynamic styling: conditionals, variables, state-based styles, loops.  <hr />- Dead code elimination loads only styles for active components, optimizing payload.  <hr />- Developer ergonomics improve by colocating styles with components, simplifying styling workflows, and reducing global scope anxiety.  <hr /><hr />Disadvantages include:  <hr />- Runtime CSS generation incurs overhead; some libraries extract CSS at build time (e.g., linaria) but face trade-offs.  <hr />- Steep learning curve: familiarity with component architectures and new syntaxes is necessary, potentially slowing initial development.  <hr />- Generated class names are often unreadable, complicating debugging, despite attempts at more meaningful naming in development mode.  <hr />- Additional library increases bundle size, potentially affecting page load performance.  <hr /><hr />Overall, CSS-in-JS enhances modularity and dynamic styling but introduces runtime overhead, complexity, and potential performance costs.

308.title: MPA, SPA and Partial Hydration
308.description: MPA, SPA and Partial Hydration are three different approaches to building web applications.
308.spr_content: - Twitter discussions highlight "Partial Hydration" and "MPA" in modern web debates.  <hr />- MPA: Multi-page application, traditional static page reloads; contrasts with SPA.  <hr />- SPA: Single-page app; dynamic, app-like navigation; uses frameworks like React, Vue, Svelte.  <hr />- SPA benefits: smooth navigation, preloading, background fetching; adopted by Facebook, Twitter, Notion.  <hr />- SPA drawbacks: large initial JavaScript bundles cause slow load and delayed content visibility (high TTI, LCP).  <hr />- Rendering models: SSR (Server Side Rendering) improves load times and SEO by sending pre-rendered HTML.  <hr />- Hydration: React process converting static HTML into interactive components; involves `renderToString` + `hydrate`.  <hr />- Full hydration: all components load interactively; leads to hydration waste when static content doesn't need interaction.  <hr />- Partial hydration: only interactive components are hydrated; reduces JavaScript payload and delays; supported by Astro, Marko.  <hr />- Implementing partial hydration in React from scratch requires complex setup and debugging.  <hr />- Choice depends on site type:  <hr />  - SPA: complex, interactive apps (dashboards, portals).  <hr />  - MPA or partial hydration: static sites, marketing pages, landing pages with minimal interactivity.  <hr />- Static generators like Astro support partial hydration natively; Gatsby and react-static currently do not.  <hr />- For React MPAs: SSR without full hydration improves performance; interactivity limited but faster load.

309.title: An Introduction to Atomic CSS
309.description: This article provides an overview of Atomic CSS, including its definition, variations, purposes, and how it compares to other CSS approaches.
309.spr_content: - Atomic CSS favors small, single-purpose classes based on visual functions.<hr />- Also known as Functional CSS or CSS utilities.<hr />- Utility classes resemble simple styling snippets, e.g., `.m-0 { margin: 0; }`.<hr />- Examples include frameworks like Tailwind, Windi CSS, Tachyons.<hr />- UI libraries such as Bootstrap and Chakra UI incorporate CSS utilities.<hr />- Variations:<hr />  - Static: predefined, unit-based design system for spacing, color, typography (e.g., `.m-4 { margin: 1rem; }`).<hr />    - Advantages: simple, immutable, self-explanatory.<hr />  - Programmatic: generated during build via tools, e.g., with class names like `Bgc(#0280ae)` producing specific styles.<hr />    - Advantages: easy, optimized, flexible, resembles inline styles.<hr />- Purposes:<hr />  - Simplifies styling; classes are immutable and straightforward.<hr />  - Ensures consistency; unit-based scaling (e.g., `m-4`, `m-8`) facilitates predictable design adjustments.<hr />  - Enhances reusability; component-based styling (e.g., React) simplifies global style updates.<hr />  - Enables abstraction: utility classes encapsulate styles for reuse and maintenance.<hr />  - Extends tooling possibilities: integrates with Sass, PostCSS, Autoprefixer.<hr />  - Promotes brevity: concise class names (`mt-0`, `flex`) reduce verbosity.<hr />  - Offers lower specificity than inline styles, allowing better override management.<hr />  - Supports capabilities inline styles lack:<hr />    - Media queries, pseudo-selectors, CSS animations, and conditional styling.<hr />- Atomic CSS is not all-encompassing; certain complex or runtime-dependent styles may require other approaches.<hr />- Coexists with other CSS methods; can serve as a foundational layer with global defaults.<hr />- Reusability achieved through component composition and CSS-in-JS techniques.<hr />- Abstraction allows centralized style updates, reducing manual edits.<hr />- Not a replacement for inline styles but an enhancement for scalable, maintainable CSS architecture.<hr />- Overall, Atomic CSS promotes clarity, consistency, and tooling-enhanced efficiency in styling workflows.

310.title: Webassembly
310.description: WebAssembly (abbreviated *Wasm*) was launched in 2017 as a low-level assembly-like language with a compact binary format, so it’s fast to load, execute, and run with near-native performance.
310.spr_content: - WebAssembly (Wasm) launched in 2017 as a low-level, assembly-like language with a compact binary format.  <hr />- Wasm enables fast load, execute, near-native performance.  <hr />- Designed as a portable target for compiling high-level languages (C/C++/Rust).  <hr />- Developers compile high-level languages into WebAssembly, not write WebAssembly directly.  <hr />- It facilitates deployment on the web for client and server applications.  <hr />- JavaScript interprets code at runtime, using dynamic variables, requiring monitoring for type inference.  <hr />- JavaScript engine monitors and converts variables to machine code once types are known.  <hr />- WebAssembly is pre-compiled into binary format, enabling instant, efficient compilation to machine code in browsers.  <hr />- No run-time interpretation needed for Wasm, as variable types are known beforehand.  <hr />- Goals: near-native speed, efficiency, portability across platforms.  <hr />- Despite being low-level, WebAssembly has a human-readable text format for debugging and understanding.  <hr />- WebAssembly runs in a sandboxed, secure environment, enforcing browser policies and same-origin rules.  <hr />- Designed to harmonize with web standards, maintaining backward compatibility.  <hr />- Use cases include media editing, peer-to-peer apps, gaming, streaming, AR/VR, scientific visualization, developer tools, and enterprise fat clients.  <hr />- Resources: Mozilla MDN, official WebAssembly site, practical guides, industry insights.

311.title: Parse, don't validate in TypeScript
311.description: The "parse, don't validate" approach is about processing incoming data and failing in a controlled manner if parsing fails.
311.spr_content: - "Parse, don't validate" emphasizes handling data at the edges via parsing, not validation, to ensure controlled failure and type safety.  <hr />- Parsing analyzes strings or data structures per formal grammar/schema, conforming to rules of syntax.  <hr />- Schema and type should be unified; parsing aligns data with schemas/types simultaneously, avoiding divergence.  <hr />- Parsing makes explicit handling of each input, reducing risks of spreading harmful data, increasing security and correctness.  <hr />- Validation often occurs within parsing but is not the primary goal; parsing ensures data fits schema/type exactly.  <hr />- Example in TypeScript with Yup illustrates schema validation but leaves data as `any`/`unknown`, requiring manual typecasting.  <hr />- Manual typecasting risks mismatch: schema and type definitions may drift apart, breaching safety.  <hr />- Using custom type guards with Yup schema improves safety: they introspect and narrow types at runtime.  <hr />- A parser function with explicit type guards returns strongly-typed objects or errors, enforced by TypeScript’s type system.  <hr />- This approach promotes business logic robustness: data is parsed into precise types before use, reducing runtime errors.  <hr />- Type aliases (e.g., PositiveInteger, Email) sharpen type safety beyond primitive types, guiding data handling.  <hr />- TypeScript's type system verifies parser correctness; parser functions returning `UserType | Error` benefit from compile-time checks.  <hr />- Central idea: process incoming data at the system boundary using parsing to ensure correctness, type safety, and simplify downstream logic.

312.file_path: playground/topics/frontend/Build polymorphic React components with Typescript.md
312.title: Build polymorphic React components with Typescript
312.description: This article provides a step-by-step guide on how to build polymorphic React components with Typescript, covering the necessary concepts and techniques to create flexible and reusable components.
312.spr_content:
- LLMs encode knowledge as latent space, activatable via priming.
- React components can be polymorphic, rendering different tags based on `as`.
- Basic `as` is `any`, allowing invalid tags, breaking type safety.
- Using `React.ElementType` constrains `as` to valid React component types (HTML tags or components).
- Extracting component prop types with `React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef` enables passing correct HTML attributes.
- Combining with children and other props yields type-safe flexible components.
- Default generic parameter `C = 'p'` ensures compilers enforce valid default tag `p`.
- Omitting `as` defaults render as `

`, with type safety for props.

- Custom internal props (`color`, `size`) should be excluded from HTML attributes via `Omit` to prevent conflicts or errors.
- To reuse for other components, extract `as?` into an `AsProp` type, and define a general `PolymorphicComponentProps< C, P >`.
- Support for `ref` requires using `React.ComponentPropsWithRef` and forwarding refs via `React.forwardRef`.
- Introduce `PolymorphicRef` to type refs according to the element type.
- Wrap component with `React.forwardRef` with generic params to keep type safety for refs.
- Use helper types (`PolymorphicComponentProps`, `PolymorphicRef`, `PolymorphicComponentPropsWithRef`) for reusable, strongly-typed polymorphic components.
- Final pattern: define component with types parameterized over `C` extends `React.ElementType`, defaulting to `p` or `button`, with correct props, ref, and usage examples.
- Achieves fully type-safe, reusable polymorphic components supporting dynamic tags, attributes, internal props, and ref forwarding.

313.title: HSL Color
313.description: HSL is the answer to resolving all of the painful points of Hexadecimal color codes.
313.spr_content: - Hexadecimal color codes are hard to write, adjust, and memorize; often require third-party tools.  <hr />- HSL is an alternative color model based on hue, saturation, and lightness, derived from the RGB wheel.  <hr />- Hue corresponds to angle on the color wheel (red at 0/360°, green at 120°, blue at 240°); values wrap with modulus 360.  <hr />- Saturation ranges from 0% (grayscale) to 100% (full color).  <hr />- Lightness ranges from 0% (black) to 100% (white), with 50% being standard/light mid-tone.  <hr />- HSL facilitates easy creation of darker or lighter shades by adjusting lightness.  <hr />- Example: for UI components like buttons, HSL enables simple dynamic adjustments for hover effects.  <hr />- HSL allows easy generation of color palettes through lightness variation, ensuring visual consistency.  <hr />- Transparency (HSLa) adds an alpha channel (0 to 1), with 0 fully transparent and 1 fully opaque.  <hr />- HSLa syntax: `hsla(hue, saturation, lightness, alpha)`.  <hr />- HSL reduces complexity in color coding, enhances programmatic control, and improves maintainability.  <hr />- References affirm HSL’s benefits for CSS color management and design workflow integration.

314.title: Why Virtual DOM is fast?
314.description: React and Vue, two popular front-end frameworks, both use Virtual DOM to improve page rendering efficiency. Understanding the concept of Virtual DOM sheds light on an important aspect of performance optimization on the client side.
314.spr_content: Virtual DOM as a JavaScript object map to real DOM enhances rendering efficiency through minimal actual DOM interactions. React's process: generate new Virtual DOM, diff with previous, create diff object, batch update real DOM, reduces frequency of costly DOM manipulations. Comparing initial and new Virtual DOM isolates necessary changes, enabling optimized, grouped updates. The diffing process, though slower than direct DOM access, prevents redundant and excessive DOM operations, which are computationally expensive due to complex algorithms.
