Virtual DOM isn't fast per se; it’s comparatively slow but advantageous over unnecessary DOM manipulations, aligning with performance optimization goals by reducing update.calls and computations.

315.title: Render optimization in data-fetching libraries
315.description: Data-fetching libraries are software tools or frameworks that can help improve the performance and scalability of your application by handling network requests and data processing more efficiently.
315.spr_content: - Data-fetching libraries optimize network requests and data processing for performance and scalability.  <hr />- They address React rendering issues by minimizing unnecessary re-renders when data remains unchanged.  <hr />- Caching strategies, such as unique keys and stale-while-revalidate, reduce network requests and provide quick responses from cache.  <hr />- Requests trigger component updates via three stateful values: data, error, fetching.  <hr />- The `fetching` flag indicates in-flight requests; unnecessary if no loading indicator is needed, can cause unwanted re-renders.  <hr />- Destructuring hook responses (`const { data, error } = useRequest`) isolates relevant properties and avoids unwanted re-rendering.  <hr />- Structural sharing compares previous and new data states, reusing unchanged parts to optimize rendering, especially with partial updates.  <hr />- For React Query, ensure data maintains referential identity across updates to leverage structural sharing effectively.  <hr />- Large datasets may diminish structural sharing benefits, requiring careful use.  <hr />- References include detailed guides on React Query, SWR, and Next.js data-fetching optimizations.

316.title: Window and iframe communication
316.description: When working with web development, communicating between a main window and an embedded iframe is often necessary for various tasks, such as content creation or widget implementation. This communication can occur between windows and iframes with the same origin or across different origins.
316.spr_content: - Web development often requires communication between main window and embedded iframe for content updates or widget interaction.  <hr />- Same origin: URLs sharing protocol, domain, and port; e.g., `http://example.com` and `http://example.com/page`.  <hr />- Different origin: URLs with differing protocol, domain, or port; e.g., `https://example.com` vs. `http://example.com`, or `http://example.com` vs. `http://example.org`.  <hr />- Same origin access grants full control: read/write iframe content, variables, document DOM.  <hr />- Cross origin access is restricted; security policy enforces isolation.  <hr />- Parent window controls iframe via `contentWindow` or `contentDocument` if same origin.  <hr />- Example: `iframe.contentDocument.body.prepend('Hello')`, works only on same origin.  <hr />- Use cases for same origin: content builders requiring CSS and layout control, responsive design, isolated content editing.  <hr />- Cross origin communication uses `postMessage` API, bypassing same-origin restrictions.  <hr />- Both parent and iframe can send messages: parent uses `iframe.contentWindow.postMessage()`, iframe uses `window.parent.postMessage()`.  <hr />- Receiving side listens with `window.addEventListener('message')` and checks `event.origin`.  <hr />- Example: iframe posts message with `postMessage('message', '*')`, listening script handles with origin verification.  <hr />- Cross origin messaging essential for embedded widgets like chatboxes, third-party integrations.  <hr />- Summary: same origin uses `contentWindow`; cross origin uses `postMessage` with `message` event listener.  <hr />- Enabling seamless iframe interaction, respecting security boundaries, for varied web app integrations.

317.title: Why Micro Frontend
317.description: As web applications become more complex and feature-rich, traditional frontend architectures such as monolithic will become harder to maintain, scale, and evolve. Micro-frontend is an emerging front-end architecture that aims to address these challenges by breaking down the front-end into small, independent and reusable modules.
317.spr_content: - Web applications are becoming increasingly complex, demanding scalable and maintainable front-end architectures.  <hr />- Traditional monolithic frontends integrate all features into a single codebase, challenging to scale, update, and maintain as systems grow.  <hr />- Micro-frontend architecture decomposes the frontend into small, independent, reusable modules, each responsible for specific functionalities.  <hr />- Analogous to microservices in backend, micro-frontends enable independent development, testing, deployment, and scaling of UI components.  <hr />- Monolithic approach bundles all code, leading to slow deployments, difficulty managing dependencies, and limited flexibility.  <hr />- Micro-frontend splits vertical slices of front-end work, reducing coupling and facilitating autonomous team ownership.  <hr />- Micro-frontends are assembled within a container or shell application, orchestrating independent modules into a cohesive user experience.  <hr />- Benefits include improved scalability via independent module deployment.  <hr />- Enhanced flexibility allows using heterogeneous frameworks, technologies, and languages per module, promoting technology diversity.  <hr />- Faster development cycles stem from parallel work of autonomous teams, enabling rapid deployment and iteration.  <hr />- Maintainability benefits from dedicated ownership, easier issue isolation, and incremental updates or replacements of individual modules.  <hr />- Challenges involve increased architecture complexity, requiring management of cross-micro-frontend interactions, routing, and dependencies.  <hr />- Performance overhead may increase due to multiple network requests, scripts, and styles for each micro-frontend.  <hr />- Compatibility challenges arise across browsers and devices due to varied dependencies and technology stacks.  <hr />- Security concerns necessitate isolation, sandboxing, and security policies to reduce attack surfaces.  <hr />- Inter-module communication needs careful design to prevent data flow issues, synchronization problems, and unintended side effects.  <hr />- Deployment infrastructure and tooling must adapt to support multiple independent modules, build pipelines, and versioning strategies.  <hr />- Micro-frontend design principles include: Single Responsibility to keep modules focused; Loose Coupling for independence; Composability for reassembly; Isolation to prevent conflicts; Standardization to ensure consistency; Testing for reliability.  <hr />- Adopting micro-frontend architectures supports scalability, flexibility, faster releases, and maintainability, beneficial for enterprise-level applications.  <hr />- Not a universal solution; traditional monoliths may still suffice for smaller or less complex projects.  <hr />- Notable adopters include AWS, IKEA, and DAZN, illustrating industry interest and potential.  <hr />- Proper implementation relies on balancing modular benefits against added complexity, tooling, and performance considerations.

318.file_path: playground/topics/frontend/URL formats for sharing via social networks.md
318.title: URL formats for sharing via social networks
318.description: Each social network has its own unique way of handling URLs, and understanding the correct formatting can make a significant difference in the visibility and engagement of your shared content.
318.spr_content: - Social platforms facilitate rapid URL sharing to large audiences.  <hr />- Each platform has a distinct URL format requiring specific syntax.  <hr />- Facebook sharing uses a straightforward URL with `https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=${url}`.  <hr />- Facebook Messenger sharing involves an app ID, sharing dialog, and redirect, formatted as `https://www.facebook.com/dialog/send?app_id=${appId}&display=popup&link=${url}&redirect_uri=${url}`.  <hr />- Facebook Messenger sharing requires creating a Facebook app, obtaining an app ID, per Facebook developer documentation.  <hr />- Zalo, popular in Vietnam, shares URLs by encoding a JSON object containing `"url"` into base64, then appending to `https://button-share.zalo.me/share_external?d=${encodedString}`.  <hr />- Other social networks follow similar formats:  <hr />  - LinkedIn: `https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=${url}`  <hr />  - Twitter: `http://twitter.com/share?url=${url}`  <hr />  - Telegram: `https://telegram.me/share/?url=${url}`  <hr />  - Reddit: `https://www.reddit.com/submit?url=${url}&title=${title}`  <hr />- Proper URL formatting enhances content visibility and engagement across platforms.  <hr />- Understanding and implementing each platform's sharing protocol is crucial for effective content distribution.

319.title: WAI-ARIA
319.description: WAI-ARIA is a technology that can help with the problems of modern websites and applications containing huge amounts of dynamic content and complex components with no semantics to describe what they mean.
319.spr_content: - Modern websites/apps contain dynamic, complex, non-semantic components, hindering assistive tech such as screen readers, TTS, magnifiers.<hr />- Without semantics, assistive tools cannot interpret or convey content meaningfully.<hr />- WAI-ARIA offers roles, states, properties to add semantic meaning to non-semantic HTML elements, improving accessibility.<hr />- Roles define "what" an element does (e.g., button, navigation, banner), supplementing missing semantics.<hr />- Properties represent static or less frequently changing data (e.g., aria-label, aria-required, aria-describedby) furnishing contextual info.<hr />- States capture dynamic statuses (e.g., aria-pressed, aria-expanded, aria-selected) that change during interaction.<hr />- Using roles, states, and properties, WAI-ARIA enhances assistive tech's understanding without altering component behavior.<hr />- WAI-ARIA is especially useful for defining regions, indicating live updates, supporting keyboard navigation, and making complex UI components accessible.<hr />- Implemented attributes are exposed via browser accessibility APIs, enabling assistive technology to improve user interaction.<hr />- WAI-ARIA bridges the gap where HTML semantics fall short, especially in modern, richly interactive interfaces.<hr />- Proper usage facilitates inclusive web design, ensuring users with disabilities can navigate, understand, and interact effectively.

320.title: Variable Fonts
320.description: Variable fonts are a font format that allows for a single font file to contain multiple variations of a typeface.
320.spr_content: - Variable fonts, also known as OpenType Font Variations, store multiple font variations in a single file.  <hr />- Variations include weight, width, slant, optical size, and more, grouped into "axes of variation."  <hr />- Each axis defines a range of values; combining these axes creates unique styles.  <hr />- Axes of variation correspond to adjustable font properties; for example, weight from Thin to Bold.  <hr />- Design intent influences how axes behave; font creators can specify how combinations affect appearance and spacing.  <hr />- Benefits of variable fonts include reduced file size, faster load times, and enhanced flexibility for customization.  <hr />- They enable creative experimentation, allowing designers to craft distinct, dynamic typography.  <hr />- Practical use involves loading them via `@font-face` with format and tech hints for compatibility.  <hr />- To manipulate variations, CSS `font-variation-settings` specify axis tags (lowercase for registered, uppercase for custom) and values.  <hr />- Standard registered axes include `wght` (weight), `wdth` (width), `opsz` (optical size), `slnt` (slant), `ital` (italics).  <hr />- Custom axes depend on font design, expanding potential variation parameters.  <hr />- Variations are dependent on font design and developer documentation for correct use.  <hr />- Examples and tools on websites like Google Fonts, VariableFonts.io, and Axis-Praxis facilitate experimentation and understanding.

321.title: Micro Frontends Microservices For Frontend Development
321.description: Micro Frontends is an architectural style where independently deliverable frontend applications are composed into a greater whole.
321.spr_content: Micro-frontend: Architectural style decomposing a frontend into independently deployable modules combined into a cohesive app.<hr /><hr />Benefits:<hr />- Small, cohesive, maintainable codebases.<hr />- Decoupled, autonomous teams enable scalability.<hr />- Incremental upgrades, updates, rewrites.<hr />- Easier long-term maintenance and testing.<hr /><hr />Build-time integration:<hr />- Publish micro frontends as packages.<hr />- Container includes dependencies.<hr />- Re-compilation/release needed for any change.<hr /><hr />Run-time via iframes:<hr />- Use iframes to embed micro frontends.<hr />- Routing based on URL.<hr />- Challenges: responsiveness, integration, deep-linking.<hr /><hr />Run-time via JavaScript:<hr />- Include micro frontends with `<script>`.<hr />- Each exposes global entry functions.<hr />- Container calls functions based on route.<hr /><hr />Run-time via Web Components:<hr />- Define micro frontends as custom elements.<hr />- Instantiate based on route.<hr />- No server-side rendering support.<hr />- Browser support varies.<hr /><hr />Cross-application communication:<hr />- Custom events.<hr />- Routing events.<hr /><hr />Server-side rendering:<hr />- Use Server Side Includes.<hr />- Complex and limited.<hr /><hr />Trade-offs:<hr />- Dependency duplication increases payload.<hr />- Impacts performance.<hr />- Steep learning curve.<hr />- Suitable for medium/large scale projects.<hr /><hr />References:<hr />- Micro-frontends.org<hr />- Martin Fowler’s article<hr />- Tom Soderlund’s paper<hr />- Open-source resources and showcases

322.title: ViteJS native modules
322.description: ViteJS takes full advantage of the availability of native ES modules in the browser and the rise of JavaScript tools written in compile-to-native languages by introducing pre-bundles dependancies using esbuild.
322.spr_content: - Prior to native ES modules support in browsers, JavaScript lacked a standardized, modular development mechanism; this gap led to the rise of bundlers like Webpack, Rollup, Parcel for a better development experience.  <hr />- Increasing project module counts from hundreds to thousands caused significant performance bottlenecks in JavaScript tooling.  <hr />- Vite leverages native ES modules and the rise of compile-to-native tools (like esbuild) to enhance speed; esbuild written in Go is 10-100x faster than JavaScript bundlers.  <hr />- Traditional bundle-based dev servers (Webpack) compile all source code into a single JavaScript bundle on the server-side; any change requires rebuilding the entire bundle.  <hr />- Vite's native ESM dev server delays module bundling until the browser requests them, improving startup and update times by using actual module boundaries and browser's native module handling.  <hr />- When updating code, bundle-based systems rebuild whole bundles; this scales linearly with app size, slowing development.  <hr />- Vite employs Hot Module Replacement (HMR) with native ESM, invalidating only the affected module chain, ensuring rapid updates regardless of app size.  <hr />- For production, unbundled ESM is inefficient due to nested imports causing extra network requests; bundling, tree-shaking, lazy-loading, and chunk splitting optimize performance and caching.  <hr />- Despite broad browser support for ESM, production deployment often prefers bundling for efficiency, despite HTTP/2 capabilities.  <hr />- esbuild, while fast and capable for libraries, currently lacks full features like code-splitting and CSS handling necessary for complex app bundling; Rollup remains more suitable for production app bundling.

323.title: From Markup to Pixels - A look inside the DOM, CSSOM, and Render Tree
323.description: A deep dive into the rendering process of a web page, exploring the Document Object Model (DOM), CSS Object Model (CSSOM), and the Render Tree.
323.spr_content: - Web browsers contain a browser engine, which determines displayed content based on received data.<hr />- Major browsers have different engine names: Firefox's Gecko, Chrome's Blink derived from WebKit.<hr />- HTML bytes are read, converted into characters, then parsed into tokens (tags, content).<hr />- Tokens are organized into nodes forming a hierarchical DOM structure.<hr />- CSS linked via `<link>` tags is fetched and parsed into the CSS Object Model (CSSOM).<hr />- The DOM and CSSOM are combined to create a Render Tree, considering styles, inheritance, visibility.<hr />- The layout/reflow step calculates exact positions, dimensions, x/y coordinates, and bounding boxes.<hr />- Reflow occurs after DOM changes: adding/removing elements, resizing window, changing styles.<hr />- The paint step visually renders the elements’ styles, colors, borders, images, again on change.<hr />- Painting is layered; chunks are stored in layers for faster repaint and composite efficiently.<hr />- Compositing divides the page into layers, which are rendered separately and then combined by the compositor thread.<hr />- The Layer Tree guides element layering; the main thread generates it from the layout tree.<hr />- The compositor thread handles layer rendering; large layers are split into tiles processed by raster threads.<hr />- Raster threads render tiles into GPU memory, enabling smooth scrolling and animation.<hr />- These processes involve the main thread, compositor thread, and raster threads working collaboratively for rendering efficiency.

324.title: Parallelism in JavaScript
324.description: Parallelism in JavaScript is a technique to improve the performance of web applications by executing multiple tasks simultaneously.
324.spr_content: Web applications aim for web deployment; JavaScript is the main support language.  <hr />JavaScript's single-threaded design limits heavy tasks like media processing, gaming, data mining.  <hr />Parallelism support becomes a natural need; Web Worker provides initial solutions.  <hr />Web Worker runs in a separate JavaScript thread; doesn't block UI.  <hr />Web Worker operates in a different context; cannot access `document` or `window`.  <hr />Web Worker can use XMLHttpRequest, WebSocket, local storage.  <hr />Two worker types: dedicated (single script) and shared (multiple scripts).  <hr />Communication via message system: `postMessage()` and `onmessage`.  <hr />Data transfer is serialized, meaning copy, causing bottlenecks with large data.  <hr />Sample code: main script sends message; worker responds, illustrating message exchange.  <hr />WebCL bridges JavaScript with OpenCL; enables GPU and multi-core CPU computing in browser.  <hr />No browsers natively support WebCL; relies on add-ons.  <hr />RiverTrail extends JavaScript with OpenCL; runtime translation to hardware commands.  <hr />OpenCL-based frameworks are declining; browser vendor support stalled.  <hr />Current focus shifts to WebAssembly and WebGPU for performance.  <hr />Web Worker remains primary production parallelism solution in browsers.

325.title: Atomic Design Pattern
325.description: Atomic design is a methodology for crafting design systems with five key fundamental building blocks, which, when combined, promote consistency, modularity, and scalability.
325.spr_content: - Atomic design is a methodology for building design systems with five fundamental blocks: atoms, molecules, organisms, templates, and pages.<hr />- It promotes consistency, modularity, and scalability in UI development.<hr />- Atomic design provides flexible, consistent initial designs for frontend engineers.<hr />- It enables a transition from abstract components to concrete implementations.<hr />- Encourages designing systems in a way that favors reuse and prevents piecemeal pattern selection later.<hr />- Fits naturally with component-based architectures like React and Vue.<hr />-Atoms are the basic building blocks, such as HTML tags: input, button, representing raw elements.<hr />- Atoms are often abstract and not standalone useful but serve as references in larger patterns.<hr />- Molecules are groups of atoms combined, e.g., input with label, header with icons and buttons.<hr />- Molecules introduce functional components that feel more complete than atoms alone.<hr />- Organisms are complex sections formed by joining molecules, creating distinct interface segments.<hr />- Organisms represent more elaborate, functional parts of the UI.<hr />- Templates are arrangements of organisms forming layout structures, without real data, only props.<hr />- Templates are wireframes evolving into final layouts, used for client review before finalization.<hr />- Pages are specific instances of templates with real content replacing placeholders.<hr />- Pages depict the final, user-facing view, illustrating actual user experience.<hr />- The folder structure reflects the five levels, allowing flexible organization per project preference.<hr />- References provide additional insight into atomic design principles and practical implementation.

326.title: Singleton Design Pattern in Javascript
326.description: The Singleton design pattern is a design pattern that restricts the instantiation of a class to one object.
326.spr_content: - Global state management has existing solutions like Redux, React Context, Recoil, Mobx.<hr />- For minimalistic, vanilla JavaScript-specific state handling, design patterns can be employed.<hr />- The Singleton pattern ensures only one static class instance exists.<hr />- Singleton provides a shared access point across components/functions.<hr />- Creation of the singleton instance occurs lazily, only when needed.<hr />- The pattern involves a factory function (`createInstance`) returning a new class instance.<hr />- `getInstance` checks if the singleton exists; if not, it creates and returns it.<hr />- Multiple references to the singleton point to the same object, sharing state.<hr />- Example: setting and accessing a `name` property demonstrates shared state.<hr />- Singleton guarantees a single instance, ensuring consistency across usage.<hr />- It only initializes once, optimizing resource use.<hr />- Advantages include enforcing a single global instance and a unified access point.<hr />- Drawbacks involve violation of the Single Responsibility Principle, as singleton may manage multiple concerns.<hr />- Singletons complicate unit testing due to shared state and implicit dependencies.<hr />- Use cases include global configurations, database connections, user profiles.<hr />- Singleton pattern suits scenarios requiring a single point of controlled access, minimal instantiation, and consistent shared state.

327.title: What is PNPM Compare To NPM/Yarn
327.description: PNPM is a package manager for Node.js which stands for “Performant NPM”. It was introduced in 2016, the same year Yarn was released. PNPM is a fast, disk space efficient package manager that supports monorepos. It creates a non-flat `node_modules` by default, so code has no access to arbitrary packages.
327.spr_content: - PNPM stands for "Performant NPM," introduced in 2016, alongside Yarn.  <hr />- Research originated from Next.js package management, exploring benefits for larger projects.  <hr />- PNPM is a Node.js package manager emphasizing speed, disk efficiency, and monorepo support.  <hr />- It creates a non-flat node_modules structure, avoiding access to arbitrary packages, differing from NPM/Yarn.  <hr />- Installation involves three stages: dependency resolution, directory layout calculation, and linking via hard links from a central store.  <hr />- Uses a content-addressable store, ensuring each package version is stored once, reducing disk space.  <hr />- Links packages from the store to project node_modules via symlinks/hard links, sharing dependencies across projects.  <hr />- Bypasses flattening the dependency tree, maintaining a nested symlinked structure to solve deep dependency issues.  <hr />- This nested structure prevents deep hierarchies, improves clarity, and reduces duplication in large projects.  <hr />- Disadvantages include potential slower first-time installs and compatibility issues with build tools like Webpack.  <hr />- PNPM’s symlinked node_modules can pose access issues on Windows or restricted environments.  <hr />- Its nested dependency trees may cause conflicts with outdated or incompatible packages.  <hr />- Widely adopted by large companies, demonstrating practical reliability and scalability.  <hr />- Overall, PNPM offers space savings and faster installs over NPM/Yarn, especially beneficial for monorepos and large projects, but with some compatibility considerations.

328.title: Intro to IndexedDB
328.description: IndexedDB is a low-level API for client-side storage like localStorage and cookies. But this built-in non-relational database is much more powerful than those 2 counterparts.
328.spr_content: - IndexedDB is a low-level, client-side storage API, more powerful than localStorage and cookies.  <hr />- Suitable for offline applications requiring persistent, structured, large-volume data storage.  <hr />- Stores key-value pairs, including complex objects, asynchronously, supporting transactions for reliability, without SQL.  <hr />- Enforces same-origin policy: domain-restricted data access.  <hr />- Core components:  <hr />  - Database: contains object stores, identified by name and version.  <hr />  - Object store: similar to relational tables; unique within database; holds data.  <hr />  - Transaction: atomic operations on object stores; all-or-nothing; must encompass data access and modifications.  <hr />  - Index: specialized object store for efficient lookups in another store, based on a specific field.  <hr />  - Cursor: iterates over data in object stores, one record at a time, conserving memory for large datasets.  <hr />- Usage involves opening database, creating object stores, defining indexes, and performing transactions.  <hr />- Cannot rely on full text search or complex string sorting across different languages.  <hr />- Limitations include incompatibility with private browsing modes, potential storage quota issues, and increased coding complexity compared to localStorage or cookies.  <hr />- Appropriate when storing complex objects, requiring transactional integrity, and handling large amounts of structured data.

329.title: Why We Chose Our Tech Stack Accelerating Development With A Robust Frontend Solution
329.description: We pride ourselves on being a team of seasoned technology experts, passionate about crafting innovative solutions for our clients. With years of experience in the technology industry, we understand the importance of selecting the right tools and technologies to deliver exceptional results. In today's fast-paced world, staying ahead of the competition requires building and deploying features quickly without sacrificing quality or stability.
329.spr_content: - The team comprises seasoned, passionate technology experts focused on innovative client solutions.  <hr />- Experience underscores the importance of stable, mature tools for impactful, long-term projects.  <hr />- Prioritize speed without compromising quality or stability in deploying features.  <hr />- The core question for choosing frontend technologies: "Has this technology achieved stability and maturity?"  <hr />- Recognize that transformative projects require years of dedication, whereas quick wins are temporary.  <hr />- The tech stack includes React, Next.js, React Context, TypeScript, SWR, React Hook Form, TailwindCSS, and HeadlessUI.  <hr />- React offers a decade of proven stability, high performance, extensive ecosystem, and community support, suitable for long-term projects.  <hr />- Next.js extends React with hybrid rendering, TypeScript support, bundling, and routing, favoring scalability despite added complexity.  <hr />- React Context simplifies data sharing across components, avoiding prop drilling, suitable for simple to moderate state needs.  <hr />- TypeScript enhances code safety, auto-completion, API consistency, and refactoring, facilitating large-scale, maintainable applications.  <hr />- SWR manages backend data caching, ensuring UI responsiveness via stale-while-revalidate strategy, tunable for performance and data freshness.  <hr />- React Hook Form provides efficient, straightforward form management with extendability, emphasizing performance and simplicity.  <hr />- TailwindCSS accelerates development through utility classes, responsive design, auto-optimized production builds, and customization, favoring consistency and speed over initial verbosity.  <hr />- The architecture comprises layers: service connector with Fetch API, state management with React Context and SWR, logic with React Hooks, UI with TailwindCSS and HeadlessUI.  <hr />- Service connector handles API communication, integrating Fetch API with SWR for caching and error handling.  <hr />- State layer manages local and global data, ensuring reactive UI updates efficiently.  <hr />- Logic layer encapsulates business rules via React Hooks, promoting reuse and separation of concerns.  <hr />- UI layer employs TailwindCSS and HeadlessUI for flexible, accessible interfaces; contrasts with more rigid libraries like Ant Design or Material-UI.  <hr />- Testing strategy prioritizes thorough coverage: Jest for unit tests, React Testing Library for component testing based on user behavior, Cypress for end-to-end testing mimicking real user interactions.  <hr />- Jest's parallelization mitigates performance issues in large test suites.  <hr />- Cypress complements tests by catching issues that unit and component tests may miss, supporting high-quality releases.  <hr />- The combined stack and practices enable rapid development of scalable, high-quality applications, maintaining pace with industry evolution.  <hr />- The architecture, technology choices, and testing practices ensure stability, speed, and user satisfaction, establishing a competitive edge.  <hr />- The organization invites collaboration, offering expertise in scalable, high-performance frontend solutions; contact details provided online.

330.file_path: playground/topics/frontend/Tackling Server State complexity in Frontend Development.md
330.title: Tackling Server State complexity in Frontend Development
330.description: Frontend development has become increasingly complex over the years, and with it, the need for efficient state management.
330.spr_content: - Frontend complexity increased; state management critical.<hr />- Global State manages data across components, avoids prop drilling.<hr />- Prop drilling hampers maintainability; Global State offers cleaner code.<hr />- Global State effective for client data; less suited for server data.<hr />- Client State: client-controlled, local.<hr />- Server State: remote, outside application's control, requires synchronization.<hr />- Server State differs: persistence outside app, frequent updates, potential staleness.<hr />- Synchronization involves caching, background updates, memory management.<hr />- Redux exemplifies verbose handling of server responses: boilerplate for loading, error, revalidation.<hr />- Libraries like SWR and React-Query abstract server state complexities.<hr />- SWR and React-Query: simplify asynchronous data storage, minimize boilerplate.<hr />- Redux fetch example: verbose, detailed, requires extra state handling.<hr />- React-Query fetch: concise, declarative, less code.<hr />- Global State useful but has limitations with server data.<hr />- For server-state, assess whether to treat as Global State.<hr />- Use specialized libraries (SWR, React-Query) for server data to enhance efficiency and simplicity.

331.title: Remix Versus Nextjs
331.description: A brief comparison between Remix and Next.js frameworks
331.spr_content: - Remix is an edge native, full-stack JavaScript framework emphasizing web standards, unifying client and server.<hr />- Next.js is a mature React framework focusing on server-side rendering, with widespread adoption.<hr />- Remix eschews static site generation (SSG), favoring CDN caching with stale-while-revalidate strategy.<hr />- Next.js supports multiple rendering strategies, including getServerSideProps and getStaticProps.<hr />- Both use file-based routing; Remix uses /app/routes, Next.js uses /pages.<hr />- Remix leverages React Router for nested routing with Outlet components, offering powerful route nesting.<hr />- Next.js has routing support but nesting is less straightforward compared to Remix.<hr />- Remix’s data loading employs loader functions and useLoaderData hooks; Next.js uses getServerSideProps.<hr />- For data mutations, Remix simplifies with <Form> and action functions; Next.js requires manual handling.<hr />- Remix provides built-in error boundaries and nested error handling; Next.js uses custom error pages.<hr />- Remix’s abstractions enhance developer experience with integrated data, mutation, and error management.<hr />- Next.js is preferred for its maturity, React ecosystem familiarity, and larger community.<hr />- Remix is emerging, with innovative features likely to gain influence, especially in nested routing and data handling.<hr />- Overall, Next.js is a stable choice, Remix positions itself as a future-forward, flexible alternative.

332.title: Shadow DOM
332.description: Shadow DOM is a web standard that allows encapsulation of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript within a specific context.
332.spr_content: - Javis is a Chrome extension AI assistant enhancing browsing.<hr />- CSS conflicts caused interface distortion between Javis and webpages.<hr />- Shadow DOM encapsulates HTML, CSS, JS, hiding internal structures.<hr />- Shadow DOM attaches a hidden DOM tree via a shadow root to a shadow host.<hr />- Shadow host: element in main DOM hosting shadow DOM.<hr />- Shadow tree: internal DOM inside the shadow root.<hr />- Shadow boundary: demarcation between shadow DOM and main DOM.<hr />- Shadow root: the root node of the shadow DOM.<hr />- Shadow DOM manipulation mimics normal DOM operations; encapsulation prevents external style/script interference.<hr />- Creating shadow DOM involves `attachShadow({ mode: 'open' | 'closed' })`.<hr />- `open` mode exposes shadow DOM externally; `closed` mode restricts access.<hr />- Shadow DOM is ideal for extensions/widgets to preserve style/script isolation, enhancing reliability and UX.

333.title: Why DOM manipulation is slow?
333.description: Actually, the DOM is not slow. Adding or removing a DOM node is not much more than setting a property on the JS object. However, _layout_ is slow. Imagine adding a DOM node changes the height of the document, it would invoke a bunch of [rendering processes](https://web.dev/rendering-performance/) to redraw the screen. And all the complex algorithms behind the those processes makes any changes in DOM potentially expensive.
333.spr_content: DOM manipulation involves property updates to JavaScript objects, which is fast.  <hr />Layout recalculations, however, are slow due to complex rendering algorithms.  <hr />Adding or removing DOM nodes triggers layout changes if size or position impacts are involved.  <hr />Such changes activate rendering processes, including reflow and repaint.  <hr />Reflow recalculates layout geometry; repaint redraws pixels.  <hr />Reflow and repaint are costly, especially on complex pages.  <hr />The perceived slowness is from layout, not DOM modification itself.  <hr />Optimizing involves minimizing layout thrashing and batching DOM updates.

334.title: Focus trap
334.description: Focus trap is a web technique to improve accessibility by forcing keyboard focus inside a DOM element, to prevent the user navigating outside that element.
334.spr_content: Focus trap: web technique to confine keyboard focus within a DOM element.  <hr />Primarily used in modal dialogs to prevent focus from escaping.  <hr />Ensures user remains within the interactive context, preserving accessibility.  <hr />Prevents focus loss that could cause confusion about active element.  <hr />Enables predictable navigation and interaction within modal.  <hr />Related to preventing disorientation in assistive technologies.  <hr />Reference: CSS-Tricks article on CSS-approach to trap focus.

335.title: HTML inert
335.description: `inert` is a boolean HTML property that makes the browser ignore the user input events for an element, including focus events and events from assistive technologies.
335.spr_content: - `inert` is a boolean HTML property that disables user interaction and assistive technology input on an element.  <hr />- When `inert` is present, element is removed from tab focus and accessibility tree.  <hr />- `inert` eliminates the need for complex focus traps combined with `aria-hidden` for modals/dialogs.  <hr />- Prior to `inert`, disabling interaction required `tabindex="-1"`; `inert` simplifies this.  <hr />- Using `inert` still requires manual focus management: focus must be shifted to dialog on open and restored on close.  <hr />- `aria-hidden` hides elements from assistive tech but does not block interaction; `inert` blocks both.  <hr />- `inert` helps improve accessibility for dialogs by reducing reliance on `aria-hidden` + focus trap combination.  <hr />- It streamlines modal/dialog handling, making the element truly inert to user and assistive input.

336.file_path: playground/topics/frontend/A Fragment Colocation Pattern with React & Apollo GraphQL.md
336.title: A Fragment Colocation Pattern with React & Apollo GraphQL
336.description: When working with complex GraphQL schemas, it's common to have shared fields across different types. A fragment colocation pattern allows us to define fragments alongside their corresponding components, resulting in a more cohesive and maintainable codebase.
336.spr_content: - Complex GraphQL schemas often feature shared fields across multiple types, enabling fragment reuse.<hr />- Fragment colocation aligns fragments closely with components, fostering cohesion and maintainability.<hr />- Colocating fragments simplifies reuse across components sharing common fields, reducing redundancy, enhancing consistency.<hr />- Tooling layers augment this pattern: converting fragments into TypeScript interfaces and auto-generating React hooks for queries/mutations.<hr />- GraphQL fragments are reusable pieces selecting specific fields on a type, e.g., `NameParts` on `Person`.<hr />- Using `...FragmentName` in queries spreads the fragment fields, simplifying field inclusion, akin to JavaScript spread syntax.<hr />- Changes to fragment definitions automatically propagate to all queries using them, ensuring consistency.<hr />- Example: `AnimalModel` type with shared fields; `CatModel` and `DogModel` extend it with specific fields.<hr />- Fragments for shared `id`, `name`, `breed` are declared and extended for each animal type.<hr />- `@graphql-codegen/cli` converts fragments into precise TypeScript types, guaranteeing type safety aligned with schema.<hr />- Types generated match actual GraphQL models, enabling accurate, strict typing for components.<hr />- Components (`CatCard`, `DogCard`) accept fragment types as props, ensuring correct data shape.<hr />- Query definitions (`GetCatList`, `GetDogList`) use fragments, and subsequent codegen hooks manage data fetching and lifecycle.<hr />- Hooks like `useGetCatListQuery` and lazy variants streamline data operations; automatically handle caching, revalidation.<hr />- Components (`CatList`, `DogList`) leverage generated hooks, map data to display components, maintain type safety.<hr />- Benefits:<hr />  - Reusability: Fragments tied with components promote modular code.<hr />  - Consistency: Centralized fragment definitions prevent divergence.<hr />  - Readability: Locating fragment definitions with components clarifies data dependencies.<hr />  - Overfetching Prevention: Queries request only necessary fields via fragments.<hr />  - Automatic Typing: Generated types reflect current schema, reducing manual errors.<hr />- Disadvantages:<hr />  - Fragment duplication risk complicates management.<hr />  - Increasing fragment count escalates organizational complexity.<hr />  - Deviates from traditional REST mindset, demanding a different mental model.<hr />  - Larger component trees complicate tracing fragment origins, especially without effective organization.<hr />- Pattern summary:<hr />  - Achieves cohesive, typed, maintainable code.<hr />  - Improves reusability and consistency.<hr />  - Faces potential fragmentation and complexity with scale.<hr />- Overall:<hr />  - An _easy to adopt, hard to master_ pattern.<hr />  - Embodies GraphQL philosophy: declarative, flexible, typed.<hr />  - Worth experimenting with to optimize large, shared schema codebases.

337.title: Frontend Report February 2025
337.description: Our February 2025 report covers what's new in frontend development - from React's move away from Create React App to Next.js improvements, browser compatibility updates, and cool new tools like React Scan. Get practical tips for better auth, faster websites, and making your sites work for everyone.
337.spr_content: - React has deprecated Create React App, favoring Vite for fast builds and Next.js for server-side rendering.<hr />- React Context can cause extensive re-renders; optimal to split large contexts or adopt libraries like Jotai or Zustand for fine-grained updates.<hr />- React Server Components differ from traditional components; use `Flight` stream format, avoid the `double data problem`, and recognize server versus client feature boundaries.<hr />- React Query, while popular, introduces large files, complex caches, and less transparent code flow.<hr />- Next.js 15 enhances error handling with dedicated error, global-error, and not-found components, improving site robustness; error boundaries and `useActionState` help manage server-side issues.<hr />- Vercel Fluid Compute combines requests, reducing AI operation costs significantly; replaces Edge with full Node.js support, balancing speed and resource use.<hr />- Implement session-based auth in Next.js via secure database schemas, password hashing, session validation, and UI for sign-up/sign-in.<hr />- Next.js 15's error management tools streamline crash recovery; optimize images, minimize code, leverage Gzip, apply effective caching, and inline critical CSS for speed.<hr />- Browser privacy updates with double-keyed caching partition assets by URL and site, impacting third-party content and CDN performance.<hr />- Accessibility should be integrated early: proper HTML semantics, non-placeholder forms, focus management enhance usability, SEO, and inclusivity.<hr />- Website speed can be improved via image optimization, file compression, CDN caching, Chrome dev tools, critical CSS, and system fonts.<hr />- In 2025, JavaScript trends include edge serverless, WebAssembly speedups, Microfrontends via Module Federation, and refined state management.<hr />- React's 2024 user survey highlights issues with forwardRef, memo, and rapid tooling changes; TanStack Start rises as Next.js alternative.<hr />- Interop 2025 aims for browser feature uniformity, targeting 95% compatibility in key areas like CSS Zoom, WebRTC security, mobile testing.<hr />- React performance tools like React Scan facilitate component slowdown detection with visual feedback, requiring no code modifications.<hr />- Nue offers a minimalistic framework relying on HTML, Markdown, CSS, reducing complexity and technical debt.<hr />- Standard Schema addresses Zod's performance and TypeScript lag issues, providing a versatile, standards-aligned validation system.<hr />- External commentary suggests a React slowdown, developer frustration with linters, AI challenges to browsers, and HTML's underrated programming language status.

careful loader structure is essential to avoid pitfalls.<hr />- React hooks have unspoken rules; understanding them improves clarity and performance.<hr />- React testing benefits from inverse assertions; broad hosting options.<hr />- Next.js supports internationalization; reliable date formatting for global applications.<hr />- RAG setup in TypeScript and React is streamlined; architecture and types facilitate integration.<hr />- CSS :has selector can replace React in certain scenarios; enhances focus, tables, and UI interactions.<hr />- ES5 transpilation may be less necessary; JavaScript evolution favors modern syntax; reconsider legacy dependencies.<hr />- JavaScript trademark controversy; calls for Oracle to release it; aims to reduce confusion.<hr />- Hono framework gains attention; promises high speed and full-stack simplicity.<hr />- Prompts require better design tools; improved prompt engineering enhances AI outputs.<hr />- ChatGPT can reverse engineer minified JavaScript; 340.spr_content: - 2024 frontend roundup features React Router v7, Tailwind CSS v4 Beta, Vite 6.0, Next Cloudinary, Extism, SmarkForm, plus SSR insights, JavaScript Symbols, new CSS strategies.  <hr />- React Router v7 introduces `framework mode`, Remix features, server rendering, enhanced type safety, better project templates, upgrade guides.  <hr />- Passing useState setters as props causes abstraction leaks; callbacks improve clarity, reusability, maintainability.  <hr />- React Server Components differ from SSR in key aspects; React Portals enable DOM hierarchy escape; Tremor offers dashboard/chart components.  <hr />- Next Cloudinary streamlines client-side file handling, image optimization, multi-source support (Google Drive), real-time effects, watermarking, responsiveness.  <hr />- Solito bridges React Native and Next.js, sharing components, navigation, ensuring high performance, cross-platform user experience.  <hr />- JavaScript Symbols serve as unique property keys, manage custom object behaviors (`Symbol.toPrimitive`, `Symbol.species`), support `Symbol.for()` for global sharing, control over primitive conversions, advanced object manipulation.  <hr />- Importing JS libraries without build systems involves global variables, ES modules, UMD files, import maps, converting CommonJS, but build steps facilitate dependency management.  <hr />- Evaluate browser support for CSS features via support frameworks, simulate unsupported browsers, use `@supports` for fallbacks, balance feature benefits and legacy compatibility.  <hr />- CrRRUX score normalizes Core Web Vitals to compare website performance reliably across cohorts, addressing CWV unit/scale inconsistencies.  <hr />- Tailwind CSS v4 Beta offers 5x faster builds, CSS-first configs, modern features like container queries, cascade layers, popovers.  <hr />- Vite 6.0 improves builds, supports broader frameworks, adds environment API, milestone 10M+ npm downloads — most significant since Vite 2.  <hr />- Extism leverages WebAssembly, provides a universal, plugin-based framework for diverse platforms, enabling programmable software.  <hr />- Additional tools: SmarkForm for forms, SVG font generator, JSON interactive diagrams; trending topics include advanced CSS, web performance scoring, animation evolution.

Discover trending technologies, best practices, and expert commentary shaping the future of frontend development.
341.spr_content: React 19 introduces significant enhancements: built-in actions for state management, error handling, optimistic updates, new hooks (useOptimistic, useActionState), and improved Suspense. Ref callbacks now support cleanup functions akin to useEffect, enabling DOM measurement tasks. The View Transition API offers smooth, engaging animations for better UX. Next.js 15.1 integrates React 19 seamlessly, with enhanced debugging and error handling; it now supports running on Deno Deploy, advancing serverless scalability. Multi zones enable independent micro-frontends, aiding large team deployments. Transformers.js allows client-side AI inference, eliminating server dependency; new HTML/CSS features simplify interactive element creation—popovers, CSS Anchoring, calc-size(). Trending tools include shadcn/ui, HTMX, and offline-first app techniques. Tailwind CSS v4 and Node.js TypeScript support streamline development workflows. Performance tools like Million optimize React apps; thought leadership advocates for open web, simplified types, and migration insights.

342.title: Frontend Report March 2025
342.description: March 2025 brings critical frontend updates! Learn about the Next.js security exploit you must patch nows. Explore TypeScript's upcoming 10x speed boost with Corsa, React Router's game-changing middleware, and why prefetching can surprisingly slow down your site. Plus: CSS functions are finally here, new in Chrome 133, Node.js is dropping Corepack, and TanStack Start finds an official deployment home!
342.spr_content: - React architecture: core logic + React binding (hooks/components); core created externally; connected via Context API; Observer pattern triggers re-renders via useSyncExternalStore or custom hooks.<hr />- Most React libraries use a modular architecture: core + bindings.<hr />- Modern React handles complex UI state with useState and custom hooks; global stores like Redux often unnecessary and can hinder agility.<hr />- Redux's role: often replaced by API caching tools; state management shifted toward localized, cache-driven approaches.<hr />- React 19's cache() API: caches fetches/computations per render; prevents redundant data requests; enables data preloading; enhances server component performance.<hr />- Redundant data fetching causes waterfall issues; cache() decouples data logic from presentation, improving load times.<hr />- Performance tips: optimize React.memo, leverage URL-based state, repurpose React for LLM workflows.<hr />- Next.js middleware vulnerability (CVE-2025-29927): permits auth bypass via x-middleware-subrequest header; update versions or block headers.<hr />- Next.js 15.2: improves error handling with better UI and readable stack traces; introduces streaming metadata for faster loads; Turbopack speed boosts.<hr />- Scaling Next.js: pre-rendering alone insufficient for high traffic; dedicated servers or custom solutions needed.<hr />- Some teams prefer abandoning Next.js for bespoke solutions—greater flexibility, simplicity, performance.<hr />- Tailwind CSS: rapid styling but maintenance complexity grows with project scale.<hr />- CSS functions: emerging capabilities via @function allow dynamic, type-checked CSS logic, revolutionizing complex layouts.<hr />- Prefetching: can delay critical resource loading if mismanaged; prefer post-load JavaScript hints for resource prioritization.<hr />- Trending shifts: React Server Components and Server Functions set the stage for seamless SSR/SSG; React 19 advances forms; new frameworks and tools like TanStack Start, React Compiler emerge.<hr />- TypeScript 5.8: introduces faster compilation (`Corsa` compiler), improved bug detection, better Node.js ESM/CJS support; info about native build speedup.<hr />- Node.js future: Corepack to be phased out; developers must install package managers manually.<hr />- Deployment: Netlify officially supports TanStack Start for smooth full-stack React deployments.<hr />- Tools: TanStack Form v1 offers robust, schema-validated forms; React Router v7 introduces middleware; Chrome 133 enhances CSS with attr() and container queries.<hr />- Industry trends: React 2025 emphasizes Server Components/Functions; TypeScript will become significantly faster; Node.js ecosystem evolves; new CSS capabilities unlock dynamic styling.<hr />- Commentary highlights: ongoing JavaScript fatigue debate; signals in React; local-first data models' potential and challenges.

343.title: Frontend Report August 2024
343.description: A comprehensive August 2024 update on key advancements in React 19, Next.js 15, and web development tools. Highlights include new async transitions, server components, SSR performance comparisons, and emerging technologies in the web development landscape
343.spr_content: - React 19 RC introduces async transitions via Actions, enhancing user experience during state updates.  <hr />- Improved hydration error handling reduces bugs in server-rendered React apps.  <hr />- useOptimistic hook facilitates manageable optimistic UI updates, streamlining state management.  <hr />- Support for Server Components advances server-driven rendering, improving performance and load times.  <hr />- Async scripts and resource preloading optimize resource management in React 19.  <hr />- React 19 enhances form submissions with better techniques and hooks.  <hr />- SSR performance benchmark: Vue leads, followed by Svelte and Solid; React and Preact lag behind.  <hr />- 2024 React libraries emphasize state management (Zustand), UI design (Tailwind CSS), and data fetching (TanStack Query).  <hr />- Next.js 15 RC supports React 19 RC, with improved hydration handling, caching, and experimental features like the React Compiler and Partial Prerendering for mixed static/dynamic content.  <hr />- Next.js 15 enables incremental static generation and dynamic rendering, supporting more complex app architectures.  <hr />- V0 v3D supports creating interactive 3D apps and games seamlessly.  <hr />- CSS in 2024 now encompasses scroll animations, math functions, and scoped styling, enabling more dynamic designs.  <hr />- Temporal proposal simplifies date/time handling, resolving UTC/local issues with daylight saving and comparisons.  <hr />- MUI v6 adds CSS theme variables, container queries, performance tweaks, reduces package size, and experimentally integrates React Server Components and Pigment CSS.  <hr />- Top languages 2024: TypeScript and Rust rapidly rising; Python dominates AI; SQL remains core; C declines; legacy languages persist.  <hr />- e18e community projects clean dependencies, speed up packages, and promote modern alternatives for better JavaScript performance.  <hr />- InformAI exposes app UI data to LLMs with minimal code, enabling context-aware AI responses.  <hr />- Waku simplifies React development with a lightweight, server components-compatible toolkit.  <hr />- Formity allows JSON-defined, multi-step, dynamic forms with conditions and loops.  <hr />- Rspack 1.0, built in Rust, offers 10x faster bundling than webpack, supports Module Federation 2.0, and is adopted by major enterprises.  <hr />- Web development tools expand with Coolify (cloud hosting), Web Vitals Chrome Extension, React Email 3.0, and Web Vitals tool.  <hr />- Emerging discussions highlight the evolution of CSS, the potential of CSS5, and the declining reliance on microfrontends.  <hr />- Trends show growing TypeScript and Rust usage, renewed focus on performance and tooling, and AI integration with frontend ecosystems.

344.title: Frontend Report July 2024
344.description: The Front-end Market Report for July 2024 gives you a snapshot of what’s happening in the world of web development. 345.title: Frontend Report First Half of November 2024
345.description: A comprehensive update on key advancements in frontend development for the first half of November 2024, highlighting React 19's full-stack capabilities, XState for state management, Shopify's React Native migration, Next.js 15 enhancements, and the impact of container queries on responsive design.
345.spr_content: Frontend Development (H1 Nov 2024)  <hr />- Emerging frameworks challenge established ones; TanStack Start rivals Next.js with client-first versus server-first paradigms.  <hr />- State management evolved with XState; simplifies complex UI logic, improves reliability, scales well in React.  <hr />- Shopify’s React Native migration demonstrates large-scale mobile revamp, reducing codebase, boosting performance, elevating ratings.  <hr />- Next.js 15 enhances speed, limits build times, enriches features: React Server Components, App Router, image optimization, caching.  <hr />- Advanced search filtering achieved via App Router, startTransition, useOptimistic; improves UX for dynamic queries.  <hr />- Web Components' limitations include poor state handling, integration hurdles, SSR issues; frameworks outperform in practicality.  <hr />- Container queries & Containment API unlock true responsive design; adapt elements based on parent sizes, future browser support promising.  <hr />- TanStack Start exemplifies full-stack React: type safety, SSR, streaming, scalable APIs; suits modern web apps.  <hr />- Cost reduction via Shared Memory in AWS for Recall.ai; cuts expenses, CPU load, enhances efficiency.  <hr />- Tools: HTML-to-React Figma extension; Streamlined testing with Storybook Test—integrate component, visual, accessibility tests; early access invites.  <hr />- Commentary highlights: Lighthouse score not sole metric; headless components as UI-building paradigm; CSS survey insights.

346.title: Zaplib post-mortem
346.description: Zaplib is a frontend framework that helps to port your JS/TS app to Rust/Wasm. This idea was found after the founder's painful work at https://webviz.io when he had to use a bundle of manual memory management techniques such as ArrayBuffers, WebWorkers for performance optimization. Back up with the assumption that an intricate web app like Figma also uses Wasm, they thought there would be a lot of companies experiencing a similar performance issue with their applications and those companies would be keen on using their new tool to 10x speed up the apps.
346.spr_content: Zaplib is a frontend framework designed to facilitate porting JS/TS apps to Rust/Wasm.  <hr />It originated from the founder's difficult experience with manual memory management in web apps like Webviz.  <hr />The core assumption: complex, performance-critical web apps (e.g., Figma) use Wasm; thus, many companies face similar issues and could benefit from 10x speedups.  <hr />Real-world results challenge the assumption:  <hr />- Porting a JS simulator to Rust took a week; only yielded 5% performance improvement—insufficient for compelling adoption.  <hr />- Rust's speed advantage is context-dependent, more pronounced with memory layouts (e.g., millions of small structs) than general app logic.  <hr />- Significant 10x gains occur primarily through leveraging Rust’s zero-cost abstractions, which are niche cases.  <hr />- A successful migration boost was mainly due to WebGL acceleration, not Rust or Wasm improvements.  <hr />- Figma’s speedup also relies heavily on WebGL rendering, not Rust/Wasm processing.  <hr />- Moving away from Rust/Wasm toward WebGL rerendering is considered, but market demand is uncertain and likely not promising.  <hr />The overarching insight:  <hr />- Rust/Wasm is not a universal performance panacea for frontend apps.  <hr />- High expectations of 10x improvements are often unfulfilled in typical scenarios.  <hr />- Performance benefits are mostly situational; practical gains depend on specific use cases like graphics or memory layout optimizations.

347.title: React Server Components, NextJs Route and Data Fetching
347.description: React Server Components (RSCs) offer the flexibility to decide where to render components based on their purpose, diverging from the client-side rendering approach of Single-Page Applications.
347.spr_content: - React Server Components (RSCs) enable rendering parts of React apps on the server, diverging from traditional client-side Single-Page Application (SPA) models.  <hr />- RSCs are stateless server-only components, allowing server-driven static content generation and data fetching integration within the component tree.  <hr />- RSCs facilitate seamless collaboration with Client Components, which are marked with `'use client'`, indicating client-only execution.  <hr />- They adopt a protocol-based hybrid model, serving static server-rendered content initially, then enhancing with client-side React runtime for interactivity.  <hr />- RSCs use features like top-level `await`, server-side data serialization, and plan to incorporate hooks like `use()` for client-side data loading.  <hr />- Benefits include performance optimization—faster load times, reduced JavaScript bundle sizes, and simplified data fetching—by moving heavy dependencies and logic to the server.  <hr />- Next.js introduces conventions such as `.server.jsx/tsx` for server components and `.client.jsx/tsx` for client components, promoting maintainability and clarity.  <hr />- Client-only components should use `'use client'` directive at the top; server components cannot include hooks like `useState` or `useEffect`, which rely on browser APIs.  <hr />- The component pattern emphasizes relocating interactivity to leaf client components, keeping static layout and data display as server components for efficiency.  <hr />- Server and Client components can coexist in a single tree; server components are rendered fully on the server before being sent, client components render and merge on the browser.  <hr />- Importing server components directly into client components is unsupported; instead, pass server components as `children` props or nest within client components to maintain separation.  <hr />- JavaScript module sharing between server and client components is possible but risky; use packages like `server-only` to safeguard server-only sensitive logic.  <hr />- Data fetching in RSCs leverages optimized `fetch` with caching, revalidation strategies (background or on-demand), and can be combined with React’s `use()` hook for client-side data loading.  <hr />- Next.js supports server-driven data fetching via `revalidatePath` and `revalidateTag`, improving cache control and freshness.  <hr />- Server actions (`'use server'`) enable server-side handling of interactive behaviors in client components, avoiding the need for API routes.  <hr />- For client-side data needs, recommend `SWR`, `React Query`, or later, React’s `use()` for data fetching within client components.  <hr />- Overall, RSCs enhance React’s rendering paradigm by making applications more performant, smaller in bundle size, easier to maintain, and more responsive.

348.file_path: playground/topics/frontend/Preserving and Resetting state in React.md
348.title: Preserving and Resetting state in React
348.description: State in React is tied to a position in the UI tree.
348.spr_content: - React’s state is tied to component position in the UI tree, not to the component instance itself.<hr />- React preserves state for a component as long as it remains rendered at the same position in the tree.<hr />- Multiple instances of the same component at different positions maintain independent state.<hr />- Unmounting a component destroys its state; remounting creates a new one.<hr />- The UI rendering flow: JSX → UI trees → React DOM → DOM.<hr />- Same component + same position = preserved state, regardless of prop changes.<hr />- Different components occupying the same position reset each other's state.<hr />- To reset state intentionally, assign unique keys to components.<hr />- Keys differentiate components beyond position, preventing React from reusing previous state.<hr />- Using keys effectively "tears apart" component instances, allowing state resets.<hr />- React’s position in the tree defines identity, not the markup or props.<hr />- Rendering components with different positions ensures distinct state, avoiding bugs with shared state.<hr />- When components switch at the same position without key, React updates the existing component, preserving or resetting state based on the scenario.<hr />- Proper keying is recommended for controlling state resets in dynamic component rendering.

349.title: Mitigate blocking the main thread
349.description: We all know that for web applications, perceived performance is highly importance for our users. For data intensive SPAs with CPU-intensive tasks, the single-threaded nature of Javascript starts to hinder the application's perceived performance when you cannot fit those CPU-intensive tasks into a 16.67 ms/frame window (translates to 60fps). That doesn't even account for code execution time of frameworks (React, Vue...etc), which then leaves you with approximately only a 10 ms/frame window or less to complete all your tasks on the main thread to make user interaction feel smooth and snappy.
349.spr_content: - Perceived performance is critical for user experience in web apps.<hr />- Data-heavy SPAs struggle with main thread CPU tasks surpassing 16.67 ms/frame (60 fps).<hr />- Framework overhead reduces available frame time to roughly 10 ms for app logic.<hr />- JavaScript offers tools to mitigate main thread blocking: Web Workers and Generators.<hr />- Web Worker enables multi-threading by offloading tasks to background threads.<hr />- Web Worker communication involves serialization/deserialization, impacting performance.<hr />- Serialization limits Web Worker's effectiveness with large data; binary formats help but add complexity.<hr />- For real-time updates, Web Workers can implement a game-loop pattern to emit data periodically.<hr />- Coroutines are execution threads that can be suspended and resumed, facilitating cooperative multitasking.<hr />- ES6 generators enable suspending and resuming code execution at `yield` points.<hr />- Example generator function produces numbers from 1 to 99, illustrating yield-based iteration.<hr />- Combining generators with `requestIdleCallback()` allows batching work during main thread idle times.<hr />- `requestIdleCallback()` requests execution during browser idle periods, enabling cooperative multitasking.<hr />- Libraries like `js-coroutines` implement advanced coroutine patterns for managing work load efficiently.<hr />- Overall, threading (Web Workers) and async control flows (Generators + `requestIdleCallback()`) address main thread performance bottlenecks.

350.file_path: playground/topics/frontend/Retain scroll position in infinite scroll.md
350.title: Retain scroll position in infinite scroll
350.description: Infinite scroll has become a popular web design technique in recent years, as it offers several benefits over traditional pagination models. However, it can also present some painful challenges for accessibility and usability.
350.spr_content: - Infinite scroll enhances user experience by reducing load times and minimizing pagination.<hr />- Challenges include losing scroll position upon navigating away and returning, affecting usability.<hr />- Clicking an item navigates away from list; upon return, previous scroll position is lost.<hr />- Solution involves storing scroll position and loaded pages in session storage before navigation.<hr />- Use session storage key to persist scroll position (`scrollY`) and `swr` pages loaded (`swr.size`).<hr />- Implement `createRetainPositionStore` to handle storing and retrieving scroll and load state.<hr />- Before route change, save current `scrollY` and `swr.size`.<hr />- On revisit, retrieve stored state; scroll window to prior `scrollY`.<hr />- Retrieve `swr.size` and set it with `swr.setSize()` to restore loaded pages.<hr />- Use `useEffect` hooks within `useRetainPosition` to synchronize stored state on page load.<hr />- After restoring scroll position, remove stored data to prevent repeated restoration.<hr />- Session storage provides persistent state across pages during user session.<hr />- Integrating this approach improves infinite scroll usability, maintaining user position.<hr />- The pattern applies generally beyond infinite scroll via session-based priming of internal states.<hr />

351.title: Using Correct Html Element To Increase Website Accessibility
351.description: Using the correct HTML element can significantly improve the accessibility of your website.
351.spr_content: - Website accessibility ensures users with disabilities (visual, literacy) can access content via keyboard or Screen Reader tools.  <hr />- Accessibility contributes to Google Lighthouse quality metrics.  <hr />- Proper categorization of elements enhances readability for assistive tools.  <hr />- Correct HTML semantics are crucial: using tags that represent the element's purpose improves accessibility.  <hr />- Example: `<button>` provides default styling and keyboard support; `<div>` does not.  <hr />- Semantic HTML facilitates keyboard navigation (`Tab`, `Enter`), making interfaces usable without mouse.  <hr />- Consistent semantic markup is quick and equally efficient as non-semantic code.  <hr />- Benefits of semantic HTML include:  <hr />  1. Easier development with built-in functionalities.  <hr />  2. Reduced file size, improved responsiveness on mobile.  <hr />  3. Enhanced SEO with keyword emphasis in meaningful tags.

352.title: The fundamental of web performance
352.description: The key to improving your website speed is to understand where the bottlenecks are, and how much time each step takes.
352.spr_content: Web performance hinges on identifying bottlenecks in network latency and browser rendering.  <hr />Network latency involves request-response time, influenced by ISP speed, DNS, TCP handshake, hops, server processing, and static assets size.  <hr />Improving network latency includes locating servers close to clients, reducing server response times (cache, logic optimization), compressing files, preloading resources, and employing a CDN.  <hr />Browser rendering duration depends on data reception and involves parsing assets and pixel pipelines.  <hr />Parsing converts HTML and CSS into DOM and CSSOM trees, then merges into a render tree for layout.  <hr />Pixel pipelines execute algorithms for painting backgrounds, effects, and animations, repeating each frame.  <hr />Key rendering phases: JavaScript (modifies DOM), style calculations (CSS rule application), layout (element positioning), paint (visual rendering), compositing (combining layers).  <hr />Efficiency in rendering is achieved by minimizing work during each phase, understanding browser processes, and writing optimized code—favoring simple CSS selectors and reducing style recalculations.  <hr />Objective: deliver fast, smooth web experiences by optimizing network requests and browser rendering workflows.

353.title: Scroll-driven animations
353.description: Scroll-driven animations are popular effects used in web design. They are animations that are connected to the scroll position of a scroll container.
353.spr_content: Scroll-driven animations utilize scroll position to synchronize visual effects via new web APIs.  <hr />They connect scroll progress to animation timelines, creating declarative, smooth effects without heavy JavaScript.  <hr />Two primary types of timelines exist:  <hr /><hr />- Scroll Progress Timeline: maps scroll position to percentage (0%-100%) along a specific axis within a scroll container, converting position into animated progress.  <hr />- View Progress Timeline: measures how much an element is visible within a scroll container, tracking entry and exit, mimicking intersection observer behavior, with progress from 0% to 100%.  <hr /><hr />Traditional animations relied on scroll events on the main thread, causing jitter and lack of smoothness.  <hr />Modern approach: use the Scroll-driven Animations specification integrated with Web Animations API and CSS Animations API, enabling declarative, synchronized effects.  <hr /><hr />Default animation timeline: runs on the document timeline, beginning at page load (0), progressing with real time.  <hr />New timelines:  <hr /><hr />- Scroll Progress Timeline: linked to scroll range, converts position to percentage, updates as user scrolls.  <hr />- View Progress Timeline: linked to element's visibility within container, updates as element enters or leaves viewport.  <hr /><hr />Implementation example: rotate an SVG icon based on scroll using CSS `animation` with `animation-timeline: scroll()`.  <hr />`sroll()` takes arguments: `<scroller>` (nearest, root, self), `<axis>` (block, inline, x, y).  <hr />- For root viewport on the block axis: `scroll(root block)`.  <hr />- Duration is set to `auto`; no need for seconds.<hr /><hr />Example code snippet:  <hr />```css<hr />svg {<hr />  position: fixed;<hr />  top: 50%;<hr />  left: 50%;<hr />  margin-top: -50px;<hr />  margin-left: -50px;<hr />  animation: rotate 1s linear;<hr />  animation-timeline: scroll(root, block);<hr />}<hr />```  <hr /><hr />This approach enables creating complex, performant, scroll-based visual effects declaratively, with minimal code, in compatible browsers (Chrome 115+ with experimental features enabled).  <hr />More resources and examples are available online, fostering rich, interactive web experiences driven purely by scroll position.

354.file_path: playground/topics/frontend/Applying Mock Service Worker (MSW) for Seamless Web Development.md
354.title: Applying Mock Service Worker (MSW) for Seamless Web Development
354.description: Mock Service Worker (MSW) is an API mocking library that leverages the Service Worker API to intercept requests. It offers unique features that set it apart from traditional mocking libraries, making it a go-to choice for developers. With MSW, you can seamlessly mock both RESTful and GraphQL APIs, providing flexibility for various API architectures. Additionally, MSW supports both Node.js and browser environments, enabling consistent API mocking across different parts of your application.
354.spr_content: - MSW (Mock Service Worker): API mocking library leveraging Service Worker API.<hr />- Uses request interception to mock REST and GraphQL APIs.<hr />- Supports both Node.js (backend testing) and browser environments (frontend development).<hr />- Allows seamless, environment-agnostic API mocking for consistent testing and development.<hr />- Simplifies setup by providing pre-distributed worker files; no need to write Worker code.<hr />- Initialization via CLI (`npx msw init`) copies worker to public directory.<hr />- Configures Service Worker with request handlers using `setupWorker`.<hr />- In development, worker is started conditionally, enabling live API mocking during app runtime.<hr />- Components making fetch requests (e.g., `useFetch`) can have responses mocked via handlers.<hr />- Handlers define specific responses or errors for API endpoints.<hr />- Mocked responses can simulate success (status 200 or 301), redirects, or errors (500).<hr />- Testing setup involves `setupServer` from 'msw/node' for server-side mocking.<hr />- Server lifecycle: start before tests (`server.listen()`), reset handlers after each (`server.resetHandlers()`), close after all (`server.close()`).<hr />- Tests can verify component behavior with mocked responses, including success and error scenarios.<hr />- Runtime handlers (`server.use`) enable dynamic response adjustments within tests.<hr />- Handlers added at runtime are ephemeral; they are reset by `server.resetHandlers()`.<hr />- MSW promotes reliable, isolated, or integrated testing without relying on actual backend APIs.<hr />- References: official MSW docs and relevant blog resources.

355.file_path: playground/topics/frontend/When should we use useReducer instead of useState?.md
355.title: When should we use useReducer instead of useState?
355.description: Imagine we have a component with multiple states. It is simple enough not to use state management libraries. `useState` is surely a choice for the sake of brevity and clarity. But are there any issues we have to deal with? In this article, I want to make some improvements on `useState` hook and how we can replace it with `useReducer` as an alternative solution.
355.spr_content: - `useState` manages individual or grouped states via multiple hooks or one object; leads to verbose, cluttered code.<hr />- Multiple `useState` hooks increase complexity; harder to maintain, scale.<hr />- No built-in safeguards in `useState`: invalid or inconsistent related states possible (e.g., end date before start date).<hr />- Wrapping all state in one object improves readability but necessitates careful spreading (`...`) to trigger rerenders.<hr />- Validations with `useState` are external, scattered, hard to centralize; validation logic must be managed explicitly.<hr />- Curried functions help centralize validation but introduce complexity in state updates.<hr />- `useReducer` offers controlled, centralized state management; transformer functions define immutable state transitions.<hr />- With `useReducer`, validation logic is embedded in reducer, ensuring state integrity by design.<hr />- Reducer functions can enforce invariants (e.g., startDate ≤ endDate, title length limits).<hr />- `useReducer` can perform simple toggles via state inversion; extends to complex transformations.<hr />- `useReducer` is flexible, applicable beyond complex states; useful for all state transition control.<hr />- Treat state as immutable; tools like `Immer` facilitate safe mutations, compatible with `useReducer`.<hr />- Developers prefer `useState` for familiarity; `useReducer` requires conceptual adjustment but offers robustness.<hr />- Final insight: `useReducer` grants better control, scalability, and safety; worth adopting over `useState` for complex or validation-sensitive cases.

356.title: JavaScript modules
356.description: Modules have always been a part of JavaScript development and providing mechanisms for splitting JavaScript programs up into separate modules that can be imported when needed was the absolutely necessity for JavaScript developers.
356.spr_content: Modules in JavaScript serve as fundamental building blocks, encapsulating code within files that export their functionality and promote reusability. They impose structure and boundaries, preventing code clutter and global namespace conflicts, critical for maintaining large-scale applications. Sharing code via package managers like NPM hinges on modules.<hr /><hr />Historically, JavaScript modules evolved through four stages:<hr />- **Vanilla (1990s-2000s):** No modular system; relied on inline scripts, leading to disorganization and maintenance nightmares.<hr />- **IIFEs (2000s):** Used immediately invoked function expressions with closures to hide private data and reduce global pollution, but lacked interoperability and modular swapping.<hr />- **CommonJS (2010s):** Standardized server-side modules with `require()` and `module.exports`, enabled synchronous loading, easing file organization on the backend.<hr />- **ESM (2010s-present):** Browser-supported, asynchronous module loading with `import`/`export`, introduced top-level `await`, unified concept across client and server, and improved maintainability.<hr /><hr />Key contrasts:<hr />- CommonJS executes modules synchronously, suitable for server environments.<hr />- ESM loads modules asynchronously, allowing efficient parallel loading and top-level asynchronous code.<hr />- ESM is the future standard in browsers and recent Node.js versions; CJS remains useful on servers but less compatible universally.<hr /><hr />This evolution reflects a move toward unified, asynchronous, and scalable module systems, aligning client and server JavaScript development.

357.title: useEffect double calls in React 18
357.description: In the React 18 version, the `useEffect` hook has been updated to called twice compare to only one in the older version in StrictMode.
357.spr_content: React 18 introduces a development-only StrictMode check that causes components to mount, unmount, and then remount in development.
