446.spr_content: - Solana is a high-performance blockchain supporting decentralized apps and cryptocurrencies.<hr />- It features fast transaction speeds and low fees.<hr />- Uses Proof of History (PoH) as its consensus mechanism for scalability and throughput.<hr />- Ecosystem includes DeFi, NFTs, and various applications.<hr />- Accounts on Solana store data, can hold up to 10MB, and contain either executable code or state.<hr />- Account ownership controls data modification; only owner programs can modify accounts.<hr />- Accounts are classified into executable (programs) and non-executable (data, tokens).<hr />- Data accounts hold mutable data; program accounts store immutable code.<hr />- Native accounts represent core Solana programs like System, Stake, Vote.<hr />- Data accounts are either system-owned or PDA (Program Derived Address).<hr />- Solana programs are executable entities performing logic; similar to smart contracts.<hr />- Programs are deployed as native or on-chain (user-written).<hr />- Programs operate separately from data, referencing accounts during execution.<hr />- Native programs are integrated into the core; SPL programs are library modules.<hr />- On-chain programs are open for deployment and interaction by users.<hr />- Transactions encapsulate instructions; each instruction invokes a specific program.<hr />- Instructions are the smallest logic units, requiring: program address, account list, instruction data.<hr />- Program Derived Addresses (PDAs) are deterministically generated, lack private keys, but can sign via runtime.<hr />- PDAs enable program-only modifiable storage.<hr />- Cross Program Invocations (CPIs) allow one program to call another.<hr />- CPI facilitates composability; extends signer privileges; limited to depth four.<hr />- CPI enables complex operational flows within the Solana ecosystem.

447.title: How Tokens Work on Solana
447.description: A comprehensive guide explaining how tokens function on Solana, comparing it with EVM-based tokens. This article covers the creation of fungible tokens and NFTs, minting process, token transfers, and key differences in token management between Solana and EVM blockchains.
447.spr_content: - EVM developers deploy ERC20 contracts; Solana uses a unified token program.  <hr />- No need to create new contract on Solana; token program manages tokens.  <hr />- Create a new token by sending `create` instruction to token program; results in a `mint account`.  <hr />- Each token type has one `mint account` containing `total supply`, `decimals`, `mint authority`, `freeze authority`.  <hr />- To own tokens, create a `token account` linked to the `mint account`, tracking user balances.  <hr />- Mint tokens by sending `mint` instruction to token program; only `mint authority` can do this.  <hr />- Transfer tokens via `transfer` instruction; recipient must have a `token account` for the token type.  <hr />- NFTs are tokens with `total supply` of 1, `decimals` zero; mint one token and disable further minting.  <hr />- NFT creation uses the same token program but differs in minting process; often managed via Candy Machine.  <hr />- To assign token name and symbol, submit a JSON file to the [Solana Token Registry](https://github.com/solana-labs/token-list).  <hr />- Token metadata includes chain ID, address, symbol, logo, name, submitted via pull request.

448.title: StarkNet architecture
448.description: This article provides an overview of StarkNet's architecture, including its main components, how it works, and its transaction lifecycle. It also covers the messaging mechanism between Layer 1 and Layer 2, as well as the node clients used in the StarkNet network.
448.spr_content: - StarkNet is a layer 2 blockchain leveraging ZK rollup technology to enhance scalability and efficiency.<hr />- It utilizes StarkDex technology to support well-known apps like dYdX, ImmutableX, Sorare, enabling fast, low-cost decentralized exchanges.<hr />- Core mechanism involves reducing on-chain computations by offloading processing and storing minimal data on-chain, using Merkle trees with roots stored on-chain.<hr />- The architecture comprises six main components:<hr />  - User account: a social recovery smart contract, enabling offline authentication; exemplified by Argent X wallet.<hr />  - Sequencer: single entity validating, ordering, bundling off-chain transactions into blocks, using a Cairo VM akin to EVM.<hr />  - Prover: generates cryptographic proofs confirming Sequencer's computations, producing a proof for each new block.<hr />  - Full Node: maintains a complete record of all transactions and the global network state, sharing updates via P2P.<hr />  - Verifier: smart contract on Ethereum Layer 1 verifying proofs and transactions, ensuring integrity.<hr />  - StarkNet Core: Layer 1 smart contract updating global state upon proof verification, orchestrating state transition.<hr />- Transaction process:<hr />  - Batching: Sequencer groups multiple transactions into a batch, submitting as a compressed state update with proof.<hr />  - Validation & Updating: system computes a hash representing the new state, involving class hashes, Merkle roots, and Pedersen hashes.<hr />  - Proof Generation: StarkEx produces a STARK proof asserting transaction correctness.<hr />  - On-chain Verification: proof is validated on Ethereum Layer 1; upon success, state is updated on-chain.<hr />- Messaging protocols:<hr />  - L2→L1: asynchronous messages enable L2 contracts to interact with L1 contracts.<hr />  - L1→L2: similar asynchronous messaging allows L1 contracts to communicate with L2.<hr />- Transaction lifecycle:<hr />  - Submission: transactions are sent to the Sequencer.<hr />  - Processing: batch creation, change aggregation (storage, balances, data).<hr />  - Proof: StarkEx generates cryptographic proof of validity.<hr />  - Verification: proof checked on-chain; upon success, state is committed.<hr />- Node clients include Pathfinder and Juno, similar to Go Ethereum nodes.<hr />- References include documentation, deep dives, and smart contract addresses for StarkNet core and operator.

449.title: Multisign wallet
449.description: A multisign wallet is a type of digital wallet that requires multiple signatures to authorize transactions. This article provides an overview of multisign wallets, how they work, and their benefits.
449.spr_content: - Standard blockchain wallets rely on a single private key controlling assets and transactions.<hr /><hr />- Single-key control risks: theft, lost private key, death, all leading to asset inaccessibility.<hr /><hr />- Multisig Wallets are smart contracts enabling multiple signatures (multi-party approval) for transactions.<hr /><hr />- "Multisig" = multiple signatures required (e.g., 2-of-3, 3-of-5), improving security and shared control.<hr /><hr />- Analogy: a safe requiring multiple keys (e.g., Alice and Bob) to open, ensuring joint consent.<hr /><hr />- Multisig smart contracts process logic on-chain, receiving crypto and executing based on signature consensus.<hr /><hr />- Use cases include organizational fund control, dispute resolution, and multi-party decision making.<hr /><hr />- Advantages: increased security, redundancy, shared responsibility, dispute resolution.<hr /><hr />- Disadvantages: setup complexity, potential single points of failure (losing a device), higher transaction costs, limited smart contract operations, security limitations due to evolving threats.<hr /><hr />- Building a multisig wallet involves deploying a smart contract with owner roles, confirmation requirements, and functions for submitting, confirming, executing, and revoking transactions.<hr /><hr />- Example implementation (e.g., Solidity code) includes events, owner management, transaction tracking, confirmation logic, execution, and revocation functionalities.<hr /><hr />- Notable deployed multisig wallets: ConsenSys’, Gnosis’, BitGo’s, Ethereum Dapp’s, and historical Parity (not recommended due to security breaches).<hr /><hr />- The ecosystem lacks universal standards but draws from well-established implementations and best practices.<hr /><hr />- Security audits remain critical due to evolving blockchain vulnerabilities; multisig is not invulnerable.<hr /><hr />- Gas fees increase with signature verification steps during transaction submission and approval.<hr /><hr />- Multisig wallets enhance security but require careful configuration and management to balance safety and usability.

450.title: Ton's base concepts
450.description: Base concepts to begin with TON development
450.spr_content: TON Core Concepts SPR:<hr /><hr />- Cells store data; they are the atomic unit in TON’s data architecture.  <hr />- Each cell holds up to 1023 bits and 4 references to other cells.  <hr />- Cell types include ordinary (standard) and exotic (specialized).  <hr />- Exotic cells comprise Pruned Branch, Library Reference, Merkle Proof, and Merkle Update cells; each serves specific functions.  <hr />- Serialization of cells into byte arrays is called Bag of Cells; all network states and blocks are represented as bags.  <hr />- Smart contracts in TON include address (workchain_id + account_id), code (TVM-compatible), data (state variables), balance, and flags.  <hr />- Messages facilitate contract communication, containing source/destination addresses, value, payload, optional state init.  <hr />- Internal messages enable contract-to-contract transfer; external messages connect users to contracts.  <hr />- Transactions record state changes triggered by messages, capturing inbound/outbound messages, state modifications, and gas fees.  <hr />- TON executes transactions per smart contract; communication is message-based, not multi-contract per transaction.  <hr />- Gas differs from Ethereum; insufficient gas leaves transactions partial, excess gas must be refunded manually.  <hr />- Developers set minimum gas limits; extra gas is refunded after transaction completion.  <hr />- Typical transaction costs around 0.005 TON; marketplaces may reserve additional TON for fees.  <hr />- Fee components include storage, forwarding, computation, action, and outbound forwarding fees.  <hr />- Full mastery requires understanding data formats, transaction layout, and address bounceability, to be explored further.

451.title: Build custom AI Agent with ElizaOS
451.description: This guide shows how to build a custom AI Agent with ElizaOS.
451.spr_content: DeFAI: Merges DeFi principles with AI — predictive, automated financial services.<hr /><hr />ElizaOS: Framework for persistent, multi-platform AI personas; ensures consistent behavior, learning, adaptation, seamless integration.<hr /><hr />Response process:<hr />- Platform message reception.<hr />- Runtime orchestration.<hr />- Context assembly (time, history, knowledge).<hr />- Action evaluation.<hr />- Response production.<hr />- Conversation reflection.<hr />- Storage of new insights.<hr />- Delivery to user.<hr /><hr />Building AI with ElizaOS:<hr />- Characters: JSON configs; define personality, style, knowledge, scripts.<hr />- Example: YieldMaxoor, crypto veteran, slang, risk-aware, survivalist, knowledgeable in yield strategies, risk tools.<hr />- Characters maintain voice through samples, lore, beliefs, actions.<hr />- Agents: runtime components managing memory, logic, behavior; depend on persistent DB, model provider, keys.<hr />- Actions: define specific behaviors, interactions, external integrations.<hr />- Providers: inject real-time contexts (e.g., time, market data).<hr />- Example: timeProvider supplies current UTC time for contextual accuracy.<hr /><hr />Outcome:<hr />- DeFAI ICY Swap AI Agent: user balance checks, token exchanges, character-driven responses, plugin-enabled interactions.<hr />- System components: characters, agents, providers, actions, plugins.<hr />- Code and architecture facilitate customization, learning, multi-platform deployment.<hr /><hr />References:<hr />- Framework, tooling, examples, plugins, GitHub resources.<hr />- Emphasis on modularity, extensibility, continuous learning, decentralized operation.

452.title: Solana Account
452.description: This article provides an overview of Solana accounts, including their structure, types, and how they work.
452.spr_content: Solana architecture separates logic (Program) and data (Account); Programs interact with external Accounts, mutating them.  <hr />Three account types: Data accounts (store data), Program accounts (executable code), Native accounts (system, stake, vote).  <hr />Accounts have: lamports (balance), owner (program), executable flag, data (byte array), rent_epoch (rent schedule).  <hr />Ownership rules: Only owner can modify data and debit lamports; anyone can credit lamports; owner can reassign owner if data is zeroed.  <hr />Program accounts store code; do not hold state. To run a counter, create a program account (executable) for code, another account for counter value, with ownership aligned.  <hr />Rent costs SOL; accounts need enough to be rent-exempt (~2 years). Use `getMinimumBalanceForRentExemption`.  <hr />Unfunded accounts are deallocated, data is removed.

453.title: Layer 2: Scaling Solutions for Ethereum
453.description: Explore Layer 2 solutions for Ethereum scaling, including rollups and their benefits. Learn how Layer 2 extends Ethereum's capabilities, reduces gas fees, and maintains security while improving transaction throughput and efficiency.
453.spr_content: - Ethereum scaling solutions decouple from the main blockchain, creating separate Layer 2 networks.  <hr />- These Layer 2s extend Ethereum’s capabilities while inheriting its security guarantees.  <hr />- All user transactions on Layer 2 ultimately settle back on Layer 1, maintaining the base layer’s security.  <hr />- Ethereum also acts as a data availability layer, storing Layer 2 transaction data.  <hr />- Layer 2 chains post their data to Ethereum, relying on it for data availability and dispute resolution.  <hr />- This setup allows retrieving Layer 2 state and resolving transaction disputes via Ethereum.  <hr />- Blockchain’s core properties: decentralization, security, scalability.  <hr />- The blockchain trilemma states that only two properties can be fully achieved simultaneously.  <hr />- High demand necessitates scaling solutions that do not compromise decentralization or security.  <hr />- Layer 2 scaling leverages Ethereum's robust decentralization while handling increased throughput.  <hr />- Communication between Layer 2 and Layer 1 involves submitting transaction bundles; Layer 1 ensures security and data availability.  <hr />- Layer 2 handles computation and finalization proofs, reducing load on Layer 1.  <hr />- Rollup is the preferred Layer 2 scaling method; it aggregates multiple transactions into single Layer 1 transactions.  <hr />- Rollups reduce gas fees significantly, sometimes by 100x compared to Layer 1.  <hr />- Multiple Layer 2 transactions are bundled into a single Layer 1 transaction, lowering individual costs.  <hr />- For example, 100 Layer 2 transactions sharing 1 ETH in fees means each costs 0.01 ETH.  <hr />- Rollups execute computations outside Layer 1, with proofs submitted for finality, ensuring security.  <hr />- Two main rollup types: Optimistic Rollups and ZK (Zero-knowledge) Rollups.  <hr />- Examples include Arbitrum One, Optimism, and Boba Network.  <hr />- Refer to https://ethereum.org/en/layer-2 for further details.

454.title: Zero-knowledge Proofs
454.description: This article provides an overview of zero-knowledge proofs in blockchain technology, including their definition, how they work, and their advantages.
454.spr_content: Zero-knowledge proof (ZKP) enables statement validation without revealing the statement itself.  <hr />- "Prover" attempts to demonstrate claim validity; "Verifier" assesses it.  <hr />- Goals: enhance privacy, security; avoid personal info disclosure.  <hr />- Traditional proof uses personal IDs; insecure, hackable, risking privacy.  <hr />- ZKP removes info disclosure, using a "witness" (secret knowledge) to generate a succinct proof.  <hr />- Proof affirms truth without exposing underlying data.  <hr />- Verifier checks proof properties, not the data itself.  <hr />- Protocol relies on algorithms outputting true/false; must be complete, sound, and zero-knowledge.  <hr />- Completeness: valid data yields true; honest agents accepted.  <hr />- Soundness: invalid data cannot falsely pass the proof, barring negligible errors.  <hr />- Zero-knowledge: verifier learns nothing beyond validity; cannot reverse-engineer data from proof.  <hr />- Proof structure: witness (secret), challenge (question), response (answer).  <hr />- Interaction: multiple rounds (interactive) or single (non-interactive).  <hr />- Non-interactive proofs use cryptographic algorithms for one-way communication, suitable for scalability.  <hr />- Types: ZK-SNARKs and ZK-STARKs.  <hr />- ZK-SNARKs: small proofs, quick verification, require trusted setup with CRS (Common Reference String), vulnerable if setup compromised, popular for their efficiency in Layer 2 solutions.  <hr />- ZK-STARKs: scalable, transparent (no trusted setup), quantum-resistant, but larger proofs, more expensive verification, no recursion support.  <hr />- Applications: anonymous payments, identity privacy, authentication, verifiable computation.  <hr />- Drawbacks: hardware and verification costs, trust assumptions, quantum threats.  <hr />- References: Ethereum resources, technical comparisons, deep dives into SNARKs and STARKs.

455.title: Topics
455.description: This article provides an overview of the key topics in blockchain technology, including blocks, distributed systems, smart contracts, and zero-knowledge proofs.
455.spr_content: Blocks are fundamental units in distributed systems and blockchain technology.  <hr />Distributed systems rely on blocks for data consistency and decentralization.  <hr />Smart contracts operate within blocks to automate agreement execution.  <hr />Zero-knowledge proofs enable privacy-preserving validation within blocks or transactions.  <hr />PoW (Proof of Work) and PoS (Proof of Stake) are consensus mechanisms that secure block creation and validation in distributed networks, influencing system security and efficiency.

456.title: Smart Contract
456.description: This article provides an overview of smart contracts in blockchain technology, including their definition, how they work, and their advantages.
456.spr_content: Smart contracts are self-executing blockchain programs that operate without trust between parties, ensuring conditions trigger predefined actions. They act as automated intermediaries, reducing traditional costs and steps, exemplified by real estate transactions. Development involves deploying code on the blockchain, users invoke via signatures, and processed data is archived immutably. Structurally, contracts declare language versions, libraries, variables, constructors, processing logic, state, and logs. They can interact with other contracts through defined interfaces using calls via ABI. Advantages include increased efficiency, faster processing, autonomy from third parties, and reliable, tamper-proof record-keeping; mainly thanks to blockchain's distributed ledger. Limitations involve security vulnerabilities, as exploits and bugs allow theft and manipulation; integrity concerns from untrusted or false data sources (oracles); potential mismatches between contract behavior and stakeholders’ intent, risking damage; inherent complexity in deployment and immutability, which hampers updates and adjustments—highlighted by past incidents like The DAO hack leading to chain splits.

457.title: Blocks
457.description: This article provides an overview of blocks in blockchain technology, including their structure, types, and how they work.
457.spr_content: - Blocks are permanent, immutable storage units on the blockchain, encapsulating transaction data.<hr />- Each block links to the previous via a hash, forming a secure, tamper-evident chain.<hr />- Hashing cryptographically binds blocks; altering one invalidates subsequent blocks, ensuring integrity.<hr />- Block data includes standard info: height, timestamp, transaction count, miner address, reward, difficulty, size, gas metrics, and optional extra data.<hr />- Advanced block info comprises hash, parent hash, uncles' hash, system state root, and nonce for proof-of-work.<hr />- Uncle blocks arise from simultaneous miner discoveries; they are validated but not included in main chain, yet rewarded.<hr />- Block explorers reveal uncle block details: number, time, height, miner, reward.<hr />- Average block time in Ethereum is ~12–14 seconds, dynamically adjusted via difficulty to sustain network security.<hr />- A new block's acceptance depends on full node verification, emphasizing cautious validation.<hr />- Block size targets: 15 million gas, adaptable up to 30 million gas, constrained by network demands.<hr />- Larger blocks risk performance issues; size regulation prevents full nodes from lagging.<hr />- Mining involves solving for the nonce via hashing (e.g., SHA256), a process of trial-and-error to find a hash meeting difficulty criteria.<hr />- "Mining" is probabilistic, relying on hash randomness, not just complex math.<hr />- Gas measures transaction difficulty; each function consumes gas proportional to computational effort.<hr />- Gas cost: Gas used times Gas price; paying sufficient gas prevents transaction delays.<hr />

458.title: PoS
458.description: This article provides an overview of Proof of Stake (PoS) in blockchain technology, including its definition, how it works, and its advantages.
458.spr_content: - Proof of Stake (PoS) introduced in 2011 on Bitcointalk as an alternative to Proof of Work (PoW).  <hr />- Both aim for distributed consensus, but differ in process.  <hr />- Nodes stake tokens to prove identity and participate in transaction validation.  <hr />- PoS consensus relies on staking tokens rather than computational work to establish transaction order.  <hr />- Validation power correlates with the amount of tokens owned; "more coins, more influence."  <hr />- Peercoin was the first to adopt PoS, followed by Nxt, Blackcoin, ShadowCoin.  <hr />- PoS uses pseudo-random selection, influenced by factors like stake size, staking age, and randomness.  <hr />- Participation requires locking tokens as stake, influencing selection probability—the larger the stake, the higher the chance.  <hr />- Selection methods include "Random Block Selection" (lowest hash + highest stake) and "Coin Age Selection" (staking duration times amount).  <hr />- Coin age resets after block forging, discouraging large stake domination.  <hr />- Validators verify, sign, and add transactions to the blockchain, earning fees.  <hr />- Staked coins and rewards are released after a cooldown period upon node cessation, ensuring network integrity.  <hr />- PoS reduces energy consumption compared to PoW, eliminating intensive computation.  <hr />- Miner influence is proportional to stake, not energy; e.g., owning 3% of coins limits mining to 3%.  <hr />- Security relies on economic incentives; fraudulent activity results in stake loss, discouraging dishonesty.  <hr />- A 51% attack requires majority stake ownership—a costly, impractical endeavor for large networks.  <hr />- Ethereum transitioned from PoW to PoS starting in 2017, with mainnet deployment by 2022.  <hr />- PoS offers faster transactions, environmental sustainability, resistance to government interference, and accessibility on modest devices.

459.title: Distributed systems
459.description: This article provides an overview of distributed systems in blockchain technology, including their definition, advantages, and how they work.
459.spr_content: Distributed systems on blockchain  <hr />- Distributed computing studies interconnected components across multiple computers.  <hr />- Systems are software entities geographically separated, collaborating via message exchange.  <hr />- Similar to clustering but with distributed physical resources across locations.  <hr />- Practically common; most Internet apps are distributed.  <hr />- Benefits include resource scalability, fault tolerance, independent component management, and global accessibility.  <hr /><hr />Advantages of distributed systems  <hr />- Scalability: horizontal (adding machines) & vertical (upgrading resources).  <hr />- Reliability: fault tolerance ensures service continuity despite failures.  <hr />- Availability: high system uptime; measured annually.  <hr />- Efficiency: handles many requests with low latency.  <hr />- Manageability: ease of expansion and maintenance.  <hr /><hr />Machine failure categories  <hr />- Fail-stop: process halts due to crashes, errors, or power loss; most common.  <hr />- Fail-recover: process temporarily down, then recovers using stored data.  <hr />- Byzantine failure: machine produces arbitrary/malicious outputs, defies expected behavior; hardest to handle.  <hr /><hr />Network problems  <hr />- Network partitioning: links cut, system splits, nodes cannot communicate.  <hr />- Causes include switch or wire failures, affecting system integrity.  <hr /><hr />Distributed systems in blockchain  <hr />- Blockchain: distributed ledger duplicated across nodes; each node has a full copy.  <hr />- New blocks form after transaction approval; shared consensus.  <hr />- Anyone with internet connection and adequate hardware can join as a validator.  <hr />- Bitcoin demands immense computing power due to high miner participation.  <hr /><hr />Distributed software on blockchain  <hr />- Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM): environment for executing smart contracts.  <hr />- EVM features stack, memory, gas management, persistent storage; ensures deterministic, consensus-driven outcomes.  <hr />- EVM is language-agnostic (implemented in many languages) and Turing-complete.  <hr />- Common uses: tokens (ERC20, ERC721), crowdfunding, DeFi, DApps, DAOs, gaming, prediction markets.  <hr /><hr />Blockchain scalability issues  <hr />- Distributed computing scales additively; blockchain scales via transaction and consensus limits.  <hr />- Transaction speed is constrained by the need for node consensus.  <hr />- Challenges include increasing transaction throughput, with current Ethereum (~25 TPS) lagging behind traditional systems like Visa (45,000 TPS).  <hr />- Ethereum 2.0 aims to surpass 100,000 TPS.  <hr />- Solutions include Layer 2 scaling techniques to improve performance.  <hr />- Higher node participation raises difficulty, limiting throughput due to the collective effort needed for consensus.

460.title: Blockchain Bridge
460.description: A comprehensive guide to understanding blockchain bridges, their types, and how they facilitate communication and asset transfers between different blockchain networks.
460.spr_content: - Web3 and Dapps form an ecosystem of heterogeneous L1 and L2 blockchains with unique tradeoffs and capacities.<hr />- Increasing protocols and applications intensify the need for asset transfer across chains.<hr />- Blockchain bridges function like physical bridges, connecting separate blockchain ecosystems through message and asset transfer.<hr />- Blockchains are isolated due to differing rules and consensus mechanisms, necessitating bridges for inter-chain communication.<hr />- Bridges enable trustless cross-chain transfer of assets and messages, addressing scalability and ecosystem expansion.<hr />- Types of bridges require authentication mechanisms; variations include external validators, lightweight clients, and liquidity networks.<hr />- Basic bridge operation: monitor source chain events, authenticate, then forward messages to destination chain.<hr />- Key components: monitor/relay actors (oracles, validators), message passing, consensus protocols, cryptographic signing.<hr />- Classification:<hr />  - External validator bridges: use bonded validators locking assets and generating messages via consensus.<hr />  - Lightweight client & relay bridges: generate cryptographic proofs and verify states via smart contracts; resource intensive.<hr />  - Liquidity networks: peer-to-peer routers holding assets, enabling large-value transfers securely.<hr />- Each bridge design emphasizes specific characteristics:<hr />  - Security: resistance to malicious actors, safeguarding user funds.<hr />  - Speed: transaction finality versus security tradeoff.<hr />  - Connectivity: ease of integrating target chains.<hr />  - Capital efficiency: cost-effective security and transaction fees.<hr />  - Authenticity: transfer of specific assets or complex state, cross-chain contracts.<hr />- Interoperability dilemma (akin to blockchain trilemma): only two of the following three:<hr />  - Trustless security<hr />  - Scalability across domains<hr />  - Arbitrary data handling (generalizability)<hr />- Risks:<hr />  - Smart contract bugs and exploits.<hr />  - Underlying chain vulnerabilities like hacks and rollbacks.<hr />  - Malicious or insider threats, including compromised moderators.<hr />  - Hacked bridges, internal consensus attacks.<hr />  - User errors and chain congestion affecting bridge performance.<hr />- Notable exploits: Solana Wormhole ($325M stolen), Thorchain, PolyNetwork hacks.<hr />- Case studies: icrosschain.io, Wormhole, Thorchain.<hr />- References include Wikipedia, scholarly articles, and reported security incidents.<hr />- Overall, bridging involves complex tradeoffs in trust, security, speed, and scalability, intertwined with inherent risks and the interoperability trilemma.

461.title: Anchor framework
461.description: A comprehensive guide to getting started with smart contract development on Solana using the Anchor framework. This tutorial covers the basics of Anchor, its components, installation process, and provides step-by-step instructions for creating and deploying a simple program.
461.spr_content: - The article introduces a tutorial for developing Solana smart contracts using the Anchor framework.<hr />- Assumes prior knowledge of Solana network, accounts, programs, instructions, Rust or C++, and local network setup.<hr />- Anchor is a framework/library ecosystem that accelerates Solana development; includes Rust crates, IDL, TypeScript clients, CLI tools.<hr />- Anchor's benefits: user-friendly, modular, utilities for build/test/deploy, auto-generates JS/Golang clients from IDL.<hr />- Anchor's core components: program logic, account struct with `#[derive(Accounts)]`, declare_id macro for security and key access.<hr />- Solana development mimics Ethereum's ABI: create workspace, configure cluster, deploy via CLI.<hr />- Create a project with `anchor init`; define program code in `lib.rs`, importing `anchor_lang`.<hr />- Program structure: multiple Rust files (`processor.rs`, `instruction.rs`, etc.); build with `anchor build`.<hr />- Ensure compatible Anchor version; generate IDL with `anchor idl parse`, similar to ABI.<hr />- Deployment involves setting cluster URL (`localhost`, `devnet`, `testnet`, `mainnet-beta`) and `anchor deploy`.<hr />- After deployment, use Solana's CLI or SDKs to create transactions and interact with the program.<hr />- Anchor CLI commands: `build`, `cluster`, `deploy`, `init`, `test`, `upgrade`, `verify`.<hr />- Anchor Version Manager (AVM): manages multiple CLI versions; commands include install, list, uninstall, use.<hr />- Key Solana concepts: account (record/storage), owner (program), block, BPF loader, keypair, lamport (native token), leader/leader schedule.<hr />- Example projects and references provided for templates and further reading.

462.title: Plonky2
462.description: Plonky2 is a non-Interactive Proof of Proof of Knowledge (NIPoPoK) chain that reduces blockchain size and speeds up transaction confirmations. This article explores Plonky2's technology, its applications in various blockchain projects, and compares it with other scaling solutions.
462.spr_content: - Plonky2 is a non-interactive proof system (NIPoPoK) designed to reduce blockchain size and accelerate transaction confirmation.<hr />- Built on ZK-SNARKs technology, enabling proofs without revealing internal data.<hr />- Utilizes small certificates (~1/20th size of traditional attestations), decreasing storage needs.<hr />- Implements Merkle trees with "superblocks" (small data subsets) allowing verification without full blockchain download.<hr />- NIPoPoK eliminates interaction between parties, minimizing communication, enhancing speed, and preserving security.<hr />- Merkle trees provide fast integrity validation by hashing data layers into a root; changes propagate through recalculated hashes.<hr />- Using "superblocks," Plonky2 verifies transactions efficiently, enhancing scalability.<hr />- Applied in projects like Mina Protocol, Coda, Manta Network, and Ergo to improve performance.<hr />- Example: Rewards points system uses Plonky2 to process vast transactions quickly with minimal blockchain bloat.<hr />- Challenges include ensuring the correctness of Merkle tree elements, safeguarding hash and elliptic curve security, and preventing preimage attacks.<hr />- Deployment complexity involves compatibility issues, security risks, and optimization efforts across different blockchain ecosystems.<hr />- Compared to Lightning Network and Sharding, Plonky2 directly tackles blockchain size and validation speed, not just transaction throughput.<hr />- Unlike SegWit and Lightning, which focus on transaction format and off-chain channels, Plonky2 addresses size and scalability at the cryptographic proof level.<hr />- Sharding divides data, risking security; Plonky2 offers size reduction without compromising security or decentralization.<hr />- Unlike Plasma, which layers transaction processing, Plonky2 focuses on compact proofs reducing full node storage and improving confirmation speed.<hr />- Overall, Plonky2 synergizes succinct proofs, Merkle trees, and non-interactive attestations to promote scalable, secure blockchain systems.

463.title: Introduce to Solana Token 2022 - new standard to create a token in solana
463.description: Explore Solana Token 2022, the next-generation token standard on Solana blockchain. Learn about its key features like transfer fees, non-transferable tokens, and confidential transfers. Discover how Token Extensions enhance functionality, improve security, and enable regulatory compliance for developers and businesses in the Solana ecosystem.
463.spr_content: - Solana Token 2022 introduces token extensions as an advanced standard within the Solana Program Library.<hr />- Base Token program allows minting, transferring, freezing tokens; extensions add functionalities like confidential transfers, custom logic, extended metadata.<hr />- Key extensions include:<hr />  - Transfer Fees: impose in-token fees on transfers.<hr />  - Non-Transferable: create soul-bound tokens linked intrinsically to owners.<hr />  - Permanent Delegate: assign a fixed delegate for token accounts.<hr />  - Transfer Hook: embed custom logic during transfers.<hr />  - Metadata: attach custom metadata directly on token mint, reducing account and rent overhead.<hr />  - Confidential Transfer: mask balances and transfer amounts, with issuer auditability.<hr />  - Default Account State: set new accounts frozen by default.<hr />- Benefits:<hr />  - Enhanced functionality: privacy, automatic fees, interest-like features.<hr />  - Security: standardized, pre-built tools reduce development burden.<hr />  - Regulatory compliance: enforceable metadata, non-transferability, clawback via Permanent Delegate.<hr />- Use cases:<hr />  - Bern (BONK): uses transfer fees; 6.9% fee, split between burning BONK/BERN and holder rewards, demonstrating fee and burn mechanics.<hr />  - Wen New Standard (WNS): lightweight NFT with embedded metadata, royalties, immutable ownership; uses Metadata, Metadata Pointer, Transfer Hook, Immutable Owner.<hr />  - Paxos USDP: regulated stablecoin with confidential transfers and clawback via Permanent Delegate to comply with NYDFS regulations.<hr />- Future directions:<hr />  - Over a dozen extensions enable stablecoins, game assets, governance, RWA issuance.<hr />  - Adoption by major stakeholders: GMOTrust, Paxos, Phantom, SolFlare, FluxbeamDEX.<hr />- Overall, token extensions unlock scalable, compliant, feature-rich tokens, expanding Solana’s DeFi, NFT, and enterprise ecosystem capabilities.

464.title: NFT Fractionalization
464.description: NFT Fractionalization is a process of dividing a non-fungible token (NFT) into smaller, fractional tokens that represent partial ownership of the original NFT. This article provides an overview of fractional NFTs, how they work, and their benefits.
464.spr_content: Fractional NFT is a divided whole NFT, represented by multiple ERC-20 tokens, each signifying partial ownership.  <hr />Fractionalization involves locking the NFT in a smart contract, which creates tokens per owner instructions—number, price, metadata.  <hr />Tokens are tradable on secondary markets, enabling fractional ownership, liquidity, and market price discovery.  <hr />Benefits include improved liquidity, better price signals via partial sales, and potential curator fees for owners.  <hr />Fractionalization enhances market access and valuation accuracy, facilitates exits, and incentivizes marketplace participation.

465.title: Metaplex NFT Compression
465.description: Metaplex NFT Compression is a technology that allows for the compression of NFTs on the Solana blockchain, reducing the cost of on-chain storage for NFTs. This article provides an overview of the technology, how it works, and its potential impact on the Solana ecosystem.
465.spr_content: NFT proliferation on Solana driven by demand for ubiquitous digital assets  <hr />Items include game inventories, app engagement proofs, personal profiles for all humans  <hr />Low rent cost (◎0.012) scales linearly, becoming expensive with large NFT quantities  <hr />Compression reduces on-chain storage costs dramatically at scale  <hr />Example: 10,000 NFTs at ◎3.5 (34x), 1 million at ◎5 (2,400x), 1 billion at ◎500 (24,000x)  <hr />Compression uses Merkle trees via Gummyroll program for storage and updates  <hr />Roots stored/on-chain in a buffer; modifications encoded in Solana ledger  <hr />Off-chain indexers monitor ledger changes, cache metadata, serve for dApps and smart contracts  <hr />Merkle root buffer allows multiple simultaneous writes; ensures validity across versions  <hr />Impact: Enables cost-effective mass adoption, expression, and utility of NFTs on Solana  <hr />Metaplex collaborates with wallets (Phantom, Solflare), RPCs (Quicknode, Alchemy, Triton), enterprise tools (Crossmint, GenysysGo)  <hr />Solution accelerates NFT accessibility, programmability, and ecosystem scalability  <hr />This marks a major technological shift in NFT deployment and potential use cases on Solana

466.title: Polygon zkEVM architecture
466.description: This article provides an overview of the Polygon zkEVM architecture, including its main components, how it works, and its benefits.
466.spr_content: - Polygon zkEVM architecture prioritizes efficiency, minimizing on-chain data and offloading computational tasks.<hr />- Incentivize most efficient aggregators via Proof of Efficiency (PoE), deploying decentralized auctions for batch creation.<hr />- PoE uses zk-STARKs for fast proof generation and zk-SNARKs to reduce proof size and gas costs.<hr />- All computation shifts off-chain; only finalized zk-proofs are stored on-chain.<hr />- Decentralize bridge via LX-to-Ly smart contracts for asset transfers across layers.<hr />- Main components include Proof of Efficiency, zkNode software, zkProver, and Layer 2 bridges.<hr />- zkNode enables any zkEVM node to synchronize and participate as Sequencer or Aggregator without complex setup.<hr />- zkProver comprises a state machine executor, STARK and SNARK proof builders, ensuring batch validity under polynomial constraints.<hr />- Proof of Efficiency mechanisms use decentralized auctions where participants bid tokens for batch creation rights.<hr />- Sequencers batch user transactions, submit them as L1 transactions with CALLDATA, and generate new L2 state proofs.<hr />- Aggregators process sequencer outputs, submit proofs to smart contracts, earning MATIC incentives.<hr />- Incentive structure aligns: sequencers profit from transaction fees minus L1 costs; aggregators profit from MATIC fees exceeding proof costs.<hr />- zkEVM design leverages zk-folklore principles to reduce proof sizes, transaction finality, and gas costs.<hr />- zkProver's core modules include the main executor, recursion component, CIRCOM library, and zk-SNARK prover.<hr />- Bridge processes rely on Merkle trees (globalExitTree and mainnet exit tree) for secure asset transfers and claims.<hr />- Layer 2 contracts manage exit roots and facilitate cross-network asset consistency.<hr />- RPC interface ensures compatibility with Ethereum tools (Metamask, Etherscan) for interaction and transaction management.<hr />- Network state maintained via Merkle Trees, integrating with database backends, verifying block integrity, and executing EVM code.<hr />- Resources include Polygon zkEVM docs, proofs, repo, and related literature on zkRollups and bridges.

467.title: Liquidity pool
467.description: A comprehensive guide to understanding liquidity pools in blockchain, covering their definition, functionality, the role of automated market makers (AMM), arbitrage, pool depth, slippage, how to provide liquidity, and the concept of impermanent loss. This article provides insights for both beginners and experienced users in decentralized finance (DeFi)
467.spr_content: - Liquidity pool: tokens locked in smart contract, enables swapping, provides liquidity, earns trading fees proportional to stake.<hr />- Liquidity pools underpin DEX, utilize Automated Market Maker (AMM), governed by constant product formula: x * y = k.<hr />- x, y: token balances in pool; k: unchanging constant; maintains market prices via x and y adjustments.<hr />- Example: ETH-DAI pool with 10 ETH and 1,000 DAI: buy 1 ETH; deposit DAI to keep k constant; new balances approximate 9 ETH and 1,111.11 DAI.<hr />- Arbitragers correct price deviations; buy low on one platform, sell high in pool; balance market price towards true market value.<hr />- Pool depth (k): larger k, deeper pool, less slippage; smaller pool causes higher price impact for trades.<hr />- Slippage: price difference between pool and market; inversely related to pool size; bigger pools yield lower slippage.<hr />- Providing liquidity: user deposits equal value of two tokens (ratio 50-50); receives LP tokens representing share.<hr />- LP tokens: indicate stake; accrue trading fees; fees distributed proportionally; returns may differ from initial deposit due to market shifts.<hr />- Market dynamics affect LP deposits: in bull markets ETH supply in pool drops, DAI increases; in bear markets, opposite.<hr />- Impermanent loss: opportunity loss when market moves; holding assets outside pool could yield better returns.<hr />- Calculation of impermanent loss: ETH rise from $100 to $120; pool's x,y adjusted via sqrt(k/price) and sqrt(k*price); LP’s withdrawn assets less valuable due to impermanent loss.<hr />- Impermanent loss is not realized until withdrawal; risk mitigated by fee earnings and market movements.<hr />- Overall: liquidity pools facilitate decentralized trading, with inherent risks managed by arbitrage, pool depth, and fee income.

468.title: Ton: Blockchain of blockchains
468.description: Talk about TON and its core technologies. Why do we call TON the "Blockchain of blockchains"?
468.spr_content: - TON (The Open Network) is a blockchain platform developed by Telegram creators, utilizing advanced sharding, multi-blockchain architecture, and Hypercube Routing for scalability and security.<hr />- It employs an Actor Model where every component, including wallets, is a smart contract acting as an actor with storage and behavior.<hr />- Actors are activated by messages, process events via their contract code on the TON Virtual Machine, potentially modify their state, produce outgoing messages, then standby.<hr />- Sequential actor behaviors form transactions; multiple transactions form a chain, called AccountChain when owned by a single account.<hr />- Chains are grouped into shards (AccountShard), which combine into larger structures: Chain of shards (ShardChain), and ultimately a Blockchain (Masterchain or Workchain).<hr />- TON features two primary blockchains: Workchain (normal transactions) and Masterchain (manages other blockchains, synchronized message routing).<hr />- Sharding enables scalability: large ShardChains can split into smaller shards or merge based on transaction volume and utilization.<hr />- Sharding address allocation uses binary prefixes of account addresses, maintaining determinism during splits and merges.<hr />- Instant Hypercube Routing structures shard communication as a hypercube, with message paths optimized through multi-dimensional, bit-flip routing.<hr />- This routing technique ensures scalability, rapid message delivery, fault tolerance, and efficient handling of infinite shards—each shard as a node in a high-dimensional network.<hr />- Overall, TON’s architecture combines blockchain of blockchains, actor concurrency, and hypercube routing to achieve a scalable, fast, secure, and interoperable decentralized platform.

469.title: Implement a Token Swap from the Base chain to Bitcoin for cross-chain transactions
469.description: This guide shows how to implement a token swap from the Base Chain to Bitcoin.
469.spr_content: - Swapping ICY tokens for Bitcoin involves exchanging digital currencies across incompatible blockchains.  <hr />- ICY operates on the Base chain; Bitcoin on its own blockchain.  <hr />- Direct swaps are impossible due to blockchain incompatibility and differences in system features.  <hr />- Tools key to the process include swap contracts, treasury wallets, and the Icy-Backend system.  <hr />- Swap contracts are automated on the Base chain to manage the exchange securely.  <hr />- Treasury wallets temporarily hold ICY tokens and Bitcoin during the swap.  <hr />- Icy-Backend receives swap requests, tracks them, and triggers Bitcoin transfers.  <hr />- The process starts when a user initiates a swap via the website, specifying amounts and addresses.  <hr />- The system records requests by listening to swap contract events for tracking.  <hr />- ICY tokens are burned to remove them from circulation, signaling swap initiation.  <hr />- Backend checks for the swap request and, using stored data, releases Bitcoin from treasury wallets.  <hr />- Multiple automatic retries via cronjobs ensure delivery if issues occur.  <hr />- Price determination is detailed in a related guide, ensuring fair valuation.  <hr />- The entire process employs specialized tools and automated steps to bridge blockchain incompatibilities securely.

470.title: zk-SNARKs
470.description: ZK-SNARKs is a type of zero-knowledge proof that allows one party to prove to another that a given statement is true, without revealing any additional information. This article provides an overview of zk-SNARKs, how they work, and their applications in blockchain technology.
470.spr_content: - Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-Interactive Arguments of Knowledge (ZK-SNARKs) facilitate privacy proofs without revealing sensitive information.<hr />- Zero-Knowledge (ZK) proofs demonstrate possession of data or knowledge without disclosure.<hr />- Succinctness ensures rapid verification, regardless of statement length.<hr />- Non-interactivity allows a single proof message from prover to verifier without multiple rounds.<hr />- Function C: public input `x`, secret witness `w`; prove `C(x,w)===true` without revealing `w`.<hr />- Hash example: Alice proves she knows `S` such that `H=SHA(S)` without revealing `S`.<hr />- The proof validates `SHA(S)===H` without revealing `S`.<hr />- ZK-SNARKs comprise three core functions: key generator `G`, prover `P`, verifier `V`.<hr />- `G(lambda, C)` generates key pair `(pk, vk)` using secret parameter `lambda`.<hr />- `pk` and `vk` are generated once per program `C`; they facilitate proof creation and verification.<hr />- `P(pk, x, w)` produces proof `prf` confirming knowledge of `w` satisfying `C`.<hr />- `V(vk, x, prf)` determines proof validity; outputs true/false.<hr />- Security risk: knowledge of `lambda` allows malicious proof forgery; mitigated via multi-party trusted setup.<hr />- Trusted setup involves independent parties generating `lambda` to produce `pk` and `vk` securely.<hr />- Implementation in Ethereum: zk-SNARK verification incorporated via precompiled contracts in Layer 1.<hr />- Layer 2 processes generate proofs using `pk`; Layer 1 verifies using `vk`, `proof`, and public inputs, enabling efficient scaling and privacy.

471.title: Thumbs up and Thumbs down pattern
471.description: The article talks about how important human feedback is for making large language models better, especially using thumbs up and down. It explains the Pearson correlation coefficient, which measures how variables are related. The thumbs system is an easy way for users to show if responses are helpful or not, which encourages more feedback and keeps users engaged. This feedback helps improve training data and makes the models more accurate. The article includes examples in sentiment analysis for reviews and content moderation, showing how this feedback helps understand user opinions and filter out bad content on sites like YouTube and Twitter.
471.spr_content: User feedback via thumbs up/down enhances LLM training by providing clear positive or negative signals.  <hr />Positive feedback indicates helpful responses; negative feedback signals need for improvement.  <hr />This mechanism simplifies user interaction, encouraging frequent and steady feedback.  <hr />More feedback improves model understanding and alignment with user preferences.  <hr />Pearson correlation quantifies relationships between variables; ranges from -1 (perfect negative) to +1 (perfect positive), 0 means no relation.  <hr />Thumbs up/down feedback is valuable in sentiment analysis, aiding in recognizing positive/negative reviews.  <hr />It also supports content moderation by flagging harmful or inappropriate content, assisting future filtering.  <hr />Platforms like YouTube and Twitter utilize like/dislike metrics to identify trends and ensure safety.  <hr />Simple, quick feedback loops, combined with statistical measures like Pearson, optimize model learning and content quality.

472.title: RAPTOR: Tree-based Retrieval for Language Models
472.description: An overview of RAPTOR, a novel approach for improving retrieval-augmented language models for long documents using hierarchical tree summaries.
472.spr_content: - RAPTOR addresses limitations of traditional retrieval methods that only access short, contiguous text segments.<hr />- It targets large-scale discourse understanding and multi-part thematic questions.<hr />- Employs recursive embedding, clustering, and summarization to build hierarchical text representations.<hr />- Creates a tree structure with multiple levels of abstraction, from detailed chunks to high-level summaries.<hr />- Segments text into 100-token chunks, embeds with SBERT.<hr />- Clusters similar chunks via Gaussian Mixture Models.<hr />- Summarizes clusters using LLMs like GPT-3.5-turbo.<hr />- Iteratively repeats clustering and summarization to form a bottom-up tree.<hr />- During retrieval, uses either tree traversal or a collapsed tree approach for relevance-based node selection.<hr />- Matches nodes across all layers using cosine similarity.<hr />- Retrieves information across various abstraction levels, enabling comprehensive, layered responses.<hr />- Combines clustering (GMMs) and summarization (LLMs) for flexible, hierarchical retrieval.<hr />- Outperforms traditional retrieval methods (BM25, DPR) in question-answering tasks.<hr />- Excels at complex, multi-part inquiries requiring integrated knowledge.<hr />- Scales linearly with document size, providing efficiency.<hr />- Achieves state-of-the-art performance on benchmarks (NarrativeQA, QASPER, QuALITY) with metrics like BLEU, ROUGE, METEOR, F1, and Accuracy.<hr />- Facilitates deep understanding and retrieval from long, structured texts by integrating multi-level summaries.

473.file_path: playground/topics/ai/Workaround with OpenAI's token limit with Langchain.md
473.title: Workaround with OpenAI's token limit with Langchain
473.description: This article explores strategies to overcome OpenAI's token limit using Langchain, including stuffing, map-reduce, refining, and map-rerank methods. It discusses the advantages and drawbacks of each approach in handling large documents or prompts while working within the constraints of OpenAI's API.
473.spr_content: - OpenAI’s ChatGPT tuning is limited by lack of direct model access and strict token constraints (~4,000 tokens per prompt+response).<hr />- Token limit affects the ability to input large context or documents for comprehensive responses.<hr />- LangChain framework supports models, prompts, memory, indexes, chains, and agents, enabling environment-aware language applications.<hr />- Strategies to mitigate token limit include:<hr />  - Stuffing: embedding entire resource within token constraints; simple, effective for small documents.<hr />  - Map-Reduce: splitting large documents into smaller parts, summarizing, then consolidating; parallelizable, but risk information loss.<hr />  - Refining: iterative prompting to enhance context accuracy before final summarization; increases API calls but improves quality.<hr />  - Map-Rerank: dividing documents into chunks, evaluating, and selecting highest-rated answers; ideal for structured, sectioned info but loses cross-chunk context.<hr />- These methods resemble distributed data paradigms, balancing between completeness, accuracy, and API cost.<hr />- Multiple API calls required, driving higher operational costs.<hr />- Overall, layered, modular approaches aim to extend effective prompt length within systemic constraints.

474.title: Guardrails in llm
474.description: Inspite of having strength to process and produce highly coherent human-like, behavior of LLM is unpredictable, so the need of a safety mechanisms and boundaries that control and direct an AI model's behavior to ensure it operates safely, ethically, and within intended parameters is crucial...
474.spr_content: - LLMs have strong processing and coherence capabilities but unpredictable behaviors.<hr />- Safety mechanisms and boundaries are essential to control and guide LLMs.<hr />- Guardrails in LLMs are strategies for ensuring safe, ethical, and intended operations.<hr />- Unpredictability can lead to inappropriate or harmful outputs; guardrails mitigate this.<hr />- Input guardrails preprocess inputs: filter profanity, hate speech, PII, and restrict topics.<hr />- Topical guardrails limit responses to designated domains; example: technology only.<hr />- Jailbreaking detection prevents users from overriding LLM prompts.<hr />- PII redaction anonymizes sensitive user information.<hr />- Output guardrails post-process outputs: remove harmful content, validate facts, moderate responses.<hr />- Fact-checking guardrails verify information accuracy; moderation guardrails enforce brand and ethical standards.<hr />- Syntax checks ensure structured outputs; vital for function calling or parseable responses.<hr />- Trade-offs include latency, increased costs, potential response restriction, and user frustration.<hr />- Guardrails may hinder stream mode and legitimate use cases if over-applied.<hr />- Balance is key: safety and ethics versus usability and user experience.<hr />- Implementing guardrails is a best practice, adjusting per specific context and risks.<hr />- References provide detailed techniques and frameworks for LLM guardrails.
474.category: playground > topics > ai > Building LLM system

475.title: Prevent prompt injection
475.description: Nowadays, Large Language Models (LLMs) have become integral to various applications. However, with great power comes great responsibility, and the rise of LLMs has introduced new security challenges. One such challenge is prompt injection attacks, a sophisticated technique that can manipulate AI systems to perform unintended actions. In this article, we'll dive deep into the world of prompt injection, understand its implications, and explore strategies to prevent these attacks.
475.spr_content: - LLMs are integral to diverse applications, increasing associated security challenges.<hr />- Prompt injection involves adversarially manipulating prompts to alter LLM behavior.<hr />- Primary goal: override instructions, access data, perform unauthorized actions.<hr />- Injection methods: direct (malicious commands embedded), indirect (encoding/obfuscation).<hr />- Attack can bypass security in profile management systems via crafted usernames.<hr />- Example: malicious username encodes instruction to reveal other users’ profiles.<hr />- Complete prevention is impossible due to training data gaps and model generalization.<hr />- Mitigation techniques: post-prompting (removing user input from critical prompts).<hr />- Mitigation techniques: random enclosure of user inputs to differentiate and block instruction overrides.<hr />- Mitigation techniques: fine-tuning with diverse datasets to improve guardrails.<hr />- Additional methods include XML tagging, sandwich defenses, instruction defenses.<hr />- Prompt injection poses significant privacy and security risks.<hr />- Best practices reduce, but do not eliminate, vulnerability.<hr />- Recognize inherent challenges: total safety against prompt injection is unfeasible.<hr />- Continuous refinement and layered defenses are essential for security.
475.category: playground > topics > ai > Building LLM system

476.title: Metrics
476.description: Metrics give you the rundown on how your LLM’s performing. We will show how to use these metrics to identify issues, increase efficiency, and make changes for improved outcomes.
476.spr_content: - Observability in LLM applications relies on metrics indicating correctness, performance, and efficiency.  <hr />- Metrics serve to fine-tune systems and monitor health, influencing user experience and trust.<hr /><hr />**System Metrics:**  <hr />- Latency measures response time; low latency enhances user satisfaction, high latency causes frustration.  <hr />- Throughput quantifies request handling capacity; critical in high-demand environments for maintaining performance.  <hr />- Error Rate reflects system reliability; high error rates signal issues necessitating immediate attention.  <hr />- Resource Utilization tracks CPU, memory, disk usage; identifies bottlenecks and guides resource scaling.<hr /><hr />**Model Metrics (Scoring):**  <hr />- Perplexity predicts next word; lower perplexity indicates better language understanding.  <hr />- BLEU compares generated text to references; higher scores suggest more accurate outputs.  <hr />- METEOR accounts for synonyms and stems; better semantic alignment improves evaluation depth.  <hr />- ROUGE measures n-gram overlap; useful for summarization assessment.<hr /><hr />**Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) Metrics:**  <hr />- Precision@K evaluates relevance in top K retrieved documents; higher values mean more relevant info.  <hr />- Recall@K assesses coverage of relevant info; ensures critical data isn't missed.  <hr />- MRR checks position of first relevant doc; higher scores imply quicker relevance.  <hr />- NDCG weighs ranking positions; higher scores prioritize pertinent results, improving UX.<hr /><hr />**Fine-Tuning Metrics:**  <hr />- Performance improvement compares pre/post training scores; indicates tuning efficacy.  <hr />- Training Time monitors process duration; efficiency gains aid deployment speed.  <hr />- Overfitting Rate assesses model generalization; low overfitting ensures robustness.  <hr />- Loss Reduction signals learning progress; significant drops reflect better fit.  <hr />- User Feedback offers qualitative insights; complements quantitative measures for holistic assessment.<hr /><hr />**Cost Metrics:**  <hr />- Pricing per Request tracks expense per user interaction; essential for budgeting.  <hr />- Token In/Out monitors token counts; correlates with usage costs.  <hr />- Total Time aggregates processing duration; impacts operational costs.  <hr />- Resource Costs reflect cloud expenses; critical for financial planning.  <hr />- Service Rate Limits define constraints; influence system scalability and cost management.<hr /><hr />**Overall,** implementing comprehensive metrics across system, model, retrieval, fine-tuning, and cost domains ensures observability, supports high performance, and optimizes user satisfaction and operational efficiency.
476.category: playground > topics > ai > Building LLM system

477.title: Model selection
477.description: Learn how to choose the right AI model for your needs. Explore key factors like accuracy, privacy, and cost. Compare commercial vs open-source options and API vs self-hosting approaches.
477.spr_content: Model selection is about aligning tools with specific needs, not finding universal solutions.  <hr />Each model has strengths and trade-offs; priorities guide choices.  <hr />Hard attributes are fixed constraints—licensing, training data, privacy; non-negotiable.  <hr />Soft attributes are adjustable—accuracy, speed, reliability—improve over time.  <hr />Model suitability depends on use case context—hosting environment influences attribute framing.  <hr />First rule: filter models by hard attributes to meet must-haves.  <hr />Second rule: prioritize accuracy, then optimize soft attributes afterward.  <hr />Benchmarks offer initial comparisons but are limited; multiple, domain-specific benchmarks are required.  <hr />Beware data contamination in benchmarks—models memorizing training data can mislead performance estimates.  <hr />Models fall into categories:  <hr />- Closed-source (proprietary, API-based, e.g., GPT-4).  <hr />- Open-weight (self-hosted, customizable, e.g., Llama, Mistral).  <hr />- Open-source (full transparency but limited legal clarity).  <hr />Licensing restrictions impact use-case flexibility, even with open models.  <hr />Hosting options:  <hr />- API access simplifies deployment but restricts control and might be costly at scale.  <hr />- Self-hosting offers control, privacy, and feature customization but demands technical investment.  <hr />Factors influencing hosting choice include:  <hr />- Data privacy concerns—API may pose risks.  <hr />- Performance needs—proprietary models often outperform open-source.  <hr />- Feature requirements—specific tools or outputs may necessitate certain providers.  <hr />- Cost considerations—balance API expenses versus engineering costs of self-hosting.  <hr />- Control and flexibility—self-hosting grants more freedom but adds complexity.  <hr />In summary, selecting a model involves balancing privacy, performance, cost, and control.  <hr />Define clear must-haves, run real-world tests, and choose adaptable solutions.  <hr />Whether API or self-hosted, ongoing evaluation and performance monitoring ensure the model remains aligned with evolving needs.
477.category: playground > topics > ai > Building LLM system

478.title: Intent classification by LLM
478.description: User intent classification is a crucial aspect of conversational AI, start with machine learning models, but now advanced language models (LLMs) are being explored for this task. Unlike the old methods which is need to labeled datasets exhaustively, LLMs can understand what users mean without all that preparation. This memo explores the application of LLMs in intent classification, highlighting their potential to streamline the process and overcome traditional NLU limitations.
478.spr_content: - User intent classification is vital for conversational AI.<hr />- Traditional methods rely on exhaustive labeled datasets.<hr />- LLMs can interpret user meaning without large labeled data, understanding context and nuance.<hr />- Intent classification identifies a user's goal behind input.<hr />- Methods include human involvement and machine learning.<hr />- LLM enables dynamic flow changes based on intent classification.<hr />- Example: e-commerce chatbot uses JSON prompts for intent recognition:<hr />  - product_search with keywords.<hr />  - add_to_cart with product_name.<hr />  - view_cart.<hr />  - checkout.<hr />  - customer_support with issue.<hr />  - other with message.<hr />- LLM processes input, allowing multi-step, content-rich flow control.<hr />- Include fallback options (e.g., "Other") to handle unexpected inputs.<hr />- Fallback maintains user engagement via clarification or human escalation.<hr />- Chain-of-thought prompting improves classification accuracy and explainability.<hr />- Without CoT: direct classification; with CoT: reasoning enhances decision quality.<hr />- Temperature controls response randomness; lower for deterministic, higher for creative outputs.<hr />- Few-shot prompting with labeled examples enhances model performance.<hr />- Limitations:<hr />  - Multiple intents increase complexity and risk confusion.<hr />  - Hallucinations can cause misclassification.<hr />  - Lack of transparency in decision processes without explicit reasoning (CoT).<hr />- Intent classification, empowered by LLMs, streamlines workflows and enhances conversational AI capabilities.
478.category: playground > topics > ai > Building LLM system

479.title: Multi-agent collaboration for task completion
479.description: In AI integrated systems, instead of put all workload on a single agent, we can apply divide and conquer strategy to distribute workload to multiple agents. This approach can enhance task completion by leveraging the unique skills and capabilities of each agent.This approach allows for more complex and nuanced problem-solving, as well as increased efficiency and scalability. By coordinating and communicating effectively, agents can work together to achieve common goals, divide labor, and overcome challenges that a single agent might face alone
479.spr_content: - Divide and conquer strategy distributes workloads across multiple specialized agents rather than a single agent.<hr />- Multiple agents leverage unique skills for complex, nuanced problem-solving, enhancing efficiency and scalability.<hr />- Effective communication and coordination among agents are critical for achieving shared goals and overcoming limitations of individual agents.<hr />- Single AI agent with access to all features may underperform on multi-step, feature-intensive tasks due to complexity or system prompts.<hr />- System design involves a supervisor agent orchestrating workflow, routing tasks, and aggregating results from specialized worker agents.<hr />- Worker agents focus on specific modules (e.g., Event, Project) with precise prompts and tools, enabling modular responsibility.<hr />- Variations include layered super-agents or shared tool pools, but core concept remains workload distribution via multi-agent collaboration.<hr />- Example scenario: event management application uses supervisor to route requests; Event and Project agents handle respective modules.<hr />- Supervisor analyzes user requests to assign appropriate worker agents, manages task decomposition, and consolidates outcomes until completion.<hr />- Inside the system, task division, reasoning, and tool invocation occur iteratively, with agents using LLM capabilities to decide on actions.<hr />- Multi-agent systems improve task accuracy and efficiency but require well-designed prompts and robust workflow management.<hr />- Challenges: coordination and communication overhead; solutions involve clear role definitions and an overseeing supervisor agent.<hr />- Overall, multi-agent AI systems emulate collaborative human teams, enabling scalable, complex task handling within applications.
479.category: playground > topics > ai > Building LLM system

480.file_path: playground/topics/ai/Building LLM system/§ Building LLM System.md
480.title: § Building LLM system
480.description: This map of content (MoC) outlines the critical components required to design and build a large language model (LLM) system, focusing on architecture, model customization, safeguarding, performance evaluation, and more.
480.spr_content: LLMs revolutionize AI with natural language understanding and generation, enabling diverse industry use cases. Building robust systems involves model selection, architecture, and tech stack integration. Critical factors include choosing models aligned with business needs, balancing performance and cost, and customizing via fine-tuning and prompt engineering. Enhancing context through retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), multimodal RAG, agentic RAG, and query rewriting improves accuracy. Managing output involves formatting, schema enforcement, and chaining responses to ensure structured, actionable results. Safeguards prevent misuse, data leaks, and bad outputs via guardrails. Routing and access control utilize intent classifiers, model gateways, and next-action prediction to manage multiple models securely. Latency is optimized through caching strategies: prompt, exact, and semantic caches. Complex reasoning, task delegation, and actions are handled through conditional logic, write actions, prompt injection prevention, multi-agent architectures, ReAct, and ReWOO. Performance is measured with tailored metrics, including AI-as-a-judge approaches. Monitoring and orchestrating workflows ensure system observability and smooth AI pipeline operations, integrating various components effectively.
480.category: playground > topics > ai > Building LLM system

481.title: Evaluation guidelines for LLM applications
481.description: This guide offers a structured approach to evaluating and optimizing the integration of third-party Large Language Models (LLMs) into applications, ensuring alignment with business goals and user needs through detailed checklists and evaluation metrics.
481.spr_content: - Evaluation in RAG systems is complex but essential for aligning model performance with business and technical goals.  <hr />- Structured checklists ensure comprehensive review of search, retrieval, response quality, latency, cost, and user experience.  <hr />- In retrieval, prioritize precision and recall, with specific metrics like 85% and 90%, ensuring relevant documents are retrieved accurately and efficiently.  <hr />- Task-specific accuracy (e.g., 95% in legal clause retrieval) and latency (<2 seconds for real-time responses) are critical benchmarks.  <hr />- Response generation quality is measured via coherence (>80%), coherence scores, human annotations, and reference to retrieved data.  <hr />- Token usage must be optimized (e.g., under 10,000 tokens per query) to balance cost and performance.  <hr />- Fine-tuning enhances task comprehension, reduces errors, and improves specificity; metrics like accuracy and loss should steadily improve after training.  <hr />- Post-fine-tuning, key metrics like task accuracy (targeting 90-95%) and response speed (<1.5 seconds) are essential for validation.  <hr />- Evaluation tools such as RAGAS and G-Eval facilitate targeted metric assessment including relevance, faithfulness, correctness, coherence, bias, and toxicity.  <hr />- Synthetic datasets provide controlled testing, especially for edge cases and privacy-sensitive scenarios.  <hr />- Search evaluation combines vector methods (NDCG, MRR) and full-text approaches (precision, recall, F1), often integrated with hybrid metrics for balanced assessment.  <hr />- Model as evaluator (LLMs judging responses) offers advantages: human-like judgment, continuous operation, multilingual support, and adaptable scoring based on relevance, clarity, and fairness.  <hr />- Establish baselines and targets (e.g., 85% accuracy, 700ms latency) with acceptable ranges to monitor ongoing improvements.  <hr />- Monitoring tools (LangFuse, LangSmith) track real-time performance, enabling rapid diagnosis and iterative improvements.  <hr />- Coverage must be extensive—include edge cases, integrate CI/CD for automated checks, and leverage analytics plus user feedback to refine system performance.  <hr />- Fine-tuning addresses retrieval gaps, improves understanding, reduces errors, and better handles rare cases, demonstrated by measurable metric improvements post-tuning (+15% in accuracy, -3% error rate).  <hr />- Overall, systematic evaluation using metrics, tools, and feedback ensures RAG integration aligns with user expectations and business objectives, optimizing usability and efficiency.
481.category: playground > topics > ai > Building LLM system

482.title: Tracing
482.description: Tracing is like following your LLM’s journey, step by step. We will explain how tracing makes it easy to identify and address problems by allowing you to track the entire process.
482.spr_content: - Tracing monitors, debugs, and visualizes the execution of LLM applications.<hr />- It captures a snapshot of actions like LLM calls, prompt formatting, or function execution.<hr />- A trace is a graph/tree of actions, composed of spans.<hr />- Each span represents an individual operation with specific inputs and outputs.<hr />- The Root Run is the top-level action triggered by the user or app.<hr />- Tracing reveals performance metrics: duration, token count, sequence of actions.<hr />- Essential for error detection, performance tuning, and full request path visualization.<hr />- Tools like Klu.ai and LangSmith log calls, visualize inputs/outputs, and track errors/costs.<hr />- Tracing aids in understanding origin, provenance, and model source amidst diverse model releases.<hr />- Differentiates trace (overall request lifecycle) from span (individual step) in scope and granularity.<hr />- A trace encompasses multiple spans, forming a tree with a root span representing total task time.<hr />- Spans are detailed units: measuring duration, inputs, outputs, errors, and attributes.<hr />- Common span types: Chain (workflow), Embedding, Retrieval, LLM, Tool, Agent.<hr />- Tracing supports identifying latency issues, token spend, runtime exceptions, retrieved docs, and parameter use.<hr />- Enhances debugging, performance analysis, and system comprehension.<hr />- Ultimately, tracing enables transparent, detailed oversight of LLM app operations.
482.category: playground > topics > ai > Building LLM system

483.title: Logging
483.description: Logs are like the footprints of your LLM, tracking every move it makes. We will look at how logging can help you see beneath the top layer of a system, which can help you troubleshoot problems and better understand the system behavior.
483.spr_content: - Logging in generative AI applications records user inputs, model outputs, and system events, enabling comprehensive system tracking.  <hr />- It captures questions asked and answers provided, reflecting the interaction process.  <hr />- Logs encompass inputs, outputs, system state, memory usage, prompts, and contextual metadata for detailed analysis.  <hr />- Effective logging enhances user experience by revealing interaction patterns, informing response improvements, and guiding updates.  <hr />- Logs identify model performance issues; analyzing them guides prompt adjustments, configuration tuning, and parameter optimization.  <hr />- Logging accelerates debugging by pinpointing failure points, component errors, or unexpected behaviors, saving troubleshooting time.  <hr />- Logs facilitate data-driven decision-making, revealing trends and informing feature development and resource allocation.  <hr />- Session logging archives all interactions in a session, including response confidence scores and evaluation metrics—detecting recurring issues or low-quality responses.  <hr />- Metadata logging (component type, latency, user device, location, timestamp) supports performance segmentation and scenario analysis.  <hr />- Prompt management involves logging prompts, responses, and scores, enabling prompt fine-tuning and performance assessment.  <hr />- Model parameters (temperature, max tokens, top-k, top-p) are logged to monitor their influence on output diversity, length, and quality.  <hr />- Management agents’ inputs and outputs are logged for debugging, task monitoring, and performance optimization.  <hr />- Chain and step logging assess retrieval accuracy, response quality, and tool performance within multi-step workflows.  <hr />- Evaluation scoring logs track accuracy, relevance, and conciseness, creating performance benchmarks and identifying model weaknesses.  <hr />- Visualization tools (dashboards, charts) synthesize logged data for trend analysis, real-time monitoring, and stakeholder communication.  <hr />- Feedback loops leverage logged insights; human-in-the-loop enhances model adjustment, error correction, and response refinement.  <hr />- Log analysis forms a basis for continuous improvement, increasing accuracy and user satisfaction through iterative feedback.
483.category: playground > topics > ai > Building LLM system

484.title: ReWOO: Reasoning without observation - A deeper look
484.description: In the process of improving Large Language Model (LLM) performance, many techniques have been proposed. The Augmented Language Model (ALM) approach boosted LLM accuracy by enabling the attachment of external sources to enhance the model's knowledge. However, ALMs still had limitations in terms of time consumption and token resources. To address these issues, ReWOO was developed as a more efficient solution.
484.spr_content: - LLM performance improves through various techniques; external source attachment (ALM) increases accuracy but consumes time and tokens.<hr />- ALMs integrate external information to enhance knowledge but suffer from inefficiency.<hr />- ReWOO (Reasoning Without Observation) decouples reasoning from external tool observation, focusing on modular, independent components.<hr />- Modularity enables easy modification and maintenance without affecting other parts.<hr />- ReWOO reduces token consumption by minimizing LLM calls, leveraging interaction with external tools for evidence retrieval.<hr />- Core process: Planner creates a step-by-step solution blueprint with plans, tools, and evidence variables.<hr />- Worker executes plans using specified tools (Google, LLM, APIs), collecting evidence for each step.<hr />- Solver analyzes all plans and evidence, synthesizing concise final answers, minimizing LLM calls.<hr />- ReWOO leverages previous stage plans for subsequent steps, supporting complex task handling.<hr />- Implementation uses defined prompt templates for planner and solver, executable within frameworks like Langgraph.<hr />- Nodes: Planner (creates plans), Worker (executes plans), Solver (interprets evidence).<hr />- Plan and solve functions parse plans, execute tool calls, and generate final solutions, emphasizing variable referencing with #.<hr />- The system is represented as a graph, connecting stages with directed edges, enabling structured reasoning.<hr />- Example task demonstrates reduction of total LLM calls and token usage compared to ReAct.<hr />- ReWOO’s token savings grow with task complexity;
